review:
Firstly, bear in mind this is one developer's labour of love -- a true indy game. It also came out in 2018, although there have been occasional patches and updates.

[b]Taking that into account[/b] the graphics and animations are top notch, it's not [i]too[/i] buggy and it's a reasonable length.

Since I first played the dev has added a campaign mode, which is probably the best way to play through the first time, but I go back to the "explore" (a random worldgen mode) every few months to cause some chaos!

It has an excellent, if chiefly British, sense of humour. If you like Douglas Adams, Red Dwarf or similar you should have some fun with the flavour text.

review: once you figure out the nuances of this game its actually quite engrossing, yes things can be buggy, when the AI doesnt behave like you think it should but generally speaking it just means a build order got mucked up somewhere and needs deleted and replaced. or something is blocking pathing and needs removed. the ONLY complaint i have about the game is sometimes the procedurally generated maps dont give you much space to build in near where you start and you have to expand to other "caves" pretty quickly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068615700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1334, 'last_played': 1692507388}
review: This is a conflicted positive review. Maia can be a crash-filled, buggy piece of crap but it's awesome when it works. I think most of the negative reviews of the game come down to the lack of feedback on what/where/why things are/aren't happening with your colonists. For example, most people would think "I'll build hydroponics before I build a hospital, because...why wouldn't I?". Because if you don't, your colonists will never harvest hydroponics because they'll be freezing to death in a corner of the base. There are dozens of things like that in Maia and once you figure out the process it's actually a really rewarding colony builder.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025994109', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 2952, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1721, 'last_played': 1690638367}
review: Maia is a promising game but it is very unpolished.  For a base builder it is certainly challenging, but ultimately the problem is that the unit A.I. is just awful.  There is no means of organizing your builders to give things priority.  For example, you would like to give your people orders to build heaters and atmospheric control, and you have the resources, but they ignore the thing that is killing them.  Half the time the sprites are running about following irrelevant paths to nowhere.  It is all very frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036333338', 'num_games_owned': 902, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1674993365}
review:
I have owned this game since it's initial steam release 2013, one of the first games i bought on steam, and back then the game was really promising, and just recently i installed the game and wanted to see how the game had progressed in those 9 years, and in summery it's still promising, and nothing more. 
I can't genuinely recommend this game, with the rate of progress this game might live up to it's potential when i'm 6 feet below, in hopefully 70 years or so.

The game i currently plagued by two major issues:
1. Ai, your little pawn's will run around and do everything but what you want them to, starve when food is available, die of dehydration when water is available, get stuck on corners and more to boot.
2. The UI is utterly unintuitive, most information is obtuse to find or not available at all.

Then there is a general lack of having something to do, currently the only objective is to fight with the game it self to prevent your colony to implode.
If you are interested in the genre i would pass on this and instead look on Evil genius 1 or Dungeon keeper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093589271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1288, 'last_played': 1645859892}
review:
I would hesitantly recommend this game. 

Pros:
-Able to take control and manage individual colonists/robots.
-Can make separate rooms in your colony which can be specialized for specific tasks (workshop,living area,hydroponics)
-Realism (if you have hydroponics and use red and blue light the plants will grow faster).
-Good Graphics

Cons:
-No endgame (after you make your buildings and the colonists are happy there's no much to do. You can research some stuff but that's it. There needs to be more buildings and items. 
-Colonists don't reproduce. (People land on colony and that's it you cap at 15 colonists)
-Colonist relationships are basic (some will complain about others but there is no colonist profile that you can access whenever. Only when the pop up come up once.)
-Can only have 2 livestock (chicken and an alien.)
-Again its SO BORING after you complete everything. Maybe make it so we can expand outside the bounds of the cave area. Build a space station. Author just needs to add more stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968862468', 'num_games_owned': 503, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 805, 'last_played': 1636846375}
review:
This game feels unfinished. 

There's a great foundation but its utterly tarnished by the fact that this game is utterly opaque to the player.

Its very difficult to tell what is going on. And the colonists are just... Dumb. "Fire in Storage" No one is running. Everyone is just leisurely walking around. Um Hello, Fire? Get extinguishers? Something? No?

There's no way to prioritize so if your colonists need toilets, too bad they're going to build something else first. 

Building robots dont help that much either. 
Everyone and everything moves at this leisurely pace where there's no sense of urgency. You'd think the firefighting robots would move quickly but nope, its like an RC car with low batteries.


They sprint like 3 steps and then stop. The 3 steps and then stop. Wounded colonists just... dont appear to do anything about it? I just had two colonists die because they refused to go to medical with beds and dispenser... Is it because the scanner wasnt built? Well gee sure would be nice to prioritize that. Oh wait I cant.

any other colony or building sim type game can let your prioritize but not this game.

I played this way back in early access and I'm still encountering the same issues. I really want to love this game but man it makes it hard. 

Like I said. Great concept and foundation but the execution is just not good.

Edit: Even better I cant get past the second mission because the colonists refuse to collect the samples. I've left the game running for 15 minutes now. Still at 1/3. Avoid avoid avoid

review:
The game crashed a few times after probably 10+ offline hours of gameplay, getting a colony to 15 people, and after I started trying to cram objects into rooms.  With the autosave I only lost a few minutes here and there when it happened.  I didn't really run into any bugs.  I find it to be quite playable with a fair amount of content.

That's not to say I didn't run into problems.  The design of this game will sometimes come across as bugs because it is so far from what most games follow.  Such as the fact that unlike 99% of the colony builders out there your people won't refuse to work in order to get enough rest or follow a schedule.  They will simply die of fatigue if you give them too much to do but you can't see the fatigue level of your people.  You are left wondering what happened.  You don't know what you need to do, what is wrong, or what is about to go wrong.  You are in a perpetual state of guessing.  

What's the first thing you do when you load a colony builder?  Look for the power, temp, and oxygen report or overlay and info on colonist health/mood.  You won't immediately find it.  That info exists (well except colonist info) but you'll have to go hunting for it.  You have to locate the existence of an item in the build menu that does what you want when you can't just view everything in it. You have to select the objects menu while in the right room or against a wall to see those items.  Took awhile to even figure out there was a wall objects menu with a heater.  Mouse over the correct area to get a pop up of the needed info or hunt down reports in the email system in the corner that along with your power and alerts also includes requests whether you'd like to listen to someone's music or poetry.

Games like this generally use overlays and organized reports rather than relying completely on mouse overs and little messages.  I understand the overall feel the dev was going for with the email system but my gmail is more organized than that and I don't use it for anything important.  Using a more limited and rougher system for setting the mood in the game is a very difficult thing that has to be done just right to still provide all the wanted info in easy to access locations without the typical display systems.  This attempt comes close to breaking the game.


Overall I've decided maia's gameplay just feels outdated.  A game in 1998 to early 2000s might have numbered menu lists to select things, rely on hotkeys, make you mouse over things or check messages that appear on the screen for info,etc...  These days most players are used to relying on a mouse instead of keyboard shortcuts and all the needed info ready to access.  At minimum you have a direct drop down/pop up menu that after clicking on the icon for the type of thing you want you then just move your mouse straight up/down to click on what you want from that list.  In Maia you have to hold alt to get a list in text and then move your mouse over to it while the camera spins wildly in the background.  Then fix your camera to place the item.  Option B is to select room or object and then hit q and e to scroll one by one through potentially around 19 items to get the right one.  Tedious, clumsy, outdated.


Somewhat older players used to keyboard controlled list menus, hotkeys, and limited info presentation will have the easiest time adjusting to this game.  Majority of players will likely just get frustrated and quit before they figure it out or after they figure it out they won't want to play with the slow UI design.  If you need everything right there at your fingertips without hotkeys and to know everything going on all the time then this game is not for you.  If you can't handle failing over and over again while figuring out game play that is not at all obvious then don't touch this game.  One attempt I just ignored everyone and let them die while running my mouse over rooms and walls, scrolling around outside, and looking at what was available to me before trying again.   If you want a challenge, like discovering things for yourself or solving puzzles, and don't mind using a keyboard based selection system then this game may have many interesting hours to offer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984757685', 'num_games_owned': 678, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1611541691}
review:
Virtually unplayable in it's current state (25/01/21) Extremely buggy and temperamental. Things built on walls will teleport to other rooms, doors will not connect to rooms and need to be placed again. Despite constant alerts it's often difficult to determine what the problem is, though it's almost always broken pathfinding. Workers will actively ignore certain directions to build or demolish structures, robots will refuse to mine certain walls even under direct control. And regardless of how many heaters, hydroponics, or atmospheric generators you build, most of your colonists will die of hypothermia, starvation or dehydration.
It's a shame because the small amount of plot and flavor text I was able to experience is quite good. A very hitch hikers guide vibe.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985719035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1611519450}
review:
I like the idea behind Maia very much. There is a lot that is not working too good for me but overall the game is going into the right direction. 

Don't expect a well balanced game - it is not. Though, the basics are all there and working. For some reason, it feels meaningless after playing a while. My guess is, that the GUI is simply hiding too much information that I like to have in these type of games. Why is it so hard to organize my labor? This is a vital feature in such games. Even after I build something where I thought I could manage work - I just could cycle colonists through a list without a clou what this is actually doing. Even though it feels rewarding to see one's colony growing, it is a bit too much, that I feel being just a spectator who places object blueprints and then waiting literally hours until stuff is being built. It's fine for that I have no direct control, but I need prioritization at least! It's so frustrating that some stuff is not being built over hours, other objects are built even though my build order came later. Also when building, it just says "building materials needed" - but not how much? So I have this feeling, that something is going wrong with the game's job system. Most of my colonists are walking around, repairing stuff. Sometimes they walk as if being sick - but they are not visiting the medical bay. And so forth. 

So my biggest criticism is, that the game's UI is kind of not good for this type of game. I don't feel like having the control about stuff. The second biggest issue is the job system for me as I have no clue why certain stuff is never built. Thirdly, the game seem to have some serious bugs. 

I have bought when it was heavily discoutned at 6,79 Euro. So I am not complaining. Also I saw, it's obviously one developer with a bunch of supporters rather than a sophisticated game dev studio. I really hope they are getting things straight here. Instead of adding new features like cosmetic stuff, I strongly recommend to get the game right. It's all there, just needs to be balanced right and some UI overhauling. I will then give it another try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006346654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1611487874}
review:
Years after the Kickstarter I remembered this game again. Seems like new features have been added slowly but steadily. The colonists stop by and scratch the base dog's belly! Cute! New ray thingy shadows!

Too bad, that the colonists also die from stupidity since they can't find their way out of an empty room through the door. Or they might get stuck between hydroponics planter boxes. The miner robot also gets into a loop hitting a door frame every fifteen minutes needing FPS control to get in unjinxed again. Everything happens super slowly, with most of the time spent looking at the colonists wandering around, not really doing anything useful.

I kinda hope this game gets "there" eventually, but I guess there's just something fundamentally wrong in the game system for these kind of issues to still exist after more than six years in development.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052667634', 'num_games_owned': 50, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3087, 'last_played': 1611252321}
review:
This is a wonderful hidden gem.  Buy it.

It is enjoyable, challenging, frustrating, and funny (especially in the Dry Humour British way).  You can expect hours of building, telling people what to do, and occasionally having your robots (IMPs) revolt on you.

You can also expect to have some (all) of your colonists die on (sometimes frequent) occasions.  You are attempting to colonize a hostile world, after all - everything will try to kill you!

The scenarios and tutorials are really good, especially to show you the ropes.  You can free flow it too, and do some "Exploration" games; however I don't have much experience with them yet...  "soon" though..

Patience, and maybe some single malt will be your best friend with this game, but if you like a challenge, this is one for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025182989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 985, 'last_played': 1662898346}
review:
Let me start by saying that, as far as I'm concerned, this game is still in Early Access.  
I judge it as late Alpha, maybe early Beta.

You build a colony by satisfying the needs of the colonists. You can't control them directly, but that's OK, because they know what to do to get what they need. What you need to do is manage resources, create the layout, and provide your colony a balanced diet while they get on with the Science.

At least, that what it should be, if your colonists were not neurotic, suicidal toddlers.

Your colonists die of fatigue because they got /stuck/ between a bed and a wall, without actually sleeping in it.
Your colonists die of asphyxiation because they would rather stand resolutely /just outside/ the airlock and die in their spacesuits.
Your colonists die of thirst because somehow the exit to get to the water still got /overgrown/, but the leaf-trimming robots would rather peek inside toilets.
Your colonists die of hypothermia because they'd rather make /potted plants/ than...well, apparently anything.
Your colonists die of broken bones sustained because they don't know how to walk smoothly from place to place.
Your colonists die of, I don't know, loneliness? because they wall off rooms /before/ and /without/ making the doors to get in and out.

Space is dangerous, but blithering stupidity is worse.

The developer(s) should spend less time programming the colonists to get angry when they see red glowsticks (apparently that's a thing in this game), and more time instructing them not to stand idly next to flaming machinery.

review: Well, I'd like to like this, but.. it's got SO many bugs.  I like its humor, but it doesn't make clear how to move forward it's so busy trying to be funny.  I stared at my colony for a good 2 hours waiting for them to PLEASE GD remove the door I asked you to remove hours ago.. PLEASE build the lamp, the research desk, the medical scanner.. meantime, people are dying.  There's minerals, there's building materials, but nobody builds anything. author: {'steamid': '76561198048707492', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1598485319}
review:
I wanted to like this game. I really did. It has the idea and the the graphics to make for a really great game.

Unfortunately the execution is subpar.

The controls are clunky and so is the UI. The game is buggy and glitchy. You won't know if an object isn't being built because the colonists don't care, don't have the materials, or there's some interaction preventing it. The tutorial barely tells you what you need for the basics of survival and it is challenging, not in a fun gameplay sort of way, but in a 'why did the game just close' sort of way.

TLDR Do not recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024463566', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1595892594}
review:
Now I can't say I've played a lot of this game mostly as I have only started playing it today. 

HOWEVER, there are a few things that I feel I need to say as well as ask. I am going to go back through some of the issues I have had in the last two hours of play. 

Firstly the colonists' AI/IA (Artificial intelligence/Intelligent Agents) ; Now I understand us as the 'Overseer' of these projects I can not control the colonists directly. There are a few things I feel are laking and some that I just plain wrong or a bug.
So with the lack of complete control (which I have no issues with as I have played many games like this), the fact there is no prioritising ablity is a surprising and rather irritating issue.
Next, Lava. So I am amazed that these extremely advanced and trained colonists don't understand that when lava is coming towards them to RUN! I lost two colonists, one robot and a chicken due to one drop of lava coming down straight outside the room.

Next, you have the weather. This planet seems to be worse than England for how many different kinds of weather you can get in one day. I had rain, fog, asteroids, solar flares and earthquakes in less than a full day. Now I don't mind too much. Apart from that when an earthquake happens, everyone becomes useless...even when they are right next to a fire. O yes did I forgot to mention that in the issues with the AI? (well no I just thought it worked better here).
Another issue I had was an earthquake that lasted over a day and continued when I started t new game.

Then the tutorial is a bit unpredictable, and when I had to reload as it is not very restriving in events, I had to restart the game and the tutorial. Why? Well, the fact that almost everything became unviewable and my mouse vanished. 

The last thing I am going to mention is that fact that the UI (User Interface) is very chaotic and not very user friendly. Now it's not bad enough that I would have mentioned it usually however with everything else put together it needed to be mentioned.

Now there is a lot of interesting protention to the game; however, I feel it's like it is still in beta, and I would not say it is a finished game just yet. However, it is good to see there are still updates coming out. 

I hope to see these issues ironed out as this looks to like a game I could sink days into playing.
Until then I can't give this game a thumbs up.

review:
Crash continui.
D'accordo sul fatto che colonizzare un pianeta non è cosa facile e si hanno mille difficoltà, ma in questo gioco è tutto portato all'esasperazione, ed intendo tutto, il gameplay è un nemico molto più pericoloso di uno sciame di meteore, terremoti, incendio e attacchi di alieni... tutti insieme!

Gli NPC interrompono il gioco (a te, perché il realtà il tempo del gioco continua) e ad ogni messaggio si oscura lo schermo e devi leggerti le robe FUTILI che hanno da dirti, ultima su tutte "esco fuori. punto." -> dopo 1 minuto npc morto.
Il menù costruzione ti cambia da solo gli oggetti se ti sposti in altre stanze... (MCC??? colorami l'oggetto di rosso per farmi capire che non posso, non cambiarlo con l'oggetto più vicino in lista!).
Come se non bastasse dopo un po' il gioco crasha, sempre, e per farlo ripartire va fatta SEMPRE la verifica dei file di gioco.
Evito di elencare altri difetti perché oggi è Domenica e non la voglio passare totalmente a scrivere cose brutte :)

Peccato perché l'idea mi piace moltissimo, ma il gameplay è un nemico indistruttibile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033570001', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1591993650}
review:
I bought this game when it was in early access. I was excited to see it progress, but the same buggy issues have persisted (and now the game is supposed to be "complete"?).
Room building is incredibly glitchy and, although your astronauts won't 'die' if a wall looks as if it's been breached (because it didn't build) it just looks awful. In emergency situations, the astronauts won't hurry to get anything done. Although they have been programmed to run (and they do this randomly), they don't hurry to build critical infrastructure at times when your whole settlement/base is about to experience a catasrophy (e.g. lack of food, atmosphere, temp etc.). There are fires in the game and there's no rush to put them out.
Most recently (since the game was announced as 'complete'), I have found that the game randomly crashes. Frequently. This last problem has made the game literally unplayable.
MAIA had soooooooo much potential. I was so excited about it. The 'finished product' is frustrating and so disappointing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136495715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 6510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3839, 'last_played': 1684036694}
review:
Be aware the developer marked this game complete somewhere around 2018-2020, however it is still very much a Alpha stage game in development.

I purchased this game when it was new to steam, every few years I reinstall it and check on the progress, I last reviewed this game in 2021. Unfortunately I still cannot recommend this game.  The graphics have been updated a little, but I find no changes to game play despite the updates from the developer. The game still has all the bugs that were in the game on it's first release as an early access game in 2018 including but not limited to:

Colonist starve to death while having food in their inventory. 
Colonists Die from exhaustion because they will not go to sleep on one of the many beds.
Colonist die of thirst with plenty of water available, including water stations in each room.
Colonists get stuck on chairs, tables, ect and die because they can't move.
IMP robots run around breaking stuff faster than repair robots/colonists can fix them.

Now, after you get to about 12 colonists, several colonist does nothing but move from one food prep station  to the next removing all the prepared food, in seconds 6 prep stations with 40K units of food will have none and the colonists will still move from station to station taking food, never eating.

Colonists still randomly walk outside without a space suit, and still walk inside with the space suit.
Equipment placed on walls randomly changed position, sometimes on the wall of a neighboring room, other times just hanging in the middle of a hallway.

The developer is still active, there are still updates being pushed to the game, however, the developer is still treating the game as an Alpha level Early access and not addressing the bugs that have plagued the game from the day it became available on steam.

If you can deal with the bugs or just don't care about them, it's not a bad game to play and can be an interesting challenge. As long as you can keep from running out of colonists you can keep the game going. 

Review from 2021------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I originally Reviewed this game in 2020, At that time, the developer had marked the game complete and said that they would keep working on it as they had time. I saw that they had not stopped working on the game so I reinstalled it and started a game to see what had changed. 

While some things have changed, like you can only have 3 EMP robots (used to be 6) and are limited to 10 colonists (was unlimited), I was surprised to find that the same bugs are still in the game, bugs like, Colonists starve to death with plenty of food, Colonists and Robots spend lots of time doing nothing, Colonists walk outside without a space suit, sometimes they die sometimes they don't, Colonists Still ignore priority setting, Devices catch fire for no reason.

Even though the game is marked full release and while the developer is still updating the game, it is still very much an early access Alpha stage game. many bugs, some dating back to it's original release on steam and there is very little content to the game, I still can not recommend this game in it's current state.

Original Review:
Maia had a lot of potential, however, half way though the Alpha phase of development the developer said the game wasn't making enough money, as a result he has marked the game complete and stopped development. 

The game is decent to play, but there are many bugs and glitches in the game, some of them game breaking.  If you can deal with the bugs, (people just wandering around not doing anything, fires starting for no reason and people/robots not repairing/building things, people starving to death with more than enough food on hand. ect) then the game is actually ok, those bugs just make it very hard to progress.   

I would suggest waiting until it's on sale for like $5.00 if you want it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027528481', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1566146180}
review:
I'm one of the people who supported this on Kickstarter, so I have been waiting a long time for it to be released. So long in fact that I lost interest and forgot about it. I finally got around to trying it since the first alpha version, and I have to say, this one's a disappointment.
It's not even a total disaster like a lot of other Kickstarters, where you could get legitimately angry and claim you've been scammed. There's the core of a good and fun game here.
The simulation tends to go crazy, things break and catch on fire all the time, the UI is frustrating to use, it just feels unfinished. In fact, it pretty much still feels like that first alpha. Would be good with more polish, but after 6 years, I doubt it'll ever get there.

review:
This game is broken. Basic stuff just doesn't work, or is simply missing. Doors display "no description" when moused over. Enemies that die get stuck in a 'looking around' animation forever, rather than actually dying. Restarting a mission doesn't stop the ongoing narration from before the restart. And so forth.

It isn't just bugs, though. It is infuriating to play for design reasons. Your colonists are quick to complain about things, even in the tutorial level, but nowhere does it tell you WHAT you need to do in order to get your colonists to follow your orders. There is no option to say 'build this FIRST' or speed up time. So you end up just sitting there, HOPING your colonists will get their act together and follow the orders you've given them. Even when/if they do get around to following your orders, you usually have no idea if this will actually fix the issue or not. For example, I spent a bunch of time building air vents to try to get air and heat to all my rooms, only to realize that air vents just do not work, and all that effort was wasted.

This is a buggy, broken game. Stay away. Do not buy this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986630470', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1550596680}
review:
A uniquely British take on extrasolar colonisation. Cleverly fuses the earth-hewing and base management of Dungeon Keeper with a hard sci-fi edge and complex simulation.

I had a few UI issues and little bugs here and there when I played in Nov 2019, but the the game is so immersive and atmospheric that it just pulls you in hard. My experience so far is just of the scenario mode - I look forward to playing through the campaign missions in due course. 

It is even more extraordinary when you consider this is mostly the work of a single dev, who has poured his heart and soul into this, even building the engine from scratch! Top bloke who is the epitome of the hard-working indie dev with passion for the industry and the wider world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058409861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2535, 'last_played': 1558889633}
review:
I've been holding off writing this review as I wanted this game to come out of early access and give it a chance for some post-release polish. Unfortunately, for the latter part, I'm still waiting. Like many people I was taken in by the promise of a game that never fulfilled that promise. This review is based on the short amount I've played post release (5 hours) and the rest while in early access.

The game looks great and feels like a modern spin on a 80s game but for me that is as far as the good goes. The UI is clunky and awkward to use. Things that should happen automatically, like building rooms is almost impossible as the AI queuing system is flawed. Crashes are just as frequent now as in early access to the point where I find myself quick-saving every couple of minutes just to be safe - not how I should be playing any game.

Don't attempt to play this game with more than 1 monitor or any monitor above 1080p - my in-game FPS counter shows 60 but the screen actually renders at < 1 FPS.

I think the core failure here was to build a custom game engine: "MAIA USES A CUSTOM BUILT ENGINE ALLOWING AAA QUALITY GRAPHICS WITHOUT REQUIRING HIGH SYSTEM SPECS". That line is quoted from their website but I wouldn't consider the graphics AAA quality and I'm certainly not getting good performance with my 'high system spec' machine. It wouldn't be too difficult to put together a similar game with Unity in a much shorter time frame (Planetbase?).

All in all I could never recommend this game and quite frankly I wish I could get my money back.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986130354', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1558243019}
review:
At this time I wouldn't recommend this game at this time. There are a few to many issues in this iteration of the game. Notable things.
1.	Your colonists will starve, die of dehydration, or die of exhaustion even if those needs are met, and also aren't blocked. 20 beds for 5 people, 20 ration packs, 10 barrels of water? They’d rather not sleep, or eat, or drink.
2.	While you can mark constructing certain things a priority it is often things that you desperately need completed that you can’t mark as a priority. Even when you do mark things as a priority your colonists can sometimes take their sweet time getting there to do it while they finish some other minute tasks beforehand. Hurts when its time critical.
3.	Building anything is horribly inconsistent. Sometimes you place it in the middle of a room and no colonist can find a path to it or nobody is ever assigned to build it. If it does get built then sometimes everyone ignores its existence or suddenly can’t path around it, to the other things in the room, or to it to use it. Special mentions for being unbuildable goes to IVs.
4.	Your colonists don’t give enough feedback. Things can be looking swell then suddenly they’re committing suicide. Supposedly they have moods but in the time I’ve been playing they’ve gone from happily running around to walking out an airlock within seconds. Note. This is different from 5 as apparently suicide is sudden and they don’t go to the med center first.
5.	Medical issues. If a colonist breaks a bone that’s the best option as it’s over. Every other nonfatal fatal issue will never go away and you’ll never stop hearing about how so-and-so has high blood pressure or depression even when you try to brighten up everywhere in your base, with the proper colors, or have cows/chickens on all your copious wall screens.
6.	Lights in general. Most rooms seem to come in dim and gloomy and every light you can install has a range of 3 feet from it. The most inefficient bulbs in space were used.
7.	Heat. Getting warm is easy. Cooling off is nearly impossible. The only option to cool off the room involves emptying the room of its atmosphere. The fans that empty the room of its atmosphere seem to work faster than the atmosphere generator replenishes it. This would be an issue if we were actually in space and not on a planet where we could just dump excess heat outside.
8.	Doors. Sometimes they just stop building it. You get a doorway, with no actual door, with a “Door in construction” message but nobody comes back.

Some entertaining, to me at least, stories.
1.	I accidently made a couch of doom once. The colonists could get into range to sit but once they tried standing up a chair, part of a table, a few feet away broke their pathing so they just stood there until they starved to death. I had 3 bodies that the bots couldn’t get to before I found the issue was the table.
2.	The Farm segment is actually dangerous because of too many chickens. Can’t kill them, apparently you don’t eat them, and my chickens reproduced like mad. Chickens also produce a fair amount of heat so they quickly overheat the room they’re in, one of them bursts into flames, runs around putting all the other chickens on fire, and then there is a die off. My chickens go from 40+ to 3 and my base starts cooling off but the chickens start breeding again.

Do note: I say I don’t recommend AT THIS TIME. Once it gets fleshed out more and some of the more obvious issues get resolved this could very easily be a great game. Even with the bugs I had had fun but if everything goes well you rather quickly get to a point of there is nothing to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972710048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1556364001}
review:
Nice idea, but functionally unplayable. Broken tutorial that throws random, unexplained events at you, often doesn't register progress and doesn't teach you most of what you need to know. Colonists ignore orders, often do nothing at all, and aren't even interested in basic self-preservation - it's not a matter of them having personality or being awkward, they just aren't even basically functional. 

As a player you're left with no idea why anything is happening - or more to the point, not happening. Do you need to do something, or is it just a matter of waiting for your useless colonists to actually complete your orders? Why is the power out again? Why are the colonists scrapping essential items? Is this a bug, or intended crazy behaviour? From the state of the game, probably a bit of both.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090709201', 'num_games_owned': 386, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1552711223}
review:
I have had the absolute joy of watching [i]Maia[/i] evolve over the course of more than 5 years. I first found it while doing a Google search for god games, and I signed up for the mailing list. I was incredibly excited when I received an email announcing that the game was finally in Early Access on Steam in December 2013. Unfortunately, I had a sub-par laptop at the time, and the game was not well-optimized, so I had to wait a few more months until I could play it. Once I was able to load the game successfully, I found a brutal challenge with absolutely no tutorials and confusing controls, and all my colonists died repeatedly because I had no clue what I was doing. But I just thought to myself, "[i]Maia[/i] is still in Early Access; it'll shape up into a playable game in the long run."

Only a couple weeks shy of the five-year mark, [i]Maia[/i] finally left Early Access, and I've just played it for the first time since the release. Last time I played was about a year ago, and by then, the game was certainly playable and made sense. But since its official launch—hehe, launch—it's been given quite a lovely partial makeover by its sole developer, Simon Roth. The interface is refined—just don't expect it to tell you nearly everything you need to know, though, because this game hates you, and that's the idea. The keyboard controls are pretty natural once you figure them out—you can map them yourself if you don't like them, however—but this is a game that absolutely requires a mouse, and you'll probably start out using that for most things. The game does a very, very good job of driving home its status as a god game, giving you only indirect control over most characters, though you can directly control some robots and a couple other machines. The new tutorial is exactly what the game has been missing for five years, and it will set you properly on your way to managing a functioning colony, albeit while being snarky and condescending.

So all in all, I would say that [i]Maia[/i] has turned out pretty great! However, this is not a casual game; it's still brutally difficult, and the first few days of your campaign are crucial to your colony's survival. And do not get too attached to any of your colonists. Unfortunately, the game still feels a little rough around the edges, although nowhere nearly as much as it did even just a year ago. There's also only four save slots (plus another two that are reserved for auto-save and quick-save, respectively) for some reason, and they are shared across all your campaigns: scenarios and sandbox alike. The scarcity of save slots is probably the biggest drawback for me. It's also kind of pricey. Obviously, Simon put heaps of work into this and deserves [i]all of the pounds[/i] for what he has created here, but similar games like [i]Banished[/i] that also feel a bit more polished overall and sport a more diverse set of features do tend to run slightly cheaper. I snagged the game at 25% off for its Early Access launch promotion, and I think that would be a more reasonable price. (Yeah, it's like a US$6 difference, but I'm about to be drowning in student debt, so $6 is a fortune for me!)

In summary, [i]Maia[/i] sets a new gold standard for god games in the post-Molyneux era. It's gritty in its presentation, brutal in its pursuit of realism, and fun in its honest simulation (that is speckled with bleak humor) of a new space colony beyond the stars. Sure, it could use some improvement—and thankfully (and admirably), Simon has promised continued updates past launch, including the addition of new features—and may be on the pricey side for the somewhat narrow range of existing features and modes, but as the baby of one person developing it all on his own, including some rather impressive AI, [i]Maia[/i] is definitely worth adding to your wishlist.

Why do devs make a game that is only appealing to them when the masses tell them it needs to change. Listen to the public and quit being stubborn. You cant make any money selling the game to only yourself.

Save yourself some money and find something else so I don't have to tell you " I TOLD YOU SO"

Colonists love to idle constantly, there's no time acceleration, the keybindings apparently were made by an insane person that's never played video games before (Q and E cycle the item you want to build, instead of rotating the map like every other game), the tutorials break at the slightest wrong touch, and they teach you next to nothing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018169754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1547054443}
review:
Another one of the early early-access games that came to be nothing.

Maia is a nice concept and has nice poetic humour scattered around, but that will be hidden underneath the infinite pathfinding bugs, the lack of any priority system for building, and the fact that you can literally go away for 45 minutes and 10 colonists will never find the time to build a single bed or scanner in the medbay, and then they moan about needing repair drones, before proceeding to refuse to build any repair drones for you.

The game is marred by bugs that effectively softlock the game inside 10-15 minutes every playthrough. Another Early Access title that secretly is never going to leave Early Access, no matter whether or not it says it launched.

review:
I wish i could give this game a good review but after several years i am just gonna give up
The User Interface is STILL, after several years, absolutely abysmal.
Excusing a lack of features is possible, but if most features are just an absolute pain in the ass to even get to, then what is the point?
This game has tons of potential but sadly it is just a chore to play.

This is what happens when you develop your own engine and exactly why most studios don't.
You end up working more on the engine, rather than the game.

A small, experienced team could probably make this game in UE4 within 6 months.

review:
I really want to like this game, but this is probably the least playable version of it so far.  It's nowhere near ready for release.

Every crop batch dies due to some pathogen because no matter whether you have 1 plot or 10 they never harvest it before it rots.  Having twice as many repair robots as colonists still isn't enough to keep up with all the equipment breaking.  Colonists die standing up in front of machines and then the machine doesn't accept any more work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083988215', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 830, 'last_played': 1545858382}
review:
I played the explore mode for most of a day, and as it didnt have any objectives, it was not very exciting, but I got a good sense of the mechanics. 

Then today, I spent most of the day trying to play episode 1. I had powered through it yesterday so quickly, that I didnt even remember. Today, however, I could not complete it. Even though I tried for six hours. This thing is not supposed to take much more than an hour, I think. What happened what after a while, my colonists would stop working. Some would die of thirst next to full drinking fountains. They would not build things like medical facilities even though they was ample building materials, clear paths, and multiple tries and resets on my part. 

Some would die of fatigue while the beds lay empty. Even though earler the beds had been used. Why did they stop using the beds?

Its a great concept. The developer should raise some money and get some help.

review:
I recommend this game, but only if you are willing to sink some learning time into it. It took me three times to complete the tutorial. But first I printed out all the controls... there are many. Having successfully completed the tutorial, I am now prepared to really tackle all the complexities developer Simon Roth has injected into this very complicated simulator.

Yes, there are bugs. Yes, some of the commands appear to be obtuse/confusing. But I have faith Roth will continue to refine his game. 

So... don't go into this without some fortitude. Keep plugging and you will reveal a vast, technical product that will only keep getting better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015394947', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1544417317}
review:
Despite all the things going wrong, I was oddly relaxed while playing.

Space colony building on a hostile world, while challenging, has so far been fun. At it's core, a great game for fans of these sorts of city-building survivial games.

Being a single dev indy release, there are a rash minor usability issues and a bunch of odd behaviors (bugs?) in this 0.69(1.0?) release that I expect to see smoothed out over time, but the core seems well done and I expect to spend many more hours playing this as it matures.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006529809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1543962357}
review:
Maia is a poster child of 'style over substance', a colony sim game where basic information is hidden away from the player behind cheeky poetry and a ghastly UI. Between chunky performance and stability issues you'll also wrestle with overly suicidal AI and scripting issues may or may not render the tutorial moot. If you must sate your sci-fi colony sim appetite, whet it upon RimWorld or Oxygen Not Included; not this hot mess that was released early just so the developer could say that 0.69 was the final beta version.

It hurts me to write a negative review for a game in my favorite genre that I've waited so many years to see to completion. I wish Maia could have gone down in history like FTL for being one of the first big Kickstarter video game success stories. I'd say maybe it needed more time but it's been six years now and I fear that Maia is, indeed, untenable for human interaction.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022275842', 'num_games_owned': 3246, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1543916007}
review:
Although concept idea is amazing, execution is plain awful:
[list][*] Colonists job execution is lagging and full of bugs: you never know why certain job is not executed or just plainly ignored.
[*] Colonists job execution priorities are absolutely awful, the order you've added you jobs is plainly ignored. You never know in what order all jobs will be executed.
[*] Colonists job execution tips do not exist. You never know if you have resources to build something or if you need something else to remove structural wreckage. You never know why the door you've ordered for removal is not removed for the last 3 hours of gameplay.
[*] Repair bots. They seem to forget that they are repair bots. And do proper maintenance only when there is 3 repair bots per 1 colonist.
[*] Firefighting bots. They never patrol base. They always stack together in pack and get in the way of placing new objects. They always at the opposite side of the base to where fire started. And in 97.3% cases they arrive when everything already burned to crisp.[/list]

As of right now, even after the release, Maia is a far cry from being a survival colony building simulator. And only managed to live up to the name of frustration simulator. 

I haven't encountered such buggy execution of jobs and messing up of execution order even in initial early access releases of Rim World, Oxygen Not Included, Rise to Ruin and Planetbase.

review:
Maia is fantastic. This game is clearly a labour of love. It has been a long process, but one i am happy to have followed from day 1 (including those "going to barbados" jokes made during the kickstarter stream) to now. 

Still gutted i missed the launch party :( 

But if you guys like a hardcore simulation game, a sci-fi dingeon keeper that will brutally punish you for letting chickens walk under a sparking door, a game that really gives that "one more minute" feels until its 3AM, then MAIA is the game for you.

Remember, dont panic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002079304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1543276930}
review:
Preface: If you are not into base building games and have problems with "FUN" (= colonists dying. A lot..) - this is not for you! 
However, if you have enjoyed dwarf fortress (but felt incompatible with the "ui", as I did) and similar: GET THIS!
If you are a fan of complex simulations with - at times - ridiculous consequences, well.. you know.

Having been here since 0.3 it's nice to see how this has turned out. 
Especially colonists and your handling of them has strongly improved with neat upgrades to the mailing system. If there is something wrong with your base (or the minds of your colonists) they will write angry mails about it. Vice versa if you are doing fine.
Oh, did I mention about 20hours of Missions (with voiceover) if you feel overwhelmed by the prospect of diving headfirst into "sandbox"?

I can just recommend trying it out - however, a glance at the wiki is recommended if you like to learn from others mistake instead of hav-OH GOD LAVA!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009800914', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1391467557}
review:
You won't find anything related to the game in this review. Maia was the first project I ever backed on Kickstarter back in 2013 - a mere £10 paid for alpha access and, by extension, the full release these five years later.

It's been a long time since then. In that time I've backed many, many other projects on that site. Some I've backed, and received a full, satisfying product on time and on point. Some I've backed, and despite a long delay have exceeded all expectations. And there have been others I've backed, and watched as the updates became less and less frequent, until the project - and my money - faded into the ether, to join the other failed projects in the silent Kickstarter graveland of wind and ghosts.

This game is different to all of these. The good ship Maia has essentially had one guy at the helm, Mr Simon Roth, for the duration of its long, misty voyage. His game idea didn't generate an insane amount of funds on the crowdfunding site (at least relative to recent successes), but it would have been enough to get this kid a decent terraced house somewhere outside of London if he'd decided to cut and run. And believe me, over the next few years as I occasionally found my cash sucked into a few bum steers on Kickstarter (That Which Sleeps, After Reset, and The Mandate, if you're interested), there were times when I felt certain that Maia would be the fourth bum steer, the fourth project to lay with the wind and the ghosts.

But it didn't. Every time I convinced myself it was over, out came another update, small in scope, yet titanic in meaning, as far as I was concerned. I mean damn the thing was shuffling along slower than a Hammock ballad, but it DIDN'T STOP SHUFFLING.

Then Simon advertised a link to his latest blog about two years ago now. https://blog.maiagame.com/how_to_delay_your_indiegame/

Having literally nothing else to do or look at on the internet at that exact moment, I clicked on it. I read the whole thing, and I understood that this nerdy Oxford kid, this kid I had thrown £10 at in the heady honeymoon era of Kickstarter, was in pain. That pain of RESPONSIBILITY. Responsibility that, if deleted, would not delete the pain, and ergo a responsibility that MUST be fulfilled. And I knew then. I fucking knew then. This kid wasn't giving up. This ship was staying the course.

And so here I am, too. Though he didn't do it personally, today Simon asked us - he asked ME -  to leave a review on Steam. So here I am, five years later, with more swathes of grey hairs, a bigger gut and shorter breath. But I'm not giving up, because I've got responsibilities too. 

Simon dude, if you ever read this - you did it. Good man.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052446265', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1543079737}
review:
Seeing this game finally launch, I was very excited to try it again, as it always had potential but was held back by an extreme amount of bugs and generally sluggish game design.

Unfortunately, it seems not much has changed. 

[list]
    [*]Everything happens at a snail's pace and there is no user feedback whether a command has been accepted by a colonist/robot, which would be fine, except if something doesn't get built/done, it leaves you wondering why?

    [*]Pathfinding is... painful. Units run, then walk, then run and in the end they take forever to get where they need to be - if they even get there at all.

    [*]Strange bugs. I started a new game and immediately my robot started digging out dirt without me having selected anything, completely breaking the bulkhead system.

    [*]The popups... more trouble than they are worth unfortunately. It doesn't help to get updates about the electricity situation, I need to be able to see supply/demand at a specific point in time, for instance, before I start building a new room.

    [*]Even worse is the colonist requests which simply pop up like an internet ad and steals your input while interrupting whatever you were doing at the time.

    [*]Finally, the price. It's way too high for a game so plagued by the issues I've mentioned above. 
[/list]

All this being said, I'll keep an eye on development and update things here if anything changes.

review:
The inspirations for this game are both obvious and subtle, influencing how it looks, feels and plays, or rather how you think you should be playing it.

It swings from a low pace base builder with an enormously detailed simulation behind every little thing you see and can interact with to a frantic struggle for survival as the dangers of Maia strike the unprepared mercilessly. Prepare to be unprepared and learn by failing.

If you prefer to learn from the mistakes of others - or perhaps boast about your most successful survival or expansion tips and strategies, visit [url=https://wiki.maiagame.com] the official wiki[/url] and help it grow.

Much like the games it draws inspiration from you do not control your colonists directly but act more as an overseer and planner for what they should do. You decide where rooms go, what goes into them, and where to get resources from - in the form of placing digging orders. Colonists make their own priorities based on their current needs and leave feedback in form of personal emails and  expressing their most immediate needs through body language. Colonists arrive to Maia in pods which can be called down from orbit at certain intervals. Then they need to get into your base quite quickly as the atmosphere is toxic and you don't can't be outside without a suite - unlike the native flora and fauna which aren't always so happy to see new arrivals. 

There's a story driven campaing with missions letting you learn about colonist needs and how to satisfy them, told through radio conversations  with the orbital command and related managment functions. They've put you in charge of setting up several bases to accomplish tasks like establishing research facilities to learn more about the planet and technologies needed to survive there.

The overall style is very sci-fi-from-the-80's, despite being set in the distant future, people have realized colonising harsh environments require tried and trustworthy tech, with some robotics and AI applied here and there to help out where it's too dangerous (or inconvenient) to have humans spend their precious time, sweat and blood. AI isn't trusted with weaponry though, a few stationary turrets and handguns do just fine and won't uninionize on you to start making their own demands.

The humor, both explicit in voiceover/text and implicit in visual style, is [i]very[/i] British, but suits the style very well and I've become quite fond of it after spending many hours trying to expand bases in a timely fashion - yes, pacing yourself is key, even during panics. Overwhealming your colonists with tasks is most likely going to be your first mistake, and thus also your last in that scenario. Maia - as in both the planet and the game - forgives some mistakes, but only up to a certain point.

I have not played many other games which are quite like this. Dwarf Fortress is probably the closest one in terms of finding out what to do, when to do it, why you should do it, and how to understand what's actually going on. The amount of input and feedback can be both overwhealming (you'll be dismissing a lot of emails) and frustratingly sparse (try following your colonists and robots around to see what they're actually doing and pay attention to your storage levels!)

I've been with this game since the Kickstarter and I think Simon - the single developer now working full time on Maia - has delivered very well and met all my expectations. There have been delays of course, but taking on a game like this is a massive task and easy to underestimate. Simon has done - and keeps doing - a fantastic job of engaging with the community and acting (sometimes within minutes!) on the feedback provided. He's got a clear vision and communicates it well.

It's a fantastic game for the audience it's aimed at and my only hope for it is to keep going in the same direction. Special thanks to Simon for staying strong and keeping Linux gamers in mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024027944', 'num_games_owned': 151, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1222, 'last_played': 1545149450}
review:
*Nominated for the Steam Awards: 'Labour of Love' category*

I really like this game. If you're in to builders, exoplanets, and/or British humour, buy this game. It was an early access purchase for me and I'm glad - it's been a wonderful experience to see the game improve and grow in advance of its full release. I highly recommend the tutorial, and treating it akin to a roguelike - while you uncover the systems and get your base up, you will fail multiple times (at least I did!). The gameplay for me is a bit like Banished *IN SPAAAAAACE* but with a soul that Banished didn't have. Despite being a deeply simulated and hard SF game, the developer is able to inject humour and pathos for the dwellers of the colony under your control.

The graphics for the game are good for what the game needs to do, and I appreciate that. This game is about the systems and the metanarrative you ascribe to your colony. The sound design is the outstanding technical aspect to me, in addition to what's under the hood. The sound really 'sells' the environment to me, which I enjoy very much. Frankly, for the enjoyment I've gotten out of Maia it is a bargain at twice the price, so support indie developers and buy it at full price if you are able, or a sale if you are not, but please do buy this game. It's a good one!

author: {'steamid': '76561197973630764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1249, 'last_played': 1538513364}
review:
This game seemed to have so much potential, but it's just dull and buggy.

The AI pathing is awful. I had two living areas with food and water and still about a quater of my colonists would begin dying off becuase they wouldn't eat, drink or sleep, (yep, when they are too tired, they just drop dead.) If they do remember to eat and sleep, sometimes they get so depressed they just walk outside and commit suicide. (And honestly I know how they feel)

I like a challenge when building but I had to do about 8 restarts before I even got to stop dying off in droves or bugs would force a complete restart.

That aside, there's nothing to do. Don't get me wrong I love slow dull games where you can casually sit back and watch your base expand, but this......urgh. You colonists just stroll around at a frustrating plod, not really doing anything. 

Pffft. Awful.
developer_response:
One of the requirements of the colonists quitting a base is having no food. You might want to check that you are actually producing any in your food prep stations. A single meal is requires several thousand kJ. Click on your hydroponic planters to speed up their growth and ensure there is enough light on the plants.

Fatigue has also been reduced since you last played. So you may find that aspect less difficult now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962382305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1539714759}
review:
So...I recommend this game, because I really dig how much little detail went into it, the artstyle is great and it reminds me of the games of my childhood. Yet, there is a lot of stuff that really needs to be worked out.
First thing is the cursor: It looks great, but its hitbox is hard to guess and just doesn't feel right. I can hover the tip of the index finger about half way from the top over a main menu item, or key binding, whatever, and it doesn't light up. 
The tutorial: I love the sassyness and it gets all the stuff you need to know across. Problem is that sometimes stuff just doesn't happen. Colonist don't start on a crucial part, like the Wind Mill. You're supposed to move an atmosphere generator, like 2 minutes after you've built it, and while doing so, it just catches on fire. And noone cares. The colonist just keeps moving the thing while it's burning. All while the mouse-over says its in excellent condition?

I really want to play more of this game, but since I haven't that much spare time right now and the tutorial sort of glitched out on me twice, I will leave it alone for now, but I'll definitely be giving it a more in-depth spin when it releases.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012295528', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1094, 'last_played': 1538925480}
review:
Maia est un simulateur dans lequel vous gérez une colonie implantée sur une planète éponyme.

Il s'agit d'un jeu assez difficile, mais très satisfaisant. Plein d'humour et de références, notamment à H2G2. Il est facile et relaxant de le lancer et faire une "courte" session de jeu de temps en temps. Un guide vidéo provisoire a été publié [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/252250/discussions/0/1692669912403602379/]ici[/url].
Le jeu est actuellement en fin d'accès anticipé, mais le développeur a indiqué qu'il souhaitait poursuivre des mises à jours régulières. Quoi qu'il en soit, celui-ci est déjà très prenant, je ne regrette absolument pas mon achat !

Le développeur est très actif sur Discord et les forums, et les problèmes sont corrigés rapidement. Le jeu dispose aussi d'une bêta mise à jour quotidiennement. Une liste des mises à jour peut d'ailleurs être trouvée ici: https://dev.maiagame.com/

Ce qui distingue Maia des autres jeux est que les colons ne sont pas contrôlés directement. Ceux-ci ont des besoins et une volonté propre. Il ne faut pas les surcharger d'ordres de constructions, sinon ceux-ci risquent de tomber de fatigue. Ceux-ci sont libres de former des liens sociaux entre eux, leurs compétences s'améliorent avec la pratique. Il vous feront part de tout cela par e-mail, ainsi que de ce qu'ils pensent de la base, de leurs besoins, etc (pas toujours de manière explicite, cependant).

De plus, le jeu est vraiment une simulation complète, la plupart des mécanismes étant simulés de manière assez plausible : par exemple, la température du corps est calculée en fonction de l'émissivité radiative de celui-ci, de la quantité d'énergie dépensée pour l'activité, des coefficients d'absorption et de réflexion du vêtement porté, ainsi que de la température de la salle (convection et émission radiative). Et chacune des compétences, aussi loufoque soit-elle, a un impact sur le jeu.
Il s'agit véritablement d'un jeu de "SF dure", où les technologies sont plausibles, et dans le futur proche.

Le jeu a énormément de potentiel, même si celui-ci affiche de nombreux problèmes en l'état, et s'avère difficile à prendre en main. Je n'ai cependant aucun doute que les futures mises à jour amélioreront la plupart de ces points, et je le recommande, même dans son état actuel, si vous êtes intéressés après avoir lu cela.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966602256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1079, 'last_played': 1588705451}
review:
This game is a little gem for colony/base builders (and mayhap even SIM players). There is so much going on and it takes some time to get all the details even at it’s slow pace. Sadly not much is explained in-game [yet?]. Figured most stuff out by playing or watching others play. I still absolutely recommend this. It’s very relaxing and hilarious fun at times when an unfortunate chain of events culminate in an unexpected disaster :D

This game always had a very steady progress, unlike other EA games, and it was fun keeping an eye on it and watch the improvements over time. Remember that this is an Indie and not a huge studio. I’m a dev myself and I tell you it’s amazing what S. Roth managed to achieve here. He could also be reached e.g. via Discord or Twitter so I’ve absolutely no idea why some people here complain that they were ignored. Mayhap they were simply rude?

Don’t give the bad reviews here too much credit. The annoying repeating crashes e.g. that many players describe did only happen in fact for Windows players due to a bug with async operations in a library from Microsoft. That was not related to the game itself, and is fixed by now. This game didn’t crash for me in hours on Linux so I believe this statement by the dev. And to this dude blaming this killed his hard-disk or boot-loader or whatsoever: Just no. This is not how computers work o0

Originally posted at: [url=https://beko.famkos.net/2018/09/28/maia/]https://beko.famkos.net/2018/09/28/maia/[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198031004364', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1449, 'last_played': 1537472009}
review:
Maia's a fun colony manager with a good sense of humour and a degree of challenge. It's not a casual game, and you'll have to spend quite some time thinking about the order and arrangement of what you build to optimise your base and prevent unnecessary bottlenecks and/or death. It has a deep level of simulation when it comes to things like temperature and atmospheric systems, as well as colonist psychology and behaviours, which isn't made immediately apparent to the player with hard numbers. Instead, you have to use the information provided to you be the colonists' reports and in-game objects (such as info screens) a lot more than you use many parts of the UI.

As a game that's been in early access for a long while, most of the negative reviews revolve around bugs which were long fixed, features which have long since been implemented, and a general level of polish and completeness that didn't exist years ago but does now. Complaints like the lack of tutorial are entirely invalid, for example; it has one.
Simon's a wonderful dev who'll identify and begin to fix problems you find in the game very rapidly, and quite often the more amusing emergent "features" become features indeed.

For the price, it's well worth it, especially considering it's done nothing but grow and improve over time.
Support your indie devs!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025247656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1537526892}
review:
Maia is clearly a labour of love from its developer Simon Roth¸ and it shows in the attention to detail, witty humour and overall richness of the world offered to your reckless command to build on while trying to keep your colonists alive.

I've played the game on Linux and it runs great so far, and I enjoy it a lot. Among the current "Mixed" review status you'll see lot of reports of breaking bugs, which did exist, but Simon is doing a great job to fix them with regular releases (~every 3 months). You can get access to bug fixes faster by playing the "development" branch, and take part in shaping the game by discussing with the dev and other users on their Discord channel (I reported a few bugs there, got fixed within hours in the dev branch).

So keep in mind that this game is still Early Access, but if you're willing to play an already fun game and maybe also take part in shaping a great project, I definitely recommend Maia.

review:
This is one of my favourite colony mangement games which rewards good design and punishes sloppiness.  The colonists seem intent on killing themselves in every way possible so careful thought about how to place items and the layout of the base is the difference between a happy productive paradise or a nightmare of alarms, people dropping like flies and fires everywhere.

While the game has been in early access for a while the developer is constantly working on it and is an active part of the community, easilly accessable and willing to hear feedback and suggestions on improvements.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993699776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 2592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1540, 'last_played': 1682840217}
review:
Okay, so you know how Banished can be tough? Now imagine that but on another planet. 

Both games are stunning in their visuals in their own ways, as would be expected given the different settings. Maia goes to extra lengths to really draw one into this sort of Low Maia Orbit view where you monitor your colonists' behavior & changing moods/attitudes, guide their mining and base construction, and try to make sure they don't rapidly starve, dehydrate, and die of exhaustion. 

In short, it's a base building & management sim, with many of the quirks you'd expect of that if you've played other games of the sort. 

Where Maia really shines though is in capturing the hard scifi aesthetic. Maia is an extremely tumultuous world, prone to earthquakes and hurricanes; while also being in an active star system, with its local star flaring up from time to time creating electromagnetic interference that generates blackouts and the occasional meteorite shower that can smash surface constructions yet also provide some useful research material. 

Oh, and both earthquakes and meteor showers can lead to cave-ins as you carve out your base, so you gotta watch out for those even more than you otherwise might...Alongside stumbling into the occasional vein of lava that can swallow up IMPs (mining robots) & colonists if you're not careful.

It's challenging, but if you can work your way through all that, you get to see a cool little base come together and see colonists eke out their new lives on another planet. Plus, you get some amusing stories about remote controlling repair bots to fix stuff and accidentally setting livestock on fire because they just happened to pass too close to your welding arm, IMPs going stir crazy from not being issued many orders lately, & sabotaging things, and then of course sometimes simply forgetting to throw together some repair & cleaning bots leading to things catching fire or acting up.

Perhaps most importantly to some folks though...It has raptors that barge into your base, alongside some other curious wildlife. So really, what other space basebuilding games are out there that let you have temperamental robots to deal with [i]and[/i] hostile raptors, while also letting you zap chickens aflame if ya get a little frustrated?

author: {'steamid': '76561197967609494', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3056, 'last_played': 1554766952}
review:
I like this game as a "Sims in Space but Grim and Deadly", I really do, but I just cannot recommend it in it's current form.  
Yes, it is in early access, however, after firing it up on a whim after 10 months, the game has not moved forward appreciably and the crashes-to-desktop have become much, much worse.  About every 20 minutes.
I have gone on the discussion page to read the pinned posts about crashes.
I have updated my drivers.
I have retarted.
I have checked file integrity.
I have toggled the beta trackon and off.
I have tried lower settings.

If you were playing PC games around 1998, you know this experience.  The difference now is that I have no sunk cost in this.  (Well, very minimal)  I don't have to go under the hood of my pc to make this work when I have a list of other games one click away.  
I really hope this game works out, and if you think you will like it I would urge you to give it a chance when-honestly, if?-it leaves early access and can deliver a hassle-free experience.  There is a whole lot of good stuff here.
developer_response: The crashes were caused by a bad library (shipped by Microsoft). The game should be decently stable. We now have a dedicated Discord where I can provide support immediately for any issue. https://discord.gg/3zn3n6h

author: {'steamid': '76561198074001782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 4323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3146, 'last_played': 1675650805}
review:
I have given this game many chances, but now I am tapping out. I have emailed the creator with log files, issues, bugs; posted in the forums and never once have i received a reply. The game has been in Early Access for years, and I doubt it will ever leave. If it does, it will still be broken.

My honest opinion, is the game is alright, for awhile... The game goes great for a few hours of building and playing, but then the characters start freezing, pathing failures, build queue failures, etc. etc....

Like I said, I've sent my log files to the creator, even put delivery reciepts on the last few, and not response. He claims to want people to point out issues so he can fix them, yet I've only seen him respond to easy fix things in the forums or people that have little play time. I have over 50 hours in this game, you would think my testing is a bit more relevant than some one with 2 hours. 

If the issues ever get fixed, the game will be a great survival/colony builder, but in it's current state; I just get a headache after wasting hours building up and then the failures start.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008048609', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 727, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1653051906}
review:
Now it has been updated and it's actually fun :)

Original review below, tho.

------

It freezes. Not so often, but in a strategically manner - usually when the colony is eventually somewhat auto-sustainable.
Often these freezes follows the delivery of a new notification. Wildlife herding e-mail notification -> freeze. Colonist haiku e-mail -> freeze. And so on.
In addition, colonists are almost always stupid. AI, for instance, cannot even figure out how to extinguish a wild fire in Workshop, providing plenty supplies of water.
And if you lost your only IMP prior to build the 3D printer, because it mined a Lava source while expanding buildable area of your base, you've lost the game.
I know, most of the issues that I'm having can be filed under some Bugtracker platform or something like that and fixed.
I know, give this game some more time to develop, and it can be awesome.
I know, we're talking about (yet another) Early Access title. That has got potential. You know, a Ferrari chassis has the potential to become a badass Ferrari. But with a poor engine, tires, electronics and so on, we can have a Laika resembling a Ferrari, which is definitely *not* what I'm wet dreaming about.
I think that even on sale it's a bit overpriced, taking also in account that this game need more fans and sponsors to grow, so the more people you reach, the more visibility you gain, the more future buyers you can expect to harvest. Yes, 10 € on sale doesn't seems much - 5 € here, 7 € there, 10 € up, 15 € down... sum that money to the taxes... and you must eat, don't you? And so that "only 10 €" obtain a more heavy meaning when talking about household economy.

To sum it up, this game is an EA, of course, and it's got potential (that phrase must be some sort of Steam meme) to become Great Again, but for me, and for now, it's a no-go. I'm going to apply for a refund and I shall buy it again, even at full price if it's worthy, when some more of that famous "potential" is concretized.
