author: {'steamid': '76561197971935758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1136, 'last_played': 1515246801}
review:
Ich habe dem Spiel nun mehrere Jahre Zeit gegeben aber es sind immer noch die Basics die es quasi unspielbar machen und wirklich neue Features sind an einer Hand abzuzählen.

Negativ:
- Die GUI ist grauenhaft .. wirklich grauenhaft..
- Die KI der Siedler ist katastrophal. 99.9 % aller Tode wären vermeidbar, wenn Deine Siedler einfach mal was sinnvolles tun würden aber nein obwohl Du Tonnen an Nahrung hast kommen sie nicht auf die Idee mal was zu essen oder das Gegenteil sie umarmen sich lieber und stehen dumm in der Gegend rum anstatt mal die Pflanzen zu ernten oder zu verarbeiten.
- Sagte ich schon die GUI ist grauenhaft ? 
- Sinnvolle neue Ding/Features brauchen ewig um ins Spiel zu kommen, im Moment wird gerade mal ein bisschen hübsch gemacht.
- Gerade für neue Spieler sind die ersten Spielstarts extrem frustrierend, die Startressourcen sind viel zu knapp .. man muss ziemlich genau wissen was man tut sonst hat man schnell keine Nahrung mehr und es heißt game over.
- Man kann nur sehr indirekt Befehle an die Siedler geben.. erkennt man das es beispielsweise einen Engpass gibt weil sich die Siedler um gewisse Dinge einfach nicht kümmern kann man nur wenig machen um den Siedlern einen Klaps zu geben. Meist bleibt einem nicht viel übrig als alles andere ab zu schalten damit mal jemand langsam in Richtung Problemzone geht, häufig hilft das aber auch nicht und die Siedler stehen wieder nur dum rum oder laufen hin und her anstatt wichtige Ressourcen zu bauen/einzusammeln. Beim Raumbau/Möbelbau kann man Dinge mit hoher Prio versehen, was aber nur begrenzt hilft.
- Feedback der Siedler bekommt man durch eine Art SMS .. diese nett gemeinten IC Nachrichten, sollen wohl RP-Feeling aufkommen lassen, gehen einen nach kurzen aber unglaublich auch den Sack und man klickt sie einfach nur noch weg, gerne mal eine wichtige dabei ignorierend.

Positiv:
- Nette Idee.. viel Potential
- Der Entwickler ist aktiv im Forum .. und versucht zu helfen. (Zumindest hat er es bis vor ca. 1 Jahr.)
- Sci-Fi
- ääähh viel Potential ?

…

btw.. ich hatte einige nette Gespräche via Forum mit dem Entwickler und alle meine Anmerkungen sind vom Entwickler immer vernünftig kommentiert worden… aber trotzdem glaube ich einfach, das er sich total übernommen hat. Alle meine aufgezeigten Probleme sind immer noch mehr oder weniger im Spiel. Das Problem mit der KI bekommt er trotz endlosem herumgewerkeln einfach nicht in den Griff.. und das killt wirklich jeglichen Spielspaß.

Ich möchte nichts böses unterstellen, aber schaue ich mir die letzten Erweiterungen/Patches an glaube ich das Spiel ist im Zombiepflegezustand angekommen. Das kenne man schon von anderen toten EAs, es wird einfach nur noch so getan ob man was macht und ab und an kommt ein Alibipatch.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999399886', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1277, 'last_played': 1609529655}
review: Ridiculous amount of potential but so poorly executed that it just becomes frustrating. I have tried and tried with this game through bugs and crashes and more. It is such a creative, fun and brilliant idea but its just not there in the gameplay. I find myself turning this off after an hour at a time because I get too frustrated. You have no direct control over your 'settlers' so you simply tell them what to build and where. Unfortunately you will find a group of 8 people that are starving to death would rather run around repairing items (even when you have an automated repair bot) than building places to grow seeds, cultivate them and then cook them. They will have beds but die of fatigue. They are tired but refuse to build couches to rest. This on its own is not a game breaker, however, the way you call in drop pods of a random number of new 'settlers' after specific time frames (and sometimes never again) means that you are losing three settlers because they wouldnt prioritise correctly but only one new settler drops in. You must then wait another ten minutes before calling in new settlers and again this is random so you may get one you may get four who knows. For this whole length of time you have two fewer workers which seems to mean the priorities fall further down the list. Add to this the fact some lose heart (mainly because they work backwards) so they wonder off into the wild to die and you end up never gaining additional workers, so the important things you need done, but your colonists refuse to do unless they have NOTHING else to do (that includes stuff you dont allocate), never get done, its drop pod, die or wander away, repeat, so you cannot advance your colony. This game is incredibly in depth and aimed at a very strategic audience. It isnt your average city builder and its not boring by any means. I genuinely want to love it. It seems like bugs are being ironed out but at a very slow pace. But it is happening. However, as it stands today I cannot recommend this game. If one small change were to be made, you could assign priority to jobs manually, then I would certainly change my review and insist you buy it. As it stands today the AI simply lacks the 'I' to allow it to work without atleast offering the player the option to manually set priority.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037669845', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1434, 'last_played': 1562831303}
review:
I've been following this game for a few years now. Though it is still in early access, and is UNFINISHED, it's a great concept and Simon has been making great progress over the years (which is not something you can say for a lot of early access titles!). 

The game is starting to become a true, working game at this point, and it's a joy to play! Though it did need a bit of polish for a while, which is possibly why the steam reviews are surprisingly low, it's not nearly as unpolished as it was before and many of the main game mechanics are now set. 

Worth a try if you like colony simulation, it has a TON of character and personality, and it's really well done for an indie! I think the majority of the negative reviews are from the older days when it was really an alpha. Figuring out how the gameplay works was a challenge because back then there was no tutorial or anything, and it would crash. Now crashes are mostly nonexistent and there is a tutorial, and the game mechanics are a lot less finnicky than they were (colonists act reasonably and follow orders assuming they can complete them). He's added tons of details and even a little floor polishing robot to cleanup colonist footprints!

Totally worth checking out, don't let the reviews turn you away, but be aware, it isn't finished yet, and you're buying an alpha. Don't expect it to have all of it's Campaign and mechanics fleshed out yet.

I recommend checking out his devlog to see how he makes progress, they're enjoyable to watch

author: {'steamid': '76561198028238016', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 4240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4089, 'last_played': 1548911682}
review:
Okay I finished the first 3 missions and think I can give it a proper release review.

I think if you are a fan of base building games you will be able to see passed the bugs and little things. This game does need a lot of polish but it is playable and it is difficult. The developer seems to be working hard on the game and that is good to see.

If you don't absolutely love base building games get this one on sale.



Early access review below

I keep trying and I keep crying....

Things that need to be improved before I will endorse this
1. AI: you know it, we know it, the AI is just bad. Hire someone that knows what they are doing or get some community members to help. This happens --> person gets out of the capsule and starves to death when there is a whole room of food waiting to be harvested.
2. Environmental events. Non customized exploration has events happening almost every day and some times 2 to 3 times. there are way to many events firing off. 
3. Maintenance is extreme. AI shouldn't have to maintain every item every darn day. it takes like 5 repair bots for a tiny little base and humans are still repairing stuff. 
4. Research should have some ability to focus it.
5. Depression and suicide. I had 3 humans walk off into the wilderness on like day 3 and then lost 2 more people trying to get their bodies back. If someone is going to do something like that there should be time for emergency medical response to save them. 
6. Careers. There should be a way to assign people to certain tasks. I got a guy who is good at constructing stuff spending all his time playing with the trees. This would be handled by something in the command room
7. Priority of objects. Double clicking on things helps when it doesn't make you pick the object up and then have to replace it. There is a better way. Click on a button on the interface called priorities and set a numerical number of priority to the object.


keep working hard you will get there 

Added 09/12/2020 it is good to see that this game is still being worked on. I might give it a go again soon.

review:
I've been playing Maia now since alpha 0.51 I must say I've had my fare share of game crashes bugs and glitches during this time, some after playing for many hours without any issues then suddenly everything stops working.
 
I struggle to run the game for more than about 6 hours straight before something goes wrong either my colonists are starving to death when there's clearly enough food, and/or not harvesting the food they need to survive. Going outside when critically ill or dying when I've had a med lab built since the beginning of the game, well almost.. also I still can't get my toilets built no matter how early I place them down the BP.

To date my game still keeps crashing, now more than ever after the last update.. it's a bad as it was a year ago.

 I'd like to have more control over the colonists by giving them orders for specific jobs making them a priority, plus the option to train people in certain skills like agriculture and livestock which are essential to survival. 
I hope you keep working on Maia its a great game but could be so much better

author: {'steamid': '76561198004468758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 280, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1521355487}
review: This could be one of the best survival games ever made, and I wouldn't know. There seems to be no agency, no control and no means of actually getting anything done. Player Information in Maia is one of the worst I've ever seen. I know how to place rooms, and what I would 'like' built. That is literally it. Maybe it works perfectly for the fanatic fanbase (that i'm sure exists and will rage at this) but again, I wouldn't know. There is zero information given to the player ingame as to HOW to build anything. It took some effort but mining was simple to figure out. So clearing rooms was easy, and placing rooms is simple. Unfortunately because of how aweful the building system is, it's just as easy to accidentally destroy your rooms, instantaniously mind. There is a long drawn out process to build a room, yet you can clear and undo everything you've done in one miss-click. Every time I come back to this, I had forgotten why I disliked it. Every time I give it another chance, I put it down within 20 minutes of attempts.  To put an emphysis on this, I wasn't able to get colonists to build the ONE THING THEY NEED to survive the first 5 minutes. They all die from hypothermia, and refuse to build a single heater. This is the massive drawback to a survival game where you have zero control over the people. A game that does this, and attempts to make something no one likes work desperately needs perfect AI, easy to use controls, a gameplay loop that can be understood quickly, and mechanics that work together very neatly, while also being complex enough to justify having zero control over your people. This game does none of this, and to its detriment, shows it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980294531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9872, 'last_played': 1709514487}
review:
Maia reminds me of classic comedy admin games and it's meant to but it doesn't play exactly like them. You don't control your colonists directly and you can't change the world yourself, you place orders which your staff or robots will carry out. Robots are robots and get to work as soon as they realise there's a job waiting but colonists have needs and might not rush off to build immediately so your job is to plan the base so that colonists don't have to spend all day looking after themselves.
Your first bases will die horribly while you figure out what needs building ASAP and what can wait but once you've got the hang of setting up a self-sufficient base you can stop babysitting your colonists and start expanding or experimenting with rooms. Or decorating.
There's a research system to figure out once you've done that with a bunch of nice upgrades to unlock as well but once I've built and researched everything I lose interest in that base and restart - there's not really much to do at that point besides exploring or expanding just for the sake of it and every sandbox has to end somewhere.
It's still in EA but it's not stale, the development branch is regularly updated and Simon jumps on bugs as he finds them. Some features may be lacking or wonky but such is early access, I'm not worried that I'll end up with an unfinished game. The core of the game is solid already, I can start a base and play for hours without crashes or unexplainable deaths or any glitchy weirdness.
Did I mention that I enjoy it? Maia is fun as well. I like Maia.

review:
It's an impressive start for a game, and looks like it's going in the direction I want it to be. The sense of humor is excellent, the look and feel is really cool, the potential of this being a game that eats your time up is high. The developer is charming, updates frequently, and is clearly here for the labor of love. 

In its current state, there AIs are not bright enough to take care of themselves. The game is still in Early Access, so there are a lot of feature that aren't quite there yet. If you're impatient, and looking for a polished final product (as a lot of other [whiny] reviewers seem to be), then hold off until version 1.0 or later. If you're looking to get in and watch this thing take shape, jump on in there!

review:
I enjoy sitting down with my dogs after work with a drink, and taking on the responsiblity of building an unstable colony full of unstable colonists on an unstable planet. Let your peons regale you with generative poetry, avante garde personal music projects and pleas for help before hypothermia sets in,

There's a lot more to Maia than might be apparent, under the hood a ridiculous amount of little simulations are ticking away, cascading through each other, butterfly wings flapping, ponds rippling and other appropriate metaphors. Some people will find this a touch overwhelming, others will enjoy figuring it out.

Enjoying the game and enjoying supporting developers who make stuff that they love.

OK I have been following this game for a looong time. Finally decided to say this is a no.

Really the game is complex, has a huge amount of features. It looks like it would be really interesting.

But my god the demoralizing bugs. Like colonists getting stuck behind/inside walls when building a room and then dying. Or the colonists trying to build items and like not, until they stress out and still not build the items and it stresses you out. Or the horrid AI pathfinding. Sound needs work, graphics need polish.

This game right now needs a lot of polishing. If it gets the love it needs I'd consider changing my recommendation but until then, nope.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042116220', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1510596194}
review:
I bought this Game way back in 2015 and compared to when I bought it, it HAS improved, however there is still so much Bugs in the game nearly 3 years later. The developer does has a lot of good ideas and the game itself has potential, it's a game I REALLY want to love but I feel it just needs to be put down.

There are so much controls to remember, I can't keep up, the AI is most important in a game like this but it is woeful (building a room can take hours as the AI simply does nothing sometimes or gets stuck on a wall). Also your colonists can simply just die randomly when all seems fine. 

One final thing is (and this may sound like an attack on the developer so soz about that) more new uninteresting, random content is being added and the existing bugs, glitches, shoddy tutorials etc are simply being ignored and not fixed. Almost 3 years now, but finally I'm out, i'm done with Maia for good now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979021167', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1644560949}
review:
MAIA is clearly a labour of love for an indie developer. I have a lot of sympathy for that, and viewing it through that prism helps me see past some of the more glaring issues.

The game is essentially a Dungeon Keeper-style simulator set in space, where you are a administrator rather than an evil wizard overlord. You carve out rooms, place objects in said rooms, and the colonists do their thing with what you provide. The strategy is in when and where you place rooms and objects, and it's good fun.

The game is not easy at the start, particularly as the tutorial doesn't linger long on some key elements. It took me several plays just to realise some core gameplay elements, too, like the importance of having the smelter and the robot manufacturer early, as well as power and space heaters, but that may just be me. (I lost many a colonist to hypothermia. Good times.)

To my mind, given I haven't found any major game-ending bugs, the issues are with the UIX and the colonist AI.

The UI feels sluggish, which is irritating to begin with, but you do get used to it. That's not a big issue.

The colonist AI, however, is more problematic. Because there's no way of directing individual colonists, you are completely at the mercy of the AI. And it has no mercy. It will send your colonists off to do things you would consider very low priority over things that are litterally life-saving. That's a much bigger issue, as several hours of game can be ruined by a colonist taking a stroll outside while fires rage and fellow colonists suffocate.

Having said that, I still give MAIA a thumbs-up. It's a worthy endeavour that needs your support. If you like Dungeon Keeper-style games, pick it up.

review:
just bought it to play it while in EA,its been on my wish and watch lists for years. I want to like this game,but i can't its trash pure and simple.

THE BAD

Bad UI all around.
Lacks sounds 
The sims ai is very bad,they will not delete things or build things for hours(real TIME if ever) and other problems.I could not get these ppl to delete a bird feeder in the middle of the floor for 15 hours,and they still have not done it,and there is nothing else to do but make food,and yet they are just jogging and studder running? around the base like its going to h3ll.lol

Very bare bones with things to place in rooms,very bland and basic for 5 years of EA.

The one that made me laugh was the Command room, and only a  map table is used in it.made me laugh like what no coms,no back up stuff,nadda. POINT?

The sims look the same, very similar even in their clothes.and jog and stop,jog and stop as their walking animation,its horrid.
When sims die,if ever,you just push a button and Magic another capsule drops from space,earth or some station you have no contact with,but its safe to drop on in!!
There is a cap on ppl you can have i assume,cause i have around 12 and i can't push that button anymore...

The simulation of the sims is very dull NO sounds at all

Lacks everything needed to know the people,their moods,etc,also lacks basic suppy tables. You do have a roster that you can hover over but this is another bad UI thing,,but its just names and their basic skill set as if their skills matter.Also this roster is a bad placement for what it needs to be.No needs listed,nothing like hunger,water etc...the stuff you need to know.

No build costs,or know what it takes to make something,it just smelts something then they build it.weird cause the metals have all this info on them that is a total waste of time to read and its funny,like 10% co2 or 50% etc..for what? lol its just bad

You have a storage room that will have tons of metals and they will not use it,and you will need to dig more and more just to get the AI working building what you placed and they will never use the metals all over the floor or in the hoppers..
 Can't tell if they are happy or sad or care,all they do is have a body sweat and temp reading on them.
Lacks animations.
The gfx for this game do not fit it,its hard to explain,but it looks like a realistic vibe,but it does not play that way.

Msg spam and pop ups while playing the game is so past annoying its hard to get past that alone.
The sims just jog around and sometimes will hug each other in the most crazy of places leading to their deaths sometimes,Bad AI. Setting up a base on some horrid planet would take skills,effort and dedication not hugs and non stop jogging,just does not fit the game type its weird.

Also there is a voice of the base telling you warnings and such,where does this voice come from? the Command room? NOPE...out of thin air.

Found it to be very boring after a few hours
So they make food,but you need to keep placing ration boxes for them to build or they will not eat the food they made...weird.
Nothing good to say about this game other then it looks good as in the base art and assests.
To me this game is someones college class project.

These devs tryed to make the game seem like its so deep with skills for the sims,but you can pick the worst ones,like a game programer and set up a wind turbine,etc,so its just for what i call milking EA updates.

Very slow dev team milking EA for sure. Games been in EA for years and what looks to me like it was when i first seen it years ago on youtube with the same stuff in it that it had years ago.You can go see for yourself.

SO what updates? The same ones you see from devs who have no clear goals to the game and what it can be and what it is , will not just move on and take it like a man,this game is a fail and they as a team do not have the skill set to make this game into what ever it was when they first dreamed when starting it and if this is it,well imo should be removed from steam... 100% this game will be left for dead for sure,you can already tell just by playing a few of these types of games and this one stands out for all the wrong reasons. Like rimworld,murcury fallen,space colony etc,there is a few more out there,even games like hearthstone,space base df9 and others on my list,this one is the worst one so far.

I would say make a few saves,and often just in case CTD's i played 4 games for 15+hrs or so and  crashed often.

Worth it on sale,not worth full price as it is a bit annoying with msg spam like i never seen before,repeat msgs by the dozens the whole time you are playing,to the point you stop looking at them and deleting them. non stop and other weird things like the need to place objects like a thermo gen next to an air lock thats next to your base wall etc.

Overall i would say wait on this one as it imo is never going to be anything but a temp and farming sim with no sounds straight up cash grab for sure,and that kinda sucks.

The sims are very basic and not much to see other then them jog around ....pretty blah.

Would be cool if it was the next rimworld or a clone of another EA game called Murcury fallen but this game does not even come close to the most basic of tasks in those game for around the same price and been in EA for longer. Heck you can buy space colony for like 5 bucks and it was made 20 years ago and is better then this by miles on end.nuff said

This game for what its got feels very empty and lacking in every way you can think,but it does look good,and i think that is the Con.

6 for gfx
0 for sounds
3 for music-cause i dont listen to game music.
4 for effort.
10 for concept

But if you get it super cheap like i did,then go for it. but its a pretty basic bland colony sim. I hope this game does become something cause it looks cool,but 4 or 5 years in EA and its still looking like the first year...prolly not.

Still gonna play a bit more on the other map types,so far the game is just overall boring and maybe need to watch a movie like Moon or something to get in the mood to boot this POS up

author: {'steamid': '76561198037746408', 'num_games_owned': 277, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 12314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9529, 'last_played': 1545139703}
review:
I love Maia. I've played the game through at least 30 builds.  

The good.

The game is fully playable.  Rare crashes - and for those that experience - a dev who is extremely responsive / quick to fix if it's something on his end.

It's hard.  Not least because the AI is; on occasion, still a bit screwey - but it's basically 90% baked now so it's totally workable.  The hardness is just that.  It's a hard game.  Building a colony on a remote planet with only 4 people probably would be right.

You'll die.  You'll die again.  Sometimes it will be bad luck. Sometimes it will be a gameplay mechanic you need to learn.  Sometimes it'll just be a bad spawn (you'll soon learn to recognise the good ones!)


The bad

Very little.  it's a one man dev but the progress is steady if not light speed.  But updates come regularly.  Are properly tested. There is a dev / experimental branch for those inclined.  The dev Simon is very responsive - there is a good community of loyal players who have played multiple builds and provide constructive feedback.   Why is that bad.  Well it's small and it's slow.  And like everyone of course I'm impatient.  So the bad isn't too bad at all.

Overall.

It's an early access game with a committed developer; a clear and achievable roadmap and steady progress towards a fully baked game.  At the moment it's fully playable across multiple plarforms and configs and for those rare ocassions where a new player has a hardware issue - the dev is quick to work to resolve.  

A game that only got made becaues of Kickstarter and Early Access and which will benefit from your investment.  It's not 100% - I'd say a good 70% though and very playable and enjoyable.

(Steam says I've played 150 odd hours but that's a significant undeestimate. Some builds don't seem to trigger Steam's clock and streaming locally - which I do all the time - never counts towards play time.  It's probably more like 400 hours and therefore worth every penny of what I paid !)

author: {'steamid': '76561197972029520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4747, 'last_played': 1544745827}
review:
Ver 0.63

I really enjoy this game. Well, I can't really call it a game yet. It has what feels to me around 97% of a complete game. Keep in mind that this is early access. That said, I have been on this ride for quite some time now. It has constantly been updated and with each release makes big progress. Dev is active on forums and as far as i can tell and have seen, listens to the community and tweaks the game accordingly. If you like builder/sim games (Evil Genius) this game is up your ally. If you also like to support early access this is your game.

Im not going to list the pros out, but there are many.
Here are the cons as far as playablilty:
Tooltip is still sloppy (trouble setting priority, sometimes deletes item and puts tooltip into placement mode)
AI still needs some work
Build priority control is basically non existent
People die and get stuck under items and in walls
Doors can be a pain to get completed
Tutorial needs work (would help with learning hot keys and such)
Additional airlocks can be difficult to place if not done just so
Tend to have a hard time having native animals around 

Thats about all I can think of that has bothered me or caused me problems. In no way do any of those things make the game unplayable. Just can be annoying from time to time as the dev brushes them up and polishes them. I have played this so far 79 hours. I have enjoyed every one of them.

If Sci-Fi is your thing and you enjoy simulation/builders, get this game and help support the dev. We are not far from a jewel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997247948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 22360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 85, 'playtime_at_review': 19663, 'last_played': 1709871765}
review:
[b]Note:[/b] I wonder if there's a misconception that Maia is new. It's not. It released in Early Access, [u]Dec 4, 2013[/u]. The persistent "dev team" is a single man who has performed the Herculean task of expanding a neat bit of code to muck about with lighting into a space colonization game. If the reader is surprised by that, consider how impressive it is that a 6 year old game concept and design still garners such attention and ire.
If the reader has concern that Maia is an abandoned game, the reader is encouraged to visit [url=https://dev.maiagame.com] dev.maiagame.com [/url] for the latest updates and enjoy an informed opinion on the "abandoned game" opinion. 

[i] March 25, 2020[/i]
Well, I still like it. 

I just spent several hours having another play through (Is the metric [i]really[/i] 7 hours?!). Good times. I made it to day 46 before deciding to begin writing. Everything about the controls came back to me or was in the in-game help. I didn't play the tutorial.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*] The graphics, being stylized along the lines of 1970's / 80's British sci-fi design, are still enjoyable
[*] The humor is unmistakably British and dry
[*] The game tempo is relaxed. Real relaxed. I mean, people die and you're suddenly General Melchett.
     [list]
     [*] Dehydration? It's a tough swallow, what.
     [*] Exhaustion? Went flat out, did she?
     [*] Explosive concussion? Oh, blast!
     [/list]
[*] Haiku, all of them
[*] Pleasure is in the details. Read the descriptions. Read the emails.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*] Game controls. Maia went its own way on the user interface. It's there. It's usable. But, it's not well documented. By the way....
     [list]
      [*] [i]alt+mouse movement[/i] is the alternative to [i]middle mouse button[/i] to adjust the camera angle
      [*] [i]middle mouse button[/i] click de-|prioritizes building the object
     [/list]
[*] More than one airlock is begging for trouble
[*] Sometimes a restart of the program is needed to get the colonists going again
[*] James Cameron isn't British, so Sarah Conner never appears when we need her (You can still channel Kyle Reese and [i]blast[/i] those metal mothers into junk)
[/list]

[b]Random thoughts:[/b]
For longer term enjoyment, treat working with the AI, especially in consideration of pathing / object placement as goal, instead of regarding pathing as a shortcoming. Still, Pathing, you've come a long way, baby!

On the topic of enjoyment. It's really better to lean toward [i]Black Adder[/i] expectations of outcomes as opposed to [i]True Lies[/i] when playing the game; cynical vs. all the goodguys live. 

If I recall correctly, I usually managed to kill off my first colonist in a couple of days. With the play-through that I used for this Review, it was day 36 or so, and, given that none of the other colonists could be bothered to help, Q. Hanson probably wasn't such a great loss to the mission. 

Were I to make an effort to keep canno....colonists alive, I would regularly check them via the colonist focus in the lower left corner, to ensure that they hadn't exited an animation/interaction into a wall or object, and take action to ensure they wouldn't await their death with a stiff upper lip. I'd also apply the concept that the less objects against the walls is more death-free gameplay.

[i][b]SQUIRREL!!![/b][/i]



[i]Original Review[/i]
[i]Sep 25, 2017[/i]

I've been playing this game for a long time now, over the years. It's getting better, but I enjoy it for more than the gameplay. If you want to know about gameplay and the genre, etc. You may be better served reading a different review. Know that the game is early access. It is improving, with bugs being squashed, game mechanics being tweaked, and new aspects being introduced.

I became aware of slow TV via Norwegian programming. Slow TV programs run for hours sometimes even tens of hours, showing a task in its entirety, like the preparation and burning of a log fire. The programming shows the actual effort that goes into creating things. There's no montage to steal that appreciation for the real effort, which yields the result and how that effort contributes to the satisfaction in the well done job.

Maia has held my interest in a similar way. On the other hand, Maia sometimes feels like an Advent calendar. I open it up, get a treat and go away, returning when it's time to open the next box. 

Observing the steady progress and effort put out by Simon Roth has made the game rich for me. I watch the pathing today and know that Simon spent significant effort to improve it. At the start of each game, I wonder how food consumption will proceed, because it's been tweaked over and over in the effort to find the right balance. I take direct control of the utility robot with its laser welder then head off to the livestock room for some culling, and anticipate the day that the oxygen draining chicken parades are no more.

Simon is a responsive developer, but is firmly set on his vision of Maia. He interacts with the community, taking ideas, offering explanations, and generally demonstrating his interest in what people have to say. If a developer version of the game goes south, I'm used to his quick action to restore the game to a playable state.

Owning Maia is contributing to a Work. What kind of Work might be up for debate, but that Simon Roth has set out to create a Work is unquestionable. Indie gaming has seen its share of failures. Developers throwing up their hands and calling whatever was in front of them "good enough". For years Simon has steadily plodded along, singlehandedly developing his concept. I applaud that effort. From the outside it's like watching concert music being composed with various movements being created in a fit of inspiration and then being worked over to complement each other. Frankly, I can't wait to see this Opus finished.

The fact is that this game has held my attention more than any other purchase I've made. Heck, I've almost invested 3 working months of time in gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981539515', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1512226543}
review:
Hello all. I am playing the 0.63 release. The game has come along and is in a playable state. There are some balancing issues but nothing eggregious. I feel like the game could be a bit harder. I think you get through the early game quite fast and then it slows to a crawl as you wait for your colonists to build the things they let you know via email. 

The email system could be cleaned up some, as sometimes the emails open on there own, and you have to close them. Other times you see an email that has not been opened. As you read the emails and respond to them, and to other crises around the colony, you decide what should be built and order it. Then you sit and wait until your colonists get around to it. 

I am not sure but I think the smelter works automatically though sometimes you check it and as soon as you hover over it it starts working. I would like a dialog of the smelter so you always know what state it's in.

BUG:The 3D printer can be placed to close to a wall and the new IMPs cannont get of from between the wall and the printer. This last item I will report to the devs. 

WANTS:I would like to see the walls bias out of view as you mouse over them so you can more easily see what you're working on in the room.

In conclusion I want to see this game completed and I recommend it even now due to such high potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014503096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 4277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4002, 'last_played': 1538800394}
review:
A more 'down to earth' alien planet survival game. Main resources in play are food, water and electricity.
Game has a simple tech tree but upgrades are randomly researched.
Combat is minimal for once with the main focus on staying alive and keeping ther base running.

review:
I have had this game for quite a long time on my wishlist and I haven't bought it because of the negative reviews. I decided to buy it anyway, and I haven't regretted it at all. author: {'steamid': '76561197970426973', 'num_games_owned': 126, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 786, 'last_played': 1502954230}
review:
This game is now quite complex and avanced and I'd recommend it to anyone enjoying administering a colony on a foreign planet. Nevetheless, I'd like to point out that I used the world "administering" and not "ruling", for example.

Indeed, it's not a "god game", your role is to give the priorities of the station through make/build/repair/expand/research commands. However, the game has a built-in life simulation, which means your colonist need to eat/sleep/socialise and also to take care of your base (repairing, handling food growth, food making, dealing with water supplies, etc.). Moreover, they will send you e-mails explaining their needs and state of mind, that you have to take into consideration.

Therefore, and I think this point is the biggest part and also the most complex part of the game, you really have to understand and to manage people in a station instead of only the station as a structure. 

And, I think, this is where the game really shines. It took time, for a player, to really understand how everything works  but in the end it's really addictive and pleasant to watch everything working. 

For now,  the game is laking better tutorials and I think some kind of help manual that you could access during game could greatly improve the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040631430', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2197, 'last_played': 1502127801}
review:
Never wrote a review before, but here goes. Bought this game a couple of years back and put it away since I could not figure the starting out...lousy instructions folks. A few days ago, I decided to try again and so much easier. I've played about 3 or 4 days now and enjoying myself. After several bouts of absolute frustration I am now at day 57 with 12 colonists. 

Hydroponics was lousy so I bypassed it by doing animal containment and living quarters before it. Also built more ration packs at the beginning of the game (and dev? how did I do that with no supplies?) then brought in another load of colonists. After hitting the more colonists button I built my table, the wind turbine, atmosphere thingee, flywheel energy thingee, and then waited a bit while they did it all. More energy producers, the smelter, and a bed and food table, then went for hydroponics after all that. However, if you don't have both a food table and ration packs, someone's gonna starve. You won't be perfectly balanced until you get that 2nd table.

I noticed that some games have a lot of hypochondriacs after I create medbay. Though I still have not figured out how to cure their awful blues. I think maybe lighting so still experimenting. If don't have a lot of that, then I get more broken bones that you would believe. Like 4 broken arms for the same person, all on the same day. lol. Jeez dev. I don't think anyone would break their arm 4 times.

All in all, I enjoyed the game once I actually got started. As I believe I said, it's frustrating. Especially when everyone dies and you don't have a clue as to why except they were asphyxiated. My theory is poison gas from a just opened area but I don't know if that's even in the game. Dev. consider that for difficulty = insane. I'm a well-aged lady here....don't you dare say old... so sometimes all the sounds overlapping the warnings is often hard to decipher. Also my people keep telling me about an alarm bell that is either zen or insanity depending on the colonist. On a hunt to find it....sigh. All in all, it's fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561197973294980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1493791654}
review:
I don't remember when I started supporting this game, but its been awhile. Years probably at this point. 

When I purchased it, I simply liked the idea of the game (survival/colony manage game). Though I don't have many hours on the game, Maia sits on favorites list and I come back to it every few months. And every few months, its improved. 

I can't say much for the game in its current state, it definately needs some refinement, but I can comment on the developer. With all the early access garbage, and I've supported a few, the game takes its time being updated but its updated consistantly even about 4 years after release by what I understand to be just one guy. Even if I end up not liking the game in the end, I happily support a single man team that continueously provides content in a sea of early access garbage.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975732248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 5633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5342, 'last_played': 1543114896}

I really like both the premise and execution of the game mechanics. It's not an easy game by any means, but challenging and entertaining. author: {'steamid': '76561198105086497', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1517887001}
review:
An excellent and original idea that completely fails in execution.

Unfortunately, I can only give limited gameplay reviews, as the engine and various other failings have hindered my access to the actual game. 

First and foremost: Fullscreen mode scaled to screen size! How can I emphasize this enough? Every game scales the screen size to the edges of the monitor, and adjusts its resolution within these limits. But not Maia... Heaven help you if you toggle fullscreen, as the menu, along with 75% of the game's interface, will be shoved out of your view, leaving you to desperately try to find a way to get it back. But why would you need fullscreen in the first place? It is a convenience, truly, but I enjoy being able to scroll my view down in the game, a luxury that is denied for those of you who cannot properly scale the game's interface on full screen. 

NOTE: I may retract this portion of my review in the event that I purchase a 5 foot screen.

Second, optomization. For the love of all that is holy, optomize this game! My top-of-the-line computer should not be choking or lagging the instant I activate 2X antialiasing. And to add on to that thought, why am I forced to ramp up the graphics settings in order to get back to "none"? Another seemingly nit-picky feature that has ended me in a CTD because I had to go up to maximum antialiasing to get to none. The game panicked at what appeared to be a demand for unreasonable graphics and immediately jumped off of a bridge. So perhaps the ability to simply select lower graphics settings without testing the strain on your engine?

Third, and I know I'm going to get crapped on for this, fix the OS X port! Yes, I became so frustrated trying to make this game work on windows that I resorted to an iMac to come from another angle. I know the saying "nobody games on a mac" and apparently, the development team here has taken that to heart. Their OS X version of this game doesn't even finish loading the main screen before crashing into a heaping pile of wasted code. If you're going to sell a product for a different platform, so help me God, it is on you to make sure that it at least works! Anything less, is theft, plain and simple. 

Fourth, the AI needs some serious love. For the time I was able to play, my colonists watched as two atmosphere generators broke down and a third caught on fire. They started crying instead of worrying that the air was going to run out if they didn't jump to action. Two of them chose to starve to death instead of going to eat, and a second one kept sleeping, rather than do her job. Yes, I'm talking about you, K. Smith, you lazy freeloader! Nobody wanted you in this colony anyway! 


TL;DR, 
Don't buy this game until they fix their graphical interface to something actually usable. Don't buy this game until the AI is less pathetic. And DON'T BUY THIS GAME IF YOU OWN A MAC!! (Unless you don't like having money and want someone to take it from you. And even then, there's better ways than to give to these people.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198109004495', 'num_games_owned': 165, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1498466401}
review:
I really wanted to like this game, but it has been an incredibly buggy experience. Ignorning the fact that the game can sometimes quit without warning (everytime you agree to listen to the music your colonist has created.), the game isn't really in a stage where it is actually playable - as far as I can tell - the colonists will just stop collecting the smelted metal and you won't have any building materials to build anything, or they just won't build. So your colonists are pretty much doomed to starvation, or hypothermia or death due to fatigue as they won't do any of the things you want them to do. 


You also can't really react to all the emergencies and warnings that you are given because they will simply keep warning you of low temperatures at a certain room but since the colonists won't build the heaters you asked them to, they will freeze to death.



It's an interesting simulation but pretty repetitive. I see that the creator has been working on a ton of new features but I think he should probably work on polishing the AI till the game doesn't just end in failure each time. I haven't actually gotten far enough to enjoy the new features (or even the research lab) because the colonists just keep dying and refusing to build anything.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992189182', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1875, 'last_played': 1536022919}
review:
I ended up reversing my first review. My initial complaint was about the lack of feedback. This still holds true at the start of the game! If you can keep your colony alive past the first few desperate days the game does become more intuitive. At that point I found the game much more entertaining. You now must play a balancing game, "Do I risk sending colonists outside during a meteor swarm to build more power generation, or can I risk a loss of power?" I do like the unique feedback system that comes in hints in the Emails sent by your colonists. I see a lot of potential for this game.

But! The reason why I originally did not recommend this game is still there. The first few days of the game are still a black box, with only one path forward to survive. I hypothesize that the difference between life or death can measured in how many steps the colonists must take to get between rooms. That’s harsh for the first few minutes of the game! In the end I never did solve this initial hurdle, but had to watch and copy the developer’s video blog.

So, welcome to Maia, a death world where the Reaper is breathing down your neck!

P.S. And, remember it is still in Alpha.

review:
This game breaks my heart about once a month or once every other month.

I have followed this game for a while now and i visit the blog every so often ( whenever i remember to ) and in all that time I have never in my life been able to have a colony that doesn't completely collapse because people get stuck, or items get left in the build queue or people die / starvation of completely unknown reasons.

I almost wish that the developer would leave the priority queue logging messages in so i could figure out where they are getting stuck and keep my colony alive long enough to see what the game is about.

I tried again today while taking a short break and yet again i watched one person die right in front of a full water barrel from dehydration and another die of starvation while stadning in front of a ration.

And meanwhile we get the addition of lava.

If I could even get to lava.

I will update this if it ever changes. Right now it feels like a tech demo destined for vaporware.

review:
okay, there have been a lot of negative reviews for this game recently so i kinda feel that i need to defend it a little bit.
yes the UI is to be tweaked and eased
yes there are lots of bugs (some can be worked around for now)
yes there is not much to do once your colony is up and running

but come on guys, this is a small crew working on a quite huge poroject (some patience is a must!). look on the details, look on a witty description of things and items ingame. this requires both time and quite a character. plus the dev is kinda sexy and funny and i like to follow his videos on youtube.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037960595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1517670880}
review:
Edit as of v0.66
After noticing the multitude of patches and the developer commenting on how many fixes he has pushed lately I thought to give it another shot. No crashes thankfully. Started off very promising, colonists actually build stuff now (!) and for quite some time I was considering finally swapping to a positive review. Unfortunately I can't quite yet and here's why:

I still had a colonist die of dehydration mere feet from barrels containing hundreds of litres of water. No colonist attempted to save her or move her corpse afterwards despite having a corpse storage unit.

My airlock randomly disappeared at one point and everyone died.

People have just walked through walls to escape rooms somehow and yet still had some sort of emotional breakdown, I have no idea why anything that happens in this game actually happens.

My colonist magicked himself outside without a suit and promptly died.

It takes a colonist thirteen(!!!) seconds to pick up building materials from a smelter after they're finished. Thirteen seconds from the moment they arrive at the machine to the moment they leave.

We're really getting there though and I can (and have for other games) overlook some hefty bugs and issues, but there's just so many gamebreaking issues here. I actually enjoyed myself here and there though and didn't get pissed off at any point so there's that.

Edit as of V0.65:
Thought I'd try again. Started off promising, colonists didn't sit and die for no reason, furniture actually did the bare minimum basic functions for which I built them but then it crashed. Repeatedly. I tried four different games, every one crashed. This game hasn't earnt any more of my time than that.

Edit as of V0.62:
I was very glad to see version 0.62 release, it promised some very interesting features plus a great performance boost which I was looking forward to. Unfortunately this version has rendered the game ever more buggy than before. Since the patch I've had the main menu hang on aborting a mission, the cursor disappears which makes me have to Task Manager the game closed then reopen it. 

I've had mining orders persist between attempts at levels, i.e. I start the mission Cassiopeia, place some mining orders, inevitably get screwed and then re-start only for the mining orders to still exist from previous attempts. 

It now appears possible when directly controlling the IMP to walk too close to a wall causing him to get pulled in and either destroyed or rendered unable to move or work meaning the end of the game if it's your only one, ruining a nigh essential feature as the IMP AI prioritises work so poorly it's easier to do it myself.

After another few hours in V0.62 I have come to the conclusion that he may as well have not added anything. In my experience, I still am unable to get anywhere near far enough into the game to even see my first chicken hatch or potato crop, let alone be invaded by herds of Velociraptor pidgeons. The more I try to like this game the more jaded I become.

Original Review(0.61):
It's not often I write reviews, particularly negative ones, generally speaking it's not worth the effort but for Maia I will make an exception. I bought Maia a number of years ago and no, I'm not upset by the lack of progress, the issue here is I have yet to get to find out how much is even possible within the game. I cant get past the first few days, despite following the quick-start guide to the letter. Everyone that makes suggestions as to what to do to progress makes the assumption that if I issue an order to my colonists, they will actually do it. Unfortunately they are so abominably stupid that nothing ever gets done. The first few things take an incredibly long time but do eventually get done. My first workshop, Table, Drill and so on. I build a smelter and an atmosphere generator and mine minerals and what have you but that's about as far as I get. I'll write the issues I have in a list format.

Colonists stop building stuff. I'll have building materials lining the walls in the storage room and they will do nothing at all. Occasionally they may fiddle with the table for a bit before continuing their exercise in inadequacy. 

Colonists are stupid to the point of having four rooms to stand in, three of which are a comfortable temperature with a dedicated atmosphere generator in each one, they will choose to stand in the empty room that is cold enough to give them hypothermia even though it is unfurnished and has a construction order in it for stuff that they will not build.

Certain objects the colonists never build. I've tried queueing up vents, space heaters etc, which never get done even if there is only a single order given at that moment, there is plenty of material and they are all walking around faffing about. 

On the rare occasion where a colonist decides to actually do something (it's generally not what I wanted them to do) it takes so abominably long for them to get it done that it's barely worth doing at all. 

I tried extremely hard to like Maia, I really did but my god, I've never had a game make me so damn angry at the idiocy on display by the colonists. 

I'll delete this review if the issues are fixed or I am proven wrong. 

Edit: I've given it another few hours and frankly I think I was too generous the first time around. People just start dying within the first two days for stupid reasons. Starving with plenty of food, dehydration despite hundreds of litres of water, freezing to death despite having warm rooms to stand in. Broken and buggy mess. I still want to like it but there are some ridiculous design decisions here even past the extremely "early access" colonist AI. Why do walls not connect with the stone? That's just needlessly wasted space. Why do colonists run two steps then stop then run two steps then stop?

author: {'steamid': '76561198010067561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1492804482}
review:
I bought Maia long time ago (Dec '13), I thought it was a very promising game, the gameplay looked good, complexity check, love for base building games check. But as soon as I started, the UI was not there to help you, it was there to confuse you. I guess that the developers want the feel of a terminal. For example, when you are trying to build something, having to iterate over the options just in case there is something new is just wrong.

After many many versions (more than 3 years). I tried the game again. Same horrible UX. Interfaces are meant to help the user, make it intuitive and a pleasure to play. Having to train my reflexes to browse the choice of items to build in a room till I find the one that I want is just bad.

That is just an example. But there are others. All of them cry for the need of a UX specialist. Please, please please, hire someone that can understand usability.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079202405', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1735, 'last_played': 1538417124}
review:
It seems this game doesn't do a good job of showing what it is/is not.

Maia *is not* a game where you can micro-manage people, fiddle with spreadsheets and build queues.

Maia *is* a game where you try to build a base with (and for) a bunch of colonists that will allow them to survive on a hostile alien world. The colonists handle (most) prioritisation of tasks, they handle what they will and will not build, they handle most of their needs; the game is working out what rooms or equipment they need to fulfill those needs and explore the world they have landed on, without dying.

The lack of build queues is not a bug, the lack of spreadsheets containing task prioritisations and other ways to fiddle is not a bug. The developer has (rightly) decided these things exist in other games to patch over bad AI and we have just normalised them. In software development these things are called 'leaky abstractions' and are not desirable.

It's been a long, hard slog to get the AI to the point where it works properly (AI is hard, BTW) and doesn't eventually do something dumb and kill itself, but with 0.61 I think we're at the point where it works pretty well.

The one big minus with this game seems to be usability: the game doesn't show the player what it is (note: I don't use the word 'explain' here), meaning users have the expectation of spreadsheets and tweaking, and the build menus are cumbersome and slow to use.

Maia is also working great for me on Linux (AMD/Mesa drivers). Simon Roth also is an alright bloke who's genuinely dedicated to finishing his game.


==============
Original, stupid review, which I still stand behind:
Simon Roth is a great man, he has great hair. The best hair, everybody knows that. He has the best hair in gaming and he likes me a lot. Everyone likes me especially Simon Roth and his hair.

I predicted Maia is going to be a great game, and it is, it is. 0.61 is the best game from early access in 2013 that might be released in 2017. That's what I said back in 2012 and I was right. And you know what goes into games like this? A lot of good stuff. Like Frustum Culling. Good stuff. Great hair. And I predicted that, and I was right.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994653997', 'num_games_owned': 1439, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1543484875}
review:
[UPDATED FOR UPDATE 0.67]
So previously I said that this game had some problems that needed to be solved before I could recommend it. Some of those problems have been fixed and the other major problem  I have can be fixed as well so I am gonna switch this to a recommendation

Previously my two main issues where the awkward way you selected things and the lack of feedback

The problem with the menu's has been fixed, mostly. Now when you scroll through the menu there is a little sidebar that shows you the list you are scrolling through. This makes it a lot easier to know how close you are to a given item. Not to mention making it easier to create a mental image of where things are relative to each other in the list. It also helps you figure out what things are in which list. I am still not a massive fan of this interface but it works well enough that I can live with it now. 

The problem with feedback has also been mostly fixed, the emails now tend to be more specific and easier to parse as you read them. This does help to point out problems without completely breaking the fiction. 

However the big problem I still have with the game comes down to the early game. When you start a new game you have a storage room and a airlock and that is pretty much it. There are a couple of things that you have to get built right away. A workshop, a solar panel or wind turbine and some atmo generators. 

These are things that are critical to surviving but I have had to restart multiple times now because it feels like if you don't do things in a very specific order in a very short span of time you are screwed. This comes back to a problem I had which was that the people in the base don't seem to give a shit about themselves. 

They will stand around doing nothing when workshop tables are open and they are all freezing to death. You can set priority but it doesn't really seem to make a lot of difference. Being able to use the click and drag system that is used to move stuff around to tell a person to built a certain thing right now would be great. Basically just some way to force them to do something right away. I get you shouldn't have direct control but if in this fiction I am the commander of the base I should be able to shout at them to do things in some way.

Really my major problem is just how brutal the early game is. It would be nice to have a checklist that would get you to a basic state of the base. The tutorial doesn't really do this since it starts with a lot of basic stuff in place. In the main game just having a list that says something like "Build X then build Y" and so on would really help with the early game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037804821', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1374, 'last_played': 1542595197}
review:
I bought this game a couple of years ago. I've kind have regretted it honestly. 

There is so much broken about the AI, it is unplayable. Colonists  will not do what you need them to to survive. The pace of development is an absolute crawl, and I would never have put the game out in the current state it's in unless it was free. 
I really believe the developer needs to get bigger/better team together in order to get this game into a playable state. 
I've been holding on strong for a while with hope that the next update will bring needed bug fixes in a timely manner. I always retrun to play for about 30 minutes. Then I slowly close my laptop in frustration. I've been doing this ever since I bought it.

What this game does have: A wonderful atmosphere. Great sounds, looks, and a bit of British humor.

What this game does not have: A purpose of completion. I get the point of survival, but where do we go after that? Maybe I've just never gotten to that point yet. Even so, the AI needs a huge overhaul to prevent weird oddities. (Priorities maybe? They're starving and won't build the planters, but they'll make 1000 solar panels in the meantime, so they obviously have enough building materials!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198067337159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1455333046}
review:
Let's journey back to the year 2012. Barack Obama was president,  console gamer were buzzing about the upcoming Playstation 4, and a young Brit started a Kickstarter project inspired by Dungeon Keeper called Maia. It was a promising pitch - a game about controlling a colony with a 1970s British "real" sci-fi aesthetic. It seemed mighty ambitious for a solo developer, but I was younger, more idealistic and believed in Maia enough to pledge USD $11 on Kickstarter.

Fast-forward to 2017. Barack Obama is no longer president. Playstation 4 dominates the console market, Rimworld has show gamers how a procedurally generated storytelling, colony building game can work, and Maia is still a glorifed tech demo with no signs of becoming a real game most people would want to play.  The graphics are even more outdated than they were in 2012. The game is stil buggy and lack focus. More than any of that, there's just not much to it. At the rate the developer is moving, my as of yet unborn children will be starting university before this "game" become anything remotely fun.

I have to hand it to Simon Roth. Most indie developers would have realized by now that their plans were not going to come to fruition, given up and faded quietly into the night with whatever Kickstarter funds were left, but Simon continues to s-l-o-w-l-y build his quixotic masterpiece (?) I personally gave up any hope on this game at least 2 years ago, but for anyone thinking about buying, only do so if you're cool with buying games that are unlikely to ever be finished and even less likely to ever be good.

review:
in its current state, i would not recomend you buy. maybe in 1, 2, or possibally 5 years, but not now.
yes, its an early acess game, but the core isue is..welll..
look, with this genre, the core cause of frustraition in the playerbase is the minion/colonist ai, as you have zero direct control over them.
in this case, its almost completely nonfunctional. while there IS a system for prioratising build orders, after an hour or so, its completely ignored, with colonists randomly assembling structures/furnature in whatever order they see fit (sometimes comitting suicide by ignoreing priority orders to build a hydorponic food farm or an air filter untill everyone is dead >.>), and they are incapable of basic behaviour SUCH AS SLEEPING,EATING OR DRINKING RELIABALLY as of 25/06/2017

i'll happily amend this review WHEN Simon is able to adress the AI issues, but..well. its been like this since it arrived on steam, with relatively small improvements, to some degree or other.


as a bit of an update, its gotten no better, arguabally even worse (some of the wildlife now has a chance to run at high speed into your base and eat ALL your rations less than 30 seconds into the game, and your colonists are more liekly to break down sobbing then follow an attack order.

they appear to consider comfort (beds ect) and random low-priority tasks a much higher priority than basic lifesupport (air scrubbers, air vents) and COMPLETELY IGNORE BUILD PRIORITY 50% of the time, have a high chance to set a microwave smelter on fire and die almost immediately the first time they ever use it (half the time comsuming all the oxygen in trhe air, due to their refusal to comply with oreders to build vents/scrubbers, anything involving hydroponics), are capable of starving to death while standing directly next to food/ literally refusing to take water from stockpiles and.....


look.Simon. you've done great on your own when you look at the task you've been working at.but.

you NEED to hire MORE coders.at LEAST one other person to assist with the project. you've been essentially spinning your wheels fruitlessly for the last several years, unable to get the ai to work reliabally (they still randomly get confused and stop moving/stall in an airlock till they starve/ die of dehydration)

and to be completely blunt, the state of the game is PATHETIC considering it has been on STEAm since 2013.
stop half-assing new features and put a complete and total feature lock on ANYTHING new untill the AI,pathfinding/pathwalking,rate of needs (oxygen,hunger,dehydration ect) decay ect ect ect are ALL BOTH BALANCED AND FUCNTIONING PROPERLY

author: {'steamid': '76561198008501262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1488160075}
review:
I'm a fan of this genre of game, way back from Sim City and Startopia. This game had a lot of promise to me: science fiction setting, resource management challenges, etc.

Unfortunately I can't recommend it. I've done the tutorial now 8 times and it always ends one of two ways: the one mining robot mining as instructed and getting crushed to death in a cave in, meaning no mining and no resource production; or the mining robot doesn't get crushed but the colonists all stand idly about not building the heaters and atmosphere generators they need to live, while power and materials are available.

I even tried playing without the tutorial, doing basic game starts without the tutorials guidance, and they all end the same way: my colonists freeze and suffocate while doing nothing to help themselves, no matter what is available to them. It's pretty boring, because the game pace is pretty slow, watching the colonists freeze to death.

These failed starts don't count the failed starts due to the clunky interface: you frequently end up unbuilding things that have been built, crucial doorways and room sections disappear with one false click, mislicked false starts on construction can't be cleaned up and started over.

No way the game is ready for prime time. But I bought it, and tried too hard so I can't give it back, so I guess I'll check back in a couple of years and see if it's been updated.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986560346', 'num_games_owned': 572, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1514722107}
review:
In short: Alpha build frustrations cloud what seems like a very promising colony builder & sim. Support now to increase its chances of reaching its very tangible potential.

First things first: it's an alpha build. Not a very early alpha - it already looks very good, the base game has a bunch of systems in it already - but not a polished and certainly not a balanced end-product.

The game is basically a dystopic, older vision of science fiction colony-building on an alien planet with cheekily British tones. To sell this game by its emotional air is mainly noting it's hilariously depressive tone. Everything is terrible: setting up a colony is not easy, and the human condition has so many requirements to retain the spark of life - your people will complain about being sad, tired, hurt, lonely, cold, hungry and thirsty, and then they will break down and die. Unless of course you manage to do your job.

Which, at the current time is more than just midly difficult. Here's where the alpha-ishness comes off heaviest. The balance is not just there yet, and the building-up-to-something-great is still coming up with bugs as games tend to when they're in their growing youth. Sometimes the game may deal you a foul hand by simply ruining the crucial piece of your initial setup, like caving in on your starter construction IMP robot just as you have spent your last building materials, leaving you to wonder who's doing the digging to get up some material production necessitated by your workshop attempting to construct the air processor to stop your folks from the good old freeze-and-choke of having no warmth and breathable air. Fair amount of my plays have been 10-20 minutes in to notice some calamity or unexplained AI non-co-operation to decide I'd rather start over than deal with the fresh hell that just ruined the current colonists' lives. And people dying off when colonizing a strange place is still OK, mind you, but some of these scenarios just flip over too many of the crucial pieces you need to have stuff progressing sensibly.

User-friendliness is not terrible, even at this alpha stage - having played some Dungeon Keeper or imitators will do you no harm to get the generic idea of how digging areas, building rooms and filling them with operational equipment works -  but the main mechanics are succinct and simple. You'll experiment a bit and learn a few things, browsing your available rooms and items and seeing through the mouse-over descriptions explain a couple things more. The tutorial is not a heavy chore, save for a few bugs at the time of writing this, that may confuse you when you are for instance ordered to build a room, but the tutorial step might not get checked and carry on if you didn't build a large enough room; something which will surely be corrected in improved instruction and polish soon enough.

All in all I got some bugs, some frustration out of confusion when I could not identify when colonists were not doing their tasks (were it an intermittent alpha AI bug, or was the colonist just too far gone in hunger and depression?), but for someone who looks up to building and growing an operation, nostalgizes about dungeonkeeper-alikes or maybe enjoys these sordid little histories that the game generates with these sorry folks trying to survive, there is a lot of promise in this one.

I'll be logging in a few feedbacks and a bug report soon and am looking forward to the day when I agree with the level of challenge as entertaining rather than frustrating when a few of my issues are being fixed in the coming versions - so far the developer communication and reactivity has given me nothing but trust for matters to proceed just so. Also, for whatever reason I keep getting pulled back in for a new try even though I feel the current build is just prone to quick failures with unclear or unfair situations in play. I'd love to get to the first play where I'll actually manage to ripen and harvest something from my hydroponics room before people starve to death or my mining robot collapses a lava flow onto itself and the colony.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002548765', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2450, 'last_played': 1538781198}
review:
Maia has one of my favorite atmospheres in a game. It has an  understated and dark sense of humor that is presented in both gameplay and the item descriptions. It reminds me of a dark, funny, sci-fi Evil Genius. 

It has lots of small, hidden jokes or easter eggs (like the computer terminal in the Research Lab ) and very amusingly designed systems (like colonists desparately sending you their avante garde music and haikus as pleas for interaction and validation) that show the developer's sense of humor and dedication to world-building. It gives it a strong retro-sci-fi humor vibe and a really enjoyable atmosphere. 


Particularly after the past two patches, the game has become very stable and many of the AI issues from earlier alpha have been fixed. The game is still difficult (by design) and one should expect a few colony failures before getting the hang of it. It is definitely worthwhile.

There are still bugs, but the developer has been very active in quashing them as they are brought to his attention

author: {'steamid': '76561198361121740', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1222, 'last_played': 1488053948}
review:
If you like god games, hard sci-fi, hyper-realistic sims, and dark, British humour, then you'll like Maia.

I've played Maia for about 20 hours now, more than enough to have built myself a fully self-sustaining colony with all the bells and whistles, including the rooms that require certain levels of research, so I've seen pretty much all of the permutataions of gameplay you can get within the game.

It took me a while to get that Maia is a delicate balance between active user input (build orders, smelting stuff, etc) and watching the formidable AI systems run. However, once I understood this, my colony ran a lot better, was more productive, and I got a lot more out of gameplay. Another challenge is balancing the amount of activity. Unlike other sims, your colonists get tired and sick and dehydrated if you work them too hard, so you can't just set 4892438 build orders and go make some tea. On that note, I LOVE the level of detail - from temperatures reactive to whether an air vent system is on or off, to body heat of chickens altering room temperatures, to the relative humidity being affected by water condensing systems, to atmosphere quality being augmented by potted plants, to plants *literally* getting species-specific diseases like fungal rot and black spot... there is phenomenal detail in here that I struggle to understand at the best of times, but massively appreciate.

Another thing is that dev Roth is quite literally the King of the Easter Egg. Most people probably don't notice or read the descriptions and names of objects, but there are some real 'laugh out loud' examples of punning names that play very well within the cultural nexus of dry, dark British humour. There's also a brilliant sense of British understatement to the emails - instead of saying 'we're literally starving here, half-wit, build some food prep stations', they say wonderfully passive aggressive things like "I hope this lack of X isn't another bureaucratic oversight." Ah, the art of the strongly worded letter is strong in this game.

In terms of practical playability, the game is pretty easy to get the hang of; controls are intuitive, and the 'tabbing through' range of objects based on context rather than having to go through a sims-style full-scale menu system is great.

The fact that the game is still under development shouldn't put you off - it's fully fledged already, and the updates (like 0.60 adding colonist relationships... again, how the heck was this coded in?!) just add more levels of detail and interest to an already fully formed and extremely well-thought-out idea. I paid full price for the game and don't mind as it's an indie dev, but it seems like it has frequent sales, so definitely pick this up right now.

Overall 9/10, definitely reccommend.

review:
I've been following this game for ages - it feels like it's been in development for a long time - I bet it feels even longer for the developer.

At this point it's lived up to it's originals promises and expectations, and recent versions have completely cleared the game of the issues that the historically negative users reviews on here talk about, so don't be put off by them.

This is a difficult, almost hardcore space management sim that doesn't do much handholding. If however, you want a challenging and deeply thought-out sim that reflects the subjects being simulated, then it's definitely worth checking it.

For fans of Dwarf Fortress, Dungeon Keeper and ilk who want a challenging and deep simulation game.
