author: {'steamid': '76561197996593537', 'num_games_owned': 581, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1484072820}
review:
The game is promising.  It looks lovely, its systems look to be interesting, and its sense of humor is enjoyable.  But at this point it's simply too unpolished to really be worth buying.

---

The most obvious problem is that there are no (reasonably functional) speed controls.  The game, as far as its UI will inform me, has exactly one speed, sloth.  People move like molasses and completing basic tasks takes ages.  And despite this pokey pace, you can't sit back and relax as you strategize as you would with other games in the genre because there's no real-time pause fuction - sure, there's an undocumented pause function if you hit the Pause Break key, but this can often crash the game.  The result is that you need to quickly queue up your commands, almost a bit like Starcraft but without the immediately obedient underlings or any of the good UI design that went into that game.

This is made worse by the awful controls - the game's framerate is still not as good as it should be so it's already not quite responsive enough on reasonable hardware, but inconsistent controls make planning out your base maddening.  When placing items, right click both returns you back to your regular cursor/interact mode [i]and[/i] removes items under your cursor, either queuing placed items for destruction or immediately removing what you just placed.  The result is a lot of frustration as you have to swipe away to an empty part of the map to safely right-click your way out, or risk misclicking with the flakey FPS when trying to click the menu item to swap out of item placement.

Placing rooms of course breaks this convention - right click will remove placed floors, but it does so immediately without any queuing so you can very easily cause messy problems that you'll then need your minions to slowly fix, and if you right click in an empty area you don't go back to Interact mode like you'd expect.

And Interact mode, where you can click on stuff and see information or view the station from the point of view of your colonists in first person (which is neat and even has a low-res camera feed filter), also doubles as your mining tool, so you'll frequently be mining things when you're just trying to click on a moving colonist.

Oh, and you have to do all this when it shakes the screen due to eathquakes, meteorites, and cave-ins, which are annoyingly frequent and make it hard to just control the game.

Then there's just the bizzare key placement.  Y and N are something you need to frequently hit, and I mean [i]frequently[/i], which is rather uncomfortatble since the game expects you to have a constant WASD grip.  The three main building tools - the aforementioned Interaction, Room, and Item modes - are bound to J, K, and L respectively.  These keys are nowhere near WASD where your fingers will be resting most of the time, while Z, X, and C right underneath remain unbound.  Why?  The keys are at least rebindable, though you'll have to spend a good amount of time figuring out what keys are important and which are pointless from experience.  The tutorial doesn't even bother telling you want the keys are, and the UI doesn't bother listing the keybind either on its icons.

These may seem like small nitpicks, but bad controls combined with time pressure in what's usually a more methodical genre make for an incredibly frustrating experience.

---

And then we get into the typical EA problems.

The game provides very little feedback on why your colonists aren't doing what they need to do.  I can have three full barrels of water and water fountains everywhere, yet my colonists will mysteriously die of dehydration regardless.  Hopefully this eventually changes, but for now it's complete guesswork as to what's wrong.  In a good Dwarf Fortress-like game you don't always know immediately what little cog in your operation is causing a holdup, but at the very least you have tools at your disposal to figure out what's going on.  Those tools apparently don't exist yet, mousing over a colonist gives some physical information but you can't get useful stuff like the last letter they wrote or recent complaints or anything like that, instead forcing you to dig through the often busy feed (while the game is still running in real time, mind you).  And since the game is buggy, you can't ever feel confident that you're losing because you messed up, you're always wondering if the AI is just being bad and not doing obvious things like eating when it's hungry.

Then there's the lack of content, bugs, and general unfinished state of the game that you'd expect out of an EA title.  Yeah, it's nothing shocking, but it's nothing special either that really demands your money now like Kerbal Space Program or Darkest Dungeons or Space Engineers.  Updates happen, but they sure as hell take their time.  This game's been in EA for a long time and it still feels like it has a long way to go.

~~~

The game simply isn't ready for your money.  I want to love the game so much and it feels like in two years maybe there will be a game worth playing, but as it is now it's just a really pretty piece of junk compared to other Dorflikes like Dwarf Fortress, Prison Architect, or even other EA games like Stonehearth.  It's not Spacebase-DF9 levels of terrible, there aren't unexplainable oxygen leaks that eventually kill everyone with no further promises to improve, but it just gets so many little things wrong that it can't hold a candle to a game like Banished.

Wait and see, the game has the potential to be great.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997559839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 4885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2618, 'last_played': 1595542508}
review:
Let me preface this... THIS GAME IS IN A ROUGH STATE.  

That said, I have been holding off writing this review, but given the slow but steady progress and most systems I expect to be in the game are there at this point, and the fact I can play a fairly decent game with only frequent but not constant crashes that can for the most part be worked around... I really like playing this game.   That is not an honor I bestow to lightly... out of the 400+ in my library I like maybe 30...   

This is a fun little Colony/Miner/builder/researcher/survival game.  The cost IMHO is a smidgen high, so I waited for a sale, but if you break it down per hour played it is roughly 50 cents/hour of fairly pleasurable time. 
There is challenge, there is heartbreak, there are even missions if you're into that sort of thing. 

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR A FLAWLESS EXPERIENCE. 

BUY THIS GAME IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR SOMETHING DIFFERENT, FUN AND ARE WILLING TO USE QUICKSAVE EVERY 5 MINS FOR ONE OF THE BETTER SCI-FI COLONY SANDBOX GAMES.

review:
I bought this when it first came to steam....honestly, not much has changed in 3 years and I don't see it going anywhere fast. If you want a spacey base building sim you'd be better off with Rimworld or Planetbase

Edit:

So the game got released and after completing the tutorial I started on the first mission....and that's about as far as I've got. I've retried a couple times and it always gets to the point where things go wrong....people stop making food, they start going AWOL and nothing in the tutorial or "alert" system tells you how to fix any of this so you just slowly trickle down on people and as you get less people even less work gets done. I have a medical room, a fully kitten out living quarters, hydroponics and yet things keep going down hill with....seemingly no reason to it. Clearly the game is missing some important features somewhere along the line.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971083882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1094, 'last_played': 1538662181}
review:
Giving this game a thumbs up based on Early Access status.

It's fun, 16+ hours in and looking forward to the next update.  If you are looking for a polished game, with no bugs this is not the game for you, but worth putting on  your follow list.

Pros: engaging idea, and appeals to my strategy sense.  I like the integration of AI in terms of survival, and building.

Cons: The build priority of the colonist is a bit wonkers, and the tools to set priority don't always work.  At times (without cheats) you're at the mercy of what ever the colonist think should be done first.  Often you will find a colonist build a new facility only to have the build the wrong door first, and without additional raw building materials they will dye of hypothermia.

That being said I like it, I like it a lot.  I have played several Early Access games and this is one that I will follow regularly.  Is it worth at buy, yes, especially since it is on sale this week.  But be aware it is underdevelopment and you will encounter bugs, and things that don't work as they should.  It's challenging, and entertaining!

author: {'steamid': '76561198014470600', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 3157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1437, 'last_played': 1552968134}
review:
As much as I like this premise and hoped for improvement I cannot recommend this game even after the latest patches. The colonist AI is so bad they will allow themselves to die rather than taking care of themselves. With something so basic being broken is bad enough, but with the dev promoting working around the bad AI rather than actually acknowledging and working on the problem looks bad the the game at any stage.

UPDATE: As of the release of version .60 the colonists are no longer out to kill themselves and actually take care of their basic needs for survival as long as what they need is available. With this, the game can actually be played and progress made in creating a base. While there are still significant problems, this marks a huge improvement and is actually in a playable condition and can recommend this game.

FURTHER UPDATE: Sadly, after great progress and improvement was done, the developer introduced further bugs into the game and simultaneously declared the project completed and has not made any further updated to correct these game breaking problems since that time. As such, despite such great earlier progress, this has turned into yet another "declare finished and abandon" release.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003954276', 'num_games_owned': 1378, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 620, 'last_played': 1526129220}
review:
Maia is a nice approach to all the survival and base building games and it has a sci fi setting. Given SciFi it does not do magic but is more a "hard scifi" kind of game. The airflow e.g. is modeled realisticly and solar storms disturb your communications and energy transfers.

You cannot control your colonists directly (that technology has yet to be discovered) so it adds a feel of the Sims to the game. In result when the game tells you that it is dangerous going out, guess what some of your colonists suddenly urge to do? Right, head out to the danger zone! On every corner you will see the developers humor integrated into the game, great!

The developer, Simon Roth, updates regularly and is very transparent in his development and progress. The game still has some issues, but given the alpha state, it is already pretty playable. Bugs are hotfixed and the support for Linux is actively supported. I, for one, am really looking forward to the 1.0 release.

Update:

Release 1.0 just happened at this game is now packed with missions and voice overs and even more extremly detailed simulated entities. Also more content is promised.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082960318', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 3126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1607188016}
review:
L'idea di fondo non è male. Peccato che sia ingiocabile. Innanzitutto va in crash abbastanza spesso, poi dopo una partenza in cui le cose funzionano, subentra l'anarchia e gli ordini di costruzione vengono costantemente ignorati, finchè l'equipaggio muore, per un motivo o per l'altro. Non esiste nemmeno un livello di difficoltà impostabile, quindi te lo becchi così com'è o niente.
Insomma, è una delusione e una brutta imitazione di Space Colony, più vecchio di 15anni, ma divertente e giocabilissimo.
C'è un sacco da migliorare, e per ora nessun aggiornamento che abbia sistemato nulla di quello che realmente non funziona.....

author: {'steamid': '76561198060802080', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1589, 'last_played': 1528989626}
review:
I *LOVE* this game.  

The improvements that are made in each monthly update, have been a great and very consistantly steady progression. 

[b]Early Access:[/b]

If you used to be an Early Access believer but then had bad experiences that caused you to lose the faith, this game is a great one to help get that feeling back again. If feels pretty nice to belive in a game and actually have the developer live up to those hopes we have for what it could be next month, and then the next and so on. I feel like it's getting harder to find Early Access experiences where that still happens. I am SO glad I got this game. It's worth it for the regained trust in Early Access games alone.

[b]Linux Support:[/b]

I really appreciate the Linux support. Recent Example: The linux version had an important issue with it when it was released yesterday. We mentioned it to Simon and he had it fixed within 24hours. 

I have other games in my library, written by large teams, that have a much larger linux base asking for fixes, which are still basically unplayable (for linux and mac users, anyway) many months later. I would say I wish Simon was working for those guys so some of my other games would get this level of care as well, but I'm actually quite glad he's working on Maia because this game really deserves to have a developer working on it that really cares.

[b]Communication:[/b]

I highly recommend checking out the discussion pages as well as his website. He has been really great at working with the player base to make sure the updates contain the fixes that we care about the most and he is very transparent with what he is working on next, so you never have to guess if the thing you care about is something he is already working on or not.

[b]Is it finished?[/b]

Nooooo... Don't be confused about that, it is Early Access (Currently at 0.59 as I'm writing this review). There are lots of things he is still working on and little oddities that he doesn't like.  You will still have frustrating little moments watching your colonists do something rediculous that gets them killed now and then. The difference is that after watching the update progressions up to this point, I can now just laugh when those silly things happen, knowing that, in a few updates they won't be happening anymore.  (Which is unfortunately not something I can say for quite a few of the other games I own).

author: {'steamid': '76561198005400363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1207, 'last_played': 1634782200}
review:
Maia is an intelligent, engaging, darkly humourous game. The overall feel is an enjoyable blend of contemporary sci-fi and 70s retro. It's a base management/survival sim that takes healthy splashes of inspiration from games like The Sims, Dungeon Keeper and Evil Genius. It's rich in character; touches like colonist-created, programmatically generated music and haiku, and colonist skillsets like cat appeasement and lukewarm tea brewing, add an undeniably charming flavour to the game.

In action, it's a constant, remarkably challenging exercise in staving off disaster, whether caused by your colonists' stupidity, the environment's general malice, your own ineptitude at the sheer complexity of colony management - or, admittedly, the occasional bug, as the game is still very much a work in progress. That complexity is both one of the game's biggest selling points, and one of its biggest hurdles; the sheer intricacy of the simulation's modelling gives the game enormous depth - if you can navigate your way up the remarkably steep learning curve.

The game discards many of the usual crutches of simulation and management games. The inability to directly control your colonists certainly adds to the challenge, making the gameplay experience more one of orchestration than direct management; likewise the lack of a comprehensive, point-by-point UI - beyond the basics, the stats and status of your base and colonists are communicated more by visual and audio cues than direct notifications. The overall sensation is one of trying to conduct an orchestra comprised largely of simpletons, playing music utterly unfamiliar to you, where a quarter of the instruments are invisible, another inaudible, and nobody thought to bring any sheet music. It's unashamedly difficult, but deeply satisfying one you manage to get a handle on things.

The game is absolutely still a work in progress, but with enormous promise. The developer, Simon Roth, is active and engaged, and calling him deeply deeply invested would be an understatement. I look forward to watching it grow and flourish towards full release. Highly recommended for anyone who enjoys sci-fi, has a penchant for micro-management, and is perhaps just a bit of a masochist.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973546137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1541470843}
review:
Review as of November 24th 2016, version .59 (invasion update), 5 hours of play time:

I've had my eye on this game for awhile and decided to take the plunge. However, this game is still in a state where it requires testers more than players. The base gameplay is still too buggy and unbalanced to provide much enjoyment, although I can anticipate having a great deal of fun with Maia when it is further along.

I will update this review from time to time as the game develops.

Update October 21rd 2016, version .64

My prime problem still exists, in that the colonists feel wooden and dumb. They do things slowly and often ignore survival-critical tasks. It seems like the AI gets gummed up quickly. From the opening of the game, just attempting to set up the initial base, it feels like you need to follow a set script of actions to be successful. It doesn't feel like there's any room for individual preference or direction.

Update November 5th 2018, version .68

Checked back in for a bit over an hour's worth, two years after my last look. Not much has changed on the surface. The colonists are still slow and very dumb, leaving critical tasks unattended. The player recieves practically no information about what is needed in a reactive way (there is a barebones training missions now, which helped a little, but the gameplay is still quite bad). The one positive change I noticed was that food and water needs seem to come less often, so that rather than being dumb and starving fast your colonists are dumb and starve slowly. 

After two years and this little progress on the base gameplay, I don't imagine I'll bother checking in again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965379309', 'num_games_owned': 263, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1611718497}
review:
I didn't manage to get much time on this game due to study taking priority, but from the miniscle amount of time I did get I can say this; it's fun!

The game is a simulation of sorts of trying to colonise an inhospitable planet. There are many dangers present, such as colonist incompetence, your own incompetence (yep! My first play and everyone died of hypothermia), planetary dangers (earthquakes), equipment failures, solar flares/radiation. A bit like a Sim-something game, scaled down and focused on the premise of colonising - well okay, similar in scope to "The Sims", but Mars! 

Colonists all have their own personalities and skillsets, and as such are more/less suited for particular tasks. Getting a random song or poem from one is a charming touch.

It is a very interesting game, and one that is gaining more depth and complexity as time goes on. It may be early-access alpha level, but the game already has more than enough in it to entertain for hours; I can see myself getting lost in it easily.

The developer is incredibly active, both on social media, as well as posting a game changelog on their website and in the games news section on Steam. Seriously, check out the news section! They are very passionate about their game, and this shows heavily in playing it.


If you like the idea or premise behind "The Sims" but didn't like the mundane setting of it, maybe this will tickle your fancy?

Oh and did I mention it has humour?

author: {'steamid': '76561197972309711', 'num_games_owned': 850, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1423, 'last_played': 1585430897}
review:
I've been struggling to reach a stable point with a colony for a long time with Maia, preventing death from starvation, exhausation or stupidity before you can establish a sustainable base seems extremely challenging. It was during one of these frustrating attemps that I stumbled upon the secret backstory to Maia.

This isn't a game about society's elite heading into the stars to colonise new and interesting planets. This is a society's eugenics program in action. They have rounded up all of the lazy, the stupid, and the generally incompetent and shipped them off to some godforsaken planet with just enough resources to survive. They figured it was more humane than outright execution.

So bear this in mind when playing Maia, whenever you start screaming at the colonists to stop running from room to room staring at walls and go build that *******! solar array before they freeze to death, just relax and remember that you're the last hope of these plucky underdogs that have been abandoned by their society.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065618648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2906, 'last_played': 1601537216}
review:
I've been playing this game since 2016, have talked with the developer and this is my conclusion.
This Game has gone nowhere, will go nowhere. I was initially very interested in its development and enjoyed the style of development however the game suffered from being very slow, boring and pointless and has gone in the direction of being bug ridden slow, boring and pointless.

Having comeback to the game to see what interesting and exciting things have happened I come to see initially working features buggy, colonists refusing to use the hundreds of litres of water to satiate themselves, colonists being trapped in wide open spaces and crying themselves to death, 12 colonists struggling to focus on building 4 things over 5-10 minutes for seemingly no reason.

As it is now you have to baby every single member of your colonization, built a lamp within a few metres of a wall ? I'm afraid that's a death trap. Watch for the first half an hour as your colonists eagerly swarm around the colony being productive, mourn as they cruelly become suicidal morons bent on boring you to death. Perhaps your interested in the challenging task of guiding a group of mentally deficient individuals colonization attempt of an alien planet ? Look elsewhere, When one colonist dies he is soon replaced by another, the goal of the game is to survive building a base with a seemingly unlimited amount of expendable manpower, research a meaningless tech tree as everything that means anything is available at the start of the game. Wildlife always dies when shot at, morons are cheap and unlimited and whilst the idea that a bathroom might cost me the lives of 3 brave explorers would normally be hilarious its often a joke that takes half an hour to get to the punchline.

No matter what you want there is something somewhere else and at the current price of 
35 AUD you can pay practically the same thing and actually get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976767744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3309, 'last_played': 1518282132}
review:
This game should, someday, be great. Currently, the AI is so buggy it is hard to actually play, with colonists dying from starvation because they've managed to build a hydroponic carrot that somehow blocks the way out of the room, or a room with no doors, or simply standing in the airlock until they run out of air - I've had all of these happen. That said, updates happen, content is added, and the game is in such better shape now than a year ago that I feel comfortable giving a thumbs-up.

UPDATE: Game is now in a much better state than when I posted this originally. Crashes happen less often, and colonists do a LOT less stupid stuff. It's still quite possible to build them into a corner they can't get out of, but at least if you then tell them to unbuild said item, they do it instead of dying. Speaking of dying, if you have someone close-by, there's a good chance that dumb deaths can be brought back! Of course they still need a trip to the med bay, but at least they aren't, you know, corpsed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055635588', 'num_games_owned': 377, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 793, 'last_played': 1598468264}
review:
Reviewed: Alpha 0.58 - 16th Oct 2016

TL;DR
Don't buy it until the AI/pathfinding got a lot better, or it's on sale for <10 USD.
It has a lot of potential, the core elements are there, and there are some interesting gimmicks but it needs to get better to be enjoyable IMHO.

---------
I WANT TO BELIEVE *insert X-files joke here*
I'm a sucker for survival/build-up games (logging ~1500 hrs in Space Enginners alone) and I've been watching & wishlisting this title for two years now.
Infrequently I've been visiting the store page of this title but was always repelled by the mixed reviews, their contents and reasons.
But this weekend was a 50% off special, so 'out of boredom' I finally picked it up, especially since in version Alpha 0.58 "AI has been tremendiously overhauled and improved".

I like the aspect that you do not directly control your crew in this game, you do have control over the IMP humanoid-bots and repair-bots, but you do not specifically tell your crew what they're doing when.
That's good in my books.
But it's not good if crew-members get stuck in the middle of a Workbench, or behind walls or in Atmosphere Generators. Also not good is when crewmembers infrequently dying of dehydration, even though there's like three half-full water-tanks to drink from.

What this game needs is an overhaul of the UIX; when every ~20 seconds a full-screen displayed warning been thrown into your face - stealing the focus - bcause your veggie-farms needing to be pitched, you're slowly turning into the infamous meme of fire-breathing Pepe, yelling at your monitor.

Frequently I had to abandon & restart my early-games, because of key crew-members being stuck, trapped or clipping into stuff. Like, remotely controlling a repair-bot. it's easily to drive it through walls, but you'll never get it back out of there, being stuck. you can't disassemble it because your crew-members can't reach it. Also frequently you're giving build orders (for outside placed Wind-Turbines or Solarpanels) and your crew-members aren't building them, even though all prerequsites are met.

Unfortunately I haven't gotten too far, since my people turned after a longer game frequently into lemmings, throwing themselves into the arms of death due to starvation and/or dehydration despite an abundance of available food and water.

It's also lacking are more - "general oversight" in terms of a grid's power needs/utilization and easier indicators what your crewmember is needing/lacking. after all they got voices, so they could tell you. (No they don't tell you when they're dehydrating and about to keel over).

This being an Early Access title, you're hereby warned. I can see where this game is going with its potential. The dev team is a small one with three on-site staff and three external contractors, which explains why their progress is so slow, especially considering the complexity and intricacies of this type of games; and it seems they developed their own engine for this, instead of using a middleware like UNITY.

VERDICT: buy when <10 USD or when AI/pathfinding has drastically improved. Until then; No.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002053619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1480458313}
review:
I like an idea, (I would not buy it otherwise) but at this moment I would advice against buying this game.

Technically it is like old good dungeonkeeper but in space. The problem is, controls are so awkward that they turn the game in to the pain to play.

Developers should also consider removing that "digital noise" filter from the game (or at least have an option to turn it off) because it really does not add any value to the game - it just tires your eyes and makes You wish to turn the game off within first 10 minutes of gameplay.

The general guideline is that while games should provide some kind of challage to be interesting that challange should not be in form of bugs and awfull user interface but in a good AI, or challenging story instead.

Personally - I was blasted away by the fact that I was somehow removing whole parts of base with just a single click instantly or placing doors randomly without a chance to cancel such "design errors".

I faced these issues at the time I did this review. These might be resolved some time later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006666007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 9873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3404, 'last_played': 1675802573}
review:
Portential ist da, aber mit der Umsetzung hapert es. Momentan ist vor allem Frust angesagt. Es gibt genau 2 Möglichkeiten, wie das Spiel beendet werden kann. Entweder verhungern oder erfrieren.
Wenn eine Mission auf einem anderen Planeten in der realität stattfindet und dann so schlecht vorbereitet wäre (weder genug Nahrung noch warme Kleidung) dann würde der Missionsplaner im Knast landen! Liebe entwickler, das muss doch besser gehen.
Irgendwann hören die Missionsteilnehmer auf, sinnvoll zu agieren. Statt das dringend benötigte Baumaterial herzustellen, um die  verd... Heizung zu bauen, stehen sie frierend am kältesten Ort der Basis. Die Imps rennen herum wie scheue Hühner, fangen an zu buddeln um dann plötzlich umzudrehen, ins Lager zu rennen dort herumzustehen und dann wieder urplötzlich loszubuddeln. Welche Machine macht so was ?

Seit 2 Jaher wird dem Spiel ein Alphastatus zugesprochen, aber im Kern hat sich nicht viel getan. Die Spielmechanik ist nur geringfügig weiterentwickelt worden. Dabei könnte das durchaus ein gigantisches Spiel werden.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083948263', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1676928465}
review:
Bought this game knowing it is in development. What I read about it appealed to me - especially simulation parts and hard sci-fi approach. It certainly delivers on these terms, and developer has added more and more interesting sim aspects to the game in last year of development. I am also updating this review as it will be released in upcoming hours.

First, good stuff - game feels very unique and fun to play if you like micro simulation games with elements of strategy and reaction. While atmosphere set for this is a bit dark and gloomy, how events unfold and you as invisible manager react to it is entirely up to you. It is worth to recognize you will kill everybody in first few runs, although game has certainly improved in educating player trough tutorial how to make survival a first priority. If you manage to understand potential consequences of actions, ins and outs, it is quite smooth sailing and  beating challenges feel earned, As sound production geek I love work done on sound. I certanly can only praise simulation aspects of the game, also that author explains how they work behind features (if you follow him on Twitter). In last version before official stable release I have some issues or better say ideas for improvements regarding UI, but overall it is easy to digest and react to game events. Game has also no hands hold approach, however descriptions of devices, events, messages are verbose enough in my opinion to give you enough hints what's going on.

I can recommend game for sci-fi fans easily. It tries to marry management sim approach with interesting sci-fi simulation elements, and it mostly works and it is very interesting to experiment and mock about. Atmospheric (especially good work on sound) and visually good looking enough too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024978074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1674853860}
review:
[h1]Disclaimers[/h1]
[list]
    [*]I backed this game on Kickstarter
    [*]I haven’t played a huge amount (mainly due to ancient GPU issues), but watched many hours of Maia Twitch dev streams
    [*]I’m currently a patron of the developer (Simon Roth) at [url=https://www.patreon.com/simoroth]https://www.patreon.com/simoroth[/url]
[/list]

[i]Do you like science-fiction?[/i]
[i]Do you like classic god/sim games?[/i]
[i]Are you looking for something unique, different & challenging?[/i]

[i]If so, read on...[/i]

[h1]My Introduction to Maia[/h1]
I first became aware of Maia back in 2012 when Kickstarter was in full swing. The unusual sci-fi aesthetics and interesting vision are what initially attracted me, and I continue to be impressed by how driven the developer is.
This is a god game with subtle challenges underneath. Challenges which may even change the way you view game design in general afterwards.

[h1]Maia, the HUD & Gameplay[/h1]
Why even mention the HUD? Well, rather than take the approach of giving the player an easy categorised spreadsheet list of all the various variables/states in the game via large sprawling HUD panels, Maia chooses to integrate much of that as items/signals visually within the world itself. It is this world which you'll spend most of your time interacting with as you expand your base, build machinery, craft autonomous robots, and battle the various hardships that colonising a harsh alien landscape requires.

This difference in game design approach isn’t for everyone, and can force the more casual gamer to rage, but therein lies the treat for those who persevere. Creating a large self-sustaining tech-enabled [spoiler]nuclear fusion powered[/spoiler] colony from a few desperate souls is really satisfying, and you’ll end up more attached to it than just about any other god/sim game out there.

Sure, it does take some time to understand how the world works, and there are some quirks which may be bugs (it is in Early Access currently), but it makes for such a refreshing change from the sea of clone and asset store created games currently on sale.

[h1]Sound & Model Design[/h1]
As a fan of both the 80’s culture and electronic music in general, the general model design and music/effects are really top notch for a small studio, and thus deserve a special mention. I had flashbacks of Vangelis’ Blade Runner combined with Space 1999 and it’s a perfect fit for this type of game in my opinion.
If we’re lucky, we’ll see a Maia soundtrack release at some point.

[h1]Bugs & Developer Commitment[/h1]
For a game initially Kickstarted in 2012/2013, you’d be quite right to question when the release would be, especially as we’re now approaching 2017.
Thankfully, unlike many other games that become abandonware, the Maia build is still being actively updated with fixes and new content.
To give an example, I've recently seen the developer having to put in extraordinary work to fix problems for Linux users which were not caused by the game, but GPU drivers. I also heard they spent a huge amount of time trying to make the game run on older Intel drivers. These particular issues are also somewhat to blame for the slip in release dates.
That's commitment you don't see from AAA devs, let alone an indie dev.

You can clearly tell that this is a passion project, which more than likely means that development will continue for some considerable time irrespective of version numbering. Not only that, but the developer is extremely technically skilled, having written the actual game engine itself that drives Maia.

If I had any critisim of the developer, it would be the heavy reliance on Steam Early Access, but then this is more a business issue rather than anything else, and hopefully the future will be a bit brighter after the recent Steam changes and tweaked business models from lessons learned.

[h1]More Than Just Maia[/h1]
If you're anything like me, and have an interest in what's under-the-hood, you may be surprised to hear that the developer seems very keen to engage in that kind of discussion.

I've watched a dev twitch stream where a crash occurred. The dev then took viewers through code explaining a sizable amount, making a change, recompiling the game source, and playing the new revision. I don't think I've ever seen that kind of open engagement from a developer before.
See for yourself: [url=https://www.twitch.tv/simoroth]https://www.twitch.tv/simoroth[/url]

On top of that, they’ve also provided a publicly accessible site showing the code changes committed to the project:
[url=https://dev.maiagame.com/]https://dev.maiagame.com/[/url]
Again, which other developer does this?!

[h1]To Summarise[/h1]
If you want a new experience and appreciate the different approach Maia takes, then you will, I’m sure, see the beauty behind this one-of-a-kind labour of love.

Edit (Feb 2017): The most recent version of the game, 0.60 has lava (seen in original kickstarter art), and many, many fixes. In fact, the game has been fixed/tweaked in a huge number of places over subsequent updates such that it's hard to find any glaring issues. Very happy to see this and very impressed at the continued commitment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033125179', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2264, 'last_played': 1517793962}
review: I want to like this game.  I have been trying to like this game for over a year.  But WTF?  This is one of the most frustrating games I have ever played.  It has so much potential but the AI is just absolutely terrible.  Past terrible, it actually makes me angry just how dumb it is.  The colonists just run around doing whatever, but almost never what they need to be doing.  People starve, freeze, die of dehydration, but won't build what they need to live.  Argh...

author: {'steamid': '76561197972940143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1476315328}
review:
So you're colonists can die within the first couple of minutes of the game and you don't even know why... The dev (only 1 I believe) creating this is an idiot. I listened to a podcast he did and while I agree, I don't want to be spoonfed every detail... you could at least give me a chance to figure out what's going on... The tutorial doesn't cover anything, just makes sarcastic remarks and shows basic keystrokes but doesn't explain what anything actually does. There is no pause button, meaning you can't hit pause and look at your base to find out what to do next. Especially important at the beginning of the game. So as of right now, the game is about starting a new game, failing within minutes, and restarting a new game. While I like the concept of starting over with more info to do a better job the second time I hardly even have time to find out what my mistakes were. 

Edit: The dev is a Genius/Idiot, and I am empathetic as I am similar. He has built something so complex with actual science behind each piece. An intimate knowledge of electricity is something i've seen so far. So the idiot part, the implementation, the part where you connect with real people. As I've said there is so much lacking here. For one a pause button, but after writing this I realized there is no save. Supposedly there is a quicksave and quickload but it doesn't work. So EVERY time you load the game you're looking at starting a new game. So back to the genius/idiot point. He's done so well in the implementation of certain points of the game, however other parts make it almost broken. 

I will continue to update this review untill it is comprehensive on the good/bad points of the game... (Written below, in under FINAL EDIT: I have stopped rewievewing this after I receieved a refund. I can't very well continue a review if I'm not able to test certain aspects of the game. The review will stay 'as is' and incomplete. Poetic? I think so, this game has been in early access for a long time now. As my last entry edit, which I wasn't going to mention, the dev admits to spending around a year working to make the game compatible with old graphics cards. This is why I can't find myself to remove the genius/idiot part of the review. You could possibly replace the 'idiot' comment with inexperience, however in the same podcast he mentions the old graphics cards he touts all the projects he's worked on. Being fully aware of what you are buying into with Early Access, I don't forsee my troubles being fixed anytime soon if ever. So there you have it, an incomplete review of an incomplete game. (See dice roll below))



Plusses:
+++ A genuine real life face for every colonist
++ The plants have energy value in joules (Thank you Mr. Newton)

Minuses:
--- Everyone died in the "TUTORIAL"...
--- One mission "Cassiopeia" says you have 45 minutes until more colonists arrive, it's more like 3-5 minutes

Explanation: Ok so on top of everything else the AI is messed up beyond reproach, the I.M.P. robots will rush to make a door when things like an 'atmosphere creator' is in need of building, or a space heater has been qued when everyone is freezing. They seem to make wind generators at a fair pace but still neglect other objects needed that an alarm is buzzing at you about. It comes down to timing. The 'game' doesn't give you enough time to correct any potential problems before colonists die from them. Say hypothermia. I put up the space heaters but no one is building them. If a colonist is dying of freezing you would think that would be a priority. 

The theme is based around not being spoon-fed answers by your user-interface. You get emails from the colonists asking what they want. The problem is by the time you read them they are dead from whatever it was they wrote about. I have no idea what the dev is thinking...

Sorry, I wanted to like this but I wouldn't suggest buying even at half price...

Final Edit: I ultimately asked for and receieved a refund for Maia, I'm leaving the review as it was at the time of refund. The only things I will add are that I was fully aware of the F5 and F9 save/load, they did not work. I was not aware of the space button to pause, though I don't think it would have helped. Perhaps my machine is running the game too fast for some reason because when I see videos the colonists and imps are moving about half the speed they moved when I played. Events and emails happened so fast I couldn't read them fast enough and often the event (say a meteor-strike or death by hypothermia) happened as I was reading the in game emails. I'd also like to say I don't think this is a cash grab like some other early acess title's. The dev seems very passionate about it and is hands on updating often. Since I receieved a refund this review will remain incomplete and unchanged from here on. Good luck to dev(s) and  good luck on the dice roll anyone takes when they buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979947026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3173, 'last_played': 1543242921}
review:
A rich and detailed interplanetary colonization game that is as difficult as it is enjoyable. Start a colony from scratch with just enough to survive. Manage expanding the base with the complex energy, water, and oxygen needs of both the colonists and base itself. Perform vasts amounts of research (that the colonists decide on, not the player, which actually makes the game more interesting and unpredictable) that improve every aspect of the base, colonists, and robotics that help around the colony. And that's barely scratching the surface!

Don't let the Early Access scare you, Simon Roth and Machine Studios are one of the few that actually get it right. They put out constant updates in content and are qutie open with the community across social media. It's not hard to find out what's new, what's coming next, and what they have planned for the future.

I would STRONGLY recommend this game and look forward to see everything that they add to it in the future.

review: I was really looking forward to playing MAIA as I have been following it for a long time now.  After reading some positive reviews I thought I would give it a shot.  Unfortunately there are still many issues with the game and I cannot recommend it to anyone, even if its on sale.  One major problem would be with the AI.  The workers and robots  are so slow to respond and complete tasks that I alsways died from freezing.  All I needed to stop freezing is to build a workshop, wind generator (outside) and some wall heaters but this is almost impossible to complete because the workers refuse to complete the tasks or are too slow to complete anything.  Another problem would be the UI, there is no icons or buttons to show you have much power/water/food you have.  Instead you get emails after each day to update you with the amounts??  I understand this game is Early Access but it has been here about three years now, so I was expecting further progress.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971298136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1481958409}
review:
First, let me say, it does have great progress so far, and comming along.  I think more people should support it, that said ...

So I went on a mission, where the mission items were timed (I really hate to be pushed on timers, not fun at all). But ok, not a huge deal.  Built what I needed to, down to 5 mins, put some items down, including the main mission item – a communications antenna.  Some people were doing nothing, and eventually started building.  Seems they didn’t get the memo that communications was the next mission item, so they left it last.  1.5 minutes left, communications still pending, people are walking around, and hugging, etc., and the timer is ticking away.  It eventually reaches 0, mission failed, and the colonists don’t give a damn, lol. 

Ok, I think I put down too many items at once, so I did it a bit more controlled. There’s very little room for error, as you have to think minutes ahead (not seconds). Made it to the next mission item – also timed (argh). Ok, so started to clear an area.  Colonists are now complaining about needing sleep, and food, but the medical center and beds is the top priority?  I guess it is in case they die from hunger while working as slaves to build while starving to death because the timer doesn't have any wiggle room. I also needed more power, built another wind generator, then started the medical building, laid out the door, and 3 medical beds.  After 1-2 minutes, a colonist finally shows up to build it, and the door, and leaves the beds and takes off.  Ok, no problem, 1.5 minutes left, let’s see if anyone comes to finish the beds.  Timer runs out, mission failed, colonists don’t give a damn (again – 3 beds was the mission item), lol.

Cool, you can control the robots in first person view. After clicking the mouse button, I thought the robot pooped/regurgitated something awful. Oh ok, just the rocks I guess it collected? Not a bad thing, just funny. ;)

You can right-click to de-select the active action under your cursor when building items. You can also right-click to destroy a building without warning (oops). Costs time and materials to rebuild what was destroyed in a fraction of a second.  Had to reload the game (on timers after all, no room for error).

In the middle of all this, while building, the game takes control and throws the camera over to the incoming colonists.  I DON’T CARE, I saw the message already, let me finish what I was doing.  Now I don’t even know where I was, must scroll back – yet, on the way, the camera pulls me to something else. :/

Keep getting a warning the storage room is getting cold.  You can now hover over rooms to see their temperatures. I built atmospheric generators to help (one per room), and it helps, but I found out from watching a video that you only need space heaters in other places.  How much do they output though, or how much power is required? Doesn’t say.  I can see the temperatures in rooms rising now.  Stats are getting better, but still a bit poor list of stats, still difficult to see what’s really going on around the base.

It also crashed a few times in a way that made the cursor disappear.  Make sure to save often.

Things it needs:
1. Much better AI (perhaps even mission focused). Enough hanky panky, get back to work!
2. A priority system, so you can better queue up what needs to get built first.
3. Much better stat reporting on the items (especially generator outputs for one). If there is a warning a room is cold, at least show room stats also.
4. Status icons you can click to quickly bring you to the events/issues. DONT FORCE MY CAMERA - I might be in the middle of something. 
5. Automated smelter, or show an icon when it is waiting, or done. Don't turn this into a space focused Farmville game, lol.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=odBDAcOEKuI
6. Fix building bugs (see comments), random crashes (rare), and errors restarting missions (always have to restart the game).
7. Built hydroponics for food, but people are still dying from starvation? lol This needs to be fixed. If I'm missing something, then that should be in my notifications. ;)
8. No idea what anything does, or why I need it, nor how many I need to make.  There are details when selecting items to build, but no text describing what it is for.  Makes it a bit tedious to keep looking up what things are for, and why. For example, until I watched a video, I had no idea space heaters could be used instead of atmospheric generators.  I thought I needed a generator in every room.

I'll keep an eye on these issues and update the review as the game progresses.  I think it is a great game to support, but I had to give a thumbs down until a lot of issues are ironed out. I'm half afraid sometimes to play it in fear I forget to save and it crashes. ;) Perhaps Auto-save is needed at an internval I can specify.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033419089', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1125, 'last_played': 1513909875}
review:
Fantastic game despite not being playable for any prolonged period in its current state. The game is constantly improving with changes having positive impact and is responsive to player feedback. Can't really ask for more from a game in Alpha.

Maia is basically a base management game with survival elements and will be even better once more content is added and the bugs ironed out. At present there are actually a surprisingly low number of bugs but the main one that gets me everytime is the deaths from your colonists just deciding to stop moving and eventually dehydrate or starve (whichever comes first). This wouldn't be a problem if there wasn't a cap on the number of colonists meaning they don't get replaced. Eventually everyone will be dead and with nobody replaced the base can't get bigger as more people would be required. 

For an early access game it's a good problem to have as it will be fixed eventually. General gameplay is still really fun and oddly stable. I would recommend this game to anybody that can overllok bugs at this stage and wants to try iterations of build orders etc to try to get a perfect base. Just be aware that you will fail regardless of how well you plan at this stage.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969594811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1493946326}
review:
It's not done yet, but I come back every few builds to see very impressive progress. Major patches are more or less monthly, and each one adds some promising feature or refinement.

The simulation is very detailed, whichc creates enjoyable emergent gameplay, but can also lead to some frustration when you run into the areas of the game that aren't finished yet. All of your colonists sweating themselves to death (literally), that sort of thing.

The humour is solid, of the British understated sort. The haikus are particularly enjoyable.

I'm very much looking forward to the upcoming campaign, and the game reaching a solid beta footing. This is a game which is being made right, not fast, and it looks like it will be worth the wait.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053257369', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 890, 'last_played': 1488756494}
review:
Update:

With 0.59  Maia has had a lot of content , fixs and tweaks - really making it feel more and more like a decent budget AAA game rather then a indie. I mean, its not there yet, but Maia's pretty darn ambisious, so its amazing how far its come.
I think the key to if you will enjoy Maia or not is if your prepared to learn and replay a lot. While initially it feels like "scifi dungeon keeper", the game is a lot less forgiving. You have to balance life essentials like heat,power,atmosphere before you even get to food and drink. Each time you play - and your colonists all die horribly - you tend to learn a bit more for next time.
The game also, despite being early access, has a lot of content already, with various scenarios as well as free exploration. So with these too things in mind, its certainly not a game to be used up quickly.

The downloads/limitations of the current 0.59 state of the game are mostly UI related, as well as some AI issues with colonists build priority's. Its perfectly possible for them to build themselves into a room with no doors - so you better hope another colonist will decide to build a door before they die or starvation/dehydration.

Despite this, its a game I definitely recommend for sci-fi fans with patience, and a desire for a reasonably realistic "let me set up a base on a unexplored alien world" game.


-----------

Previous review (Sept 13):

Maia is already a great expirence, with even more great potential.
It feels sort of like dungeon keeper meets star-trek with bits of dwarf fortress chucked in too. Its ambitions are big, but its pulling them all of pretty good so far. Anyone that yearns to build bases on alien worlds really should check this game out.

Additionally;

Please don't dismiss this game from the (very recent) negative score. A lot of the negative reviews are over a year old.
Anyone that gave it a go earlier, Id recomend trying a more recent version too, its been refined A LOT over the last few months.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994049999', 'num_games_owned': 1296, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1469462876}
review:
Unless you really like frustration and lack of information as to why things aren't working, I'd steer clear of this for now.

Maia's concept basically takes Dwarf Fortress and puts it into space, on another planet.  That's both a good and a bad thing.

Like DF, you decide what needs to get done, and the colonists go off and do that on their own, with no direct control.  Unlike DF, if a colonist is unable to do something, you don't actually get any sort of message as to why — it just doesn't get done.

Like DF, it's being built by a solo developer, who is focusing way more on adding new features than on fixing bugs, even old or important ones.  Unlike DF, those bugs aren't things like "military training isn't working" — they're game-breaking things like "none of my colonists will go outside to make a wind turbine to generate power for the atmosphere generators, so they all die due to lack of oxygen".

Even once you get through the first few steps and get a real colony going, it's only a matter of time before colonists just up and decide they can't do some critical thing and they'd all prefer to die, and you don't get any indication why.

My suggestion to the developer would be: Even if it's not part of your vision on how the final game will look — for now, give us some debugging tools!  Even if they're off by default, we need some way to show us what our colonists are up to, what tasks need doing, why they aren't being done, how priorities work, etc.  For one, it's just too frustrating to play without those right now; and two, they would enable us to give you actually helpful bug reports, instead of just vague statements like "nobody would go outside so they all died".

Sadly, my experience playing Maia for several hours today was basically the same as my experience back in 2014.  A ton of stuff has been added, but the game feels exactly as inscrutable and unplayable now as it did back then.  I love the concept, I hope it becomes a great game someday, and I appreciate the difficulties a solo developer faces on a project of this size, but I can't base a review on hope and speculation.

material is magically turned into portable solar panels,.

Placement:
Sometimes I cannot remove room blocks, they light up but when I try to cancel them they won't go away. New game...


Construction:
Seems they like to construct solar panels more than they like to construct the windmills, the flare happens nearly immidiatly at random game and they all die because of power problems even though I have instructed them to build windmills and there is sufficient material left.

Pace:
Time feel its a litle bit fast, when I have made up my mind of where I want everything and instructed to robot to make room for base they have already died in some way, either lack of air or freezing to death.

As long as the devs keep updating it frequently, you can't really not reccomend the game, though I do have an issue, here's how my most recent run went.

>Get space heaters and shit, charge, etc
>Nobody is making food.exe
>why the...

>This didn't happen before
>People run out of food before they run out of water
>Check food maker-thing, nobody is using it
>40% of the colonist population dies from starvation instantly
>ragequit.exe
>logic could not be found

So long as it works. I reccomend getting it on sale or waiting a little bit longer.

Hour 1: My colonists are building an atmosphere generator and a work bench. Along with wind turbines. Things are going well

Hour 2: Two of my colonists got stuck in the hydroponics room they built themselves into...

Hour 3: Those same colonists died from hypothermia...

Day 6: BEEP BEEP BEEP! WARNING: TEMPERATURE LOW IN..........HYDROPONICS. 

GOD DAMN IT, I KNOW! THE COLONISTS HAVEN'T DECONSTRUCTED THE DAMN DOOR YET! WE'VE RAN OUT OF FOOD BEFORE WE'VE RAN OUT OF WATER, AND THEY'RE ALL GOING TO DIE!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005572955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 6673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4052, 'last_played': 1695648870}
review:
Been a year that I last wrote something about this game, and considering that the updates for the game come frequently, I think it's time to update the review as well.

Last year I called it "playable". This year I can actually call it entertaining. What's most entertaining, at least for me, is that the colonists are actually very human. Allow me to explain.

In most games, you have people that feel more like worker drones. They will go from place to place, build, mine, craft, sleep, get hurt, go to the medic bay, build, mine, craft... The "people" here feel actually like people. And they don't want to be treated like worker drones. They get stressed out if all they do is build and work. 

Of course the idea that people do something aside working isn't new. But this is I think the first game that actually models "stress". I wonder why this isn't a sales argument, but I was actually happily surprised when I noticed this! 

You start out with 4 colonists and you can of course make them work, work and work. But don't be surprised if they get really burned out very, very quickly. And that means that accidents will happen, that they get depressed, and that they will simply not really want to work anymore. They start making bad decisions, they start to mess up priorities. And they'll start to complain. Subtle at first, and eventually they'll be anything but subtle. Ever heard of "quitting on the inside"? That's what they do. If only because they can't actually quit, being stuck on an alien planet. They'll just get sick a lot, make snide comments in the emails they send you, complain about their coworkers and actually be hostile to them, work the bare minimum...

A bug? No, probably not. Because if I lower the work load, if I add "stress relievers", if I add more people to spread out the work, suddenly they start to behave "normal" again.

This is actually pretty amazing. I have never encountered this depth of AI in any other game.

Aside of this, yes, there's still a long, long road ahead of them. They now added "missions" to the already existing sandbox game where you get more or less easy tasks to fulfill within a given time. Still in need of some tweaking and balancing, IMO. The alien fauna still doesn't quite have as much of an impact as I'd have hoped it would (basically the alien animals are a backdrop and don't interact much with your base). The balancing in general still needs work, it's VERY hard to start out but if you survive the first 10 days it becomes pretty much a cakewalk, a slow, steady increase in "demand" from the colonists would be great here. And there's still not that much to "do", so to speak. Research now works pretty well, but after about a dozen or so research topcs have been checked off the list, you're done with that, too. 

So we're still not looking at much of an "endgame" to to speak, and I still hope that we'll eventually see some sort of "campaign mode" or something that's more than the sandbox (plus the "guided sandbox" callsed missions). 

It's not done yet. But with very frequents updates (about one large update per month), we're looking at a game that not only gets active development but one that actually improves with every update. Many Early Access games "break" at some point and start getting worse, losing or throwing away the reason you bought it for. So far, Maia avoided this fate. The things that get added make sense and add depth to the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022041111', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1705961864}
review:
I've been following this game for some time and when is came onto Early Access I was very excited by the concept. However since then I have become a bit disillusioned with it. But I will provide a fair judgement of it in its current state and the developers. 

The game does have amazing charm, almost all the tech in the game is not far from what we have now and this gives the game a fantastic sense of realism. Even the charecters are dressed to match what you would expect and the game has a fantastic sense of humour in the little info pop ups. Base construction is intresting placing rooms and then decorating them freeform does give a great sense of personalisation (beware OCD people out there, trying to place things dead on is a nightmare, I suffered!). The world outside your underground home feels alive in the style it has been done in with various creatures who may pose a challenge to you. And they accompany the various events such as earthquakes that keep the game fresh and intresting. Managing the various resources is also given a sense of realism such as managing air production and flow, heat, food and such and the devices used are, as I've said, realistic in design the type of thing you would see in a building today. Futhermore the game's developers are fairly active and updates are common but nothing really seems to make serious progress forward. 

However this sense of realism is compounded by the fact the game is buggy as hell. I cannot reason the A.I of your people who seeminly act at random if at all. They will often die standing in a room that has no heaters set up yet while the room next door is fully heated. Getting them do to anything is a chore and I have often had people die early on because they take so long constructing the basics. The tutorial is terrible, I thought that all you needed as the atmos gens to sort our heating and the like, but while the tutorial gets you to build one it does not get you build the heaters meaning by the time you realise you really really need to, coupled with the time it takes the A.I to do anything, it might be too late. 
The U.I is not very helpful with nothing immediatly displayed on the screen meaning on your first go you wont even know how much elect, water and such you have until it runs out. I like where the developer is trying to take it however, being able to read your peoples E-mails is a great idea and again adds to the personalisation. But at the moment is fails to give the player what they need. 
The colonists work independent of the player, but sometimes it is needed to force construction of an item or activity and if there is a way to do this I havn't found it. If you need to build a turbine for an emergency power drop, but have other actions already in place your a little screwed. 

All in all the game has a great feel to it and that is why I am reccomending it, to keep and eye on it but not to buy. Previous versions of this game were more enjoyable and to me more stable and that is a shame but hopefully this is due to them implimenting the game proper and this is just a rough patch. As I said a game to follow not to wishlist.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966391335', 'num_games_owned': 913, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1463916409}
review:
The game that never gets finished.
2 and a half years ago it was released as extremely early access pre-alpha on steam, since then it has hardly improved at all and is not even remotely close to being finshed or playable.
Today the game still has many of the same bugs and issues it did when it was released and is still in a barely playable state.
The developer is still working on the game, but at the pace it is going and considering how inexperienced and inefficient the developer still is after all these years, it seems the game will still take another 2-3 years to finish.

Because the idea behind this game is rather interesting and refreshing, and there aren't a whole lot of alternatives, it may be worth checking in on this game again in another 2-3 years. Then again, by then there might be something much better.

So for now, do not buy, not even on sale. It's not even remotely worth it at the moment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045433482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1523825461}
review:
I have been playing this game for 6 hours. Long story short: The concept is fascinating, but the implementation is extremely buggy, and there are bugs you would not expect after 3 years development.

Playing was fun sometimes, but there were lots of extremely frustrating moments. I would recommend to try it though: While I don't think it its worth its money now, I still hope the developer will start thinking "top-down" eventually, leave sound and graphics alone (they are really nice already) and fix the basic stuff that prevents this from being playable.

[list]
 [*] I've managed to play through for more than an hour, but 50 % of launches crash in the first few seconds.
 [*] The UI is not intuitive, but it's easy once you get it.
 [*] Some basic stuff is not working e.g. pathfinding: NPCs run through walls and other obstackes or get stuck
 [*] It is not obvious why a task is not executed (e.g. which resource is missing)
 [*] In one of my games, at some point there was nothing more to do.
 [*] I gave up when all of a sudden both the mouse pointer and lighting failed globally (black screen with just a few icons, unable to do anything)
[/list]

I would strongly suggest getting help from an experienced SW developer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043867560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1529268711}
review:
I don't get it. What's so difficult? I build a workshop. I build a workbench. I place the obejects for a heater and atmospheric device in there. Colonist rn between storage and workshop, eventually die of asphyxiation and/or hypothermia because none of them will build the objects that will keep them alive.

The really infuriating thing? Sometimes they will build them. But they refuse to build a smelter so then when I run out of building materials, I can't get anymore to build the heater in the hydroponics bay so they stop freezing to death just standing around in it......

[EDIT 10th September 2016]

AI Still needs some kind of prioritisation setting or system. If I tell them to build an O2 generator, and an airvent, I expect them to do it, not spend 2-5 days wandering around thinking about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029518965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1561380210}
review:
This could become an awesome game! Once it's finished and here's t he catch, the development is taking way too goddamn long (a common issue with kickstarted games apparently). 

It is understandable that one guy alone cannot move mountains, and what Simon has attempted here is simply awesome, on the other hand as a kickstart contributor i've been waiting for 3 years to play. 

This review is for alpha 0.55 and it is the first one that i managed to keep running for more than 4 h straight. The bugs are plentyfull and diverse, from annoying to game-breaking. 

I am now writing this review after an extended playthrough that i would rate as very enjoyable despite the need for frequent "save-loads" to reinitialize the scripts. It has sadly ended in a save game that loads to crash and i will probably be waiting for at least 0.6x before attempting another run. 

The game at the core is truly amazing, a hard sci-fi world with tons of attention to detail and very immersive. You need to pay attention to a million small things to keep your base running and the AI is quite helpful (when not crippled by bugs). The world is a funny and strange mix of Dungeon Keeper meets Alien and it works! 

The only big fault I see is the planning... if you budget your game for one man for 2 years but have no chance of finishing it in that time-frame you'll run in a catch 22 , the game is in a too poor state to attract new buyers and thus you cannot hire people to accelerate the process. Nobody is willing to wait 6 years for a game to go gold regardless of how good it may become.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030700675', 'num_games_owned': 303, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 3026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2803, 'last_played': 1563566467}
review:
So far, this game seems pretty good. Of course, you can never really tell with Early Access games, but first impression is it's allright. Not exceptionally awesome, but pretty good. I'd even say at least slightly above average. It was definitaly worth the money and you get pretty much everything that's being advertised. What suprised me most is that, unlike many other alpha-games, this game has exceptionally little and few bugs. Sure, you get the occasional crash (at least on win10), which can be frustrating if you haven't saved in a long time, sometimes colonists get stuck and die, object "health" sometimes becomes negative which will result in the object not getting any repairs ever but all this happens rather rarely and doesn't really have too much of a disrupting influence. All in all, i'm pretty glad i've bought this game.

quick summary:

+ rather bug free
+ you get everything that you see in the trailer
+ the game can be played almost without any disturbances
+ no game-breaking bugs (at least none that i encountered)

- no autosave (at least not that i know of)
- game sometimes crashes (at least on win10)

so i'd say, if you don't mind running into small bugs occasionally or (seemingly) random game-crashes and you like the game's concept, go ahead and buy it, even if it's just to support the developer.

Edit: it has been more than a year since i played this game last time. Currently, it is definitely not "an entirely new game" (which is good, because i liked the game the way it was) but there are a lot of changes. as far as i could tell in the few hours that i have played now, pretty much all bugs that i mentioned have been fixed and i didn't experience any crashes. there are also a few new and interesting objects to work with. i still wasn't able to locate any option for autosaves, but now that the crashes seem to have been fixed, that is only a very minor issue and almost not worth mentioning. so, i'd say it has improved a lot since i wrote my initial review.

Edit2: and just about an hour after i finished the edit, the game crashed. but still, the game has definitely improved, even if the crashes are not fixed yet and there is still no autosave to use as some sort of workaround.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985834571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 542, 'last_played': 1537979280}
review:
Have been following this game through development for a while now, both by playing each new increment, and also watching the dev streams.
Firstly, lets reiterate that this is an Early Access Game. This means that it's in development, some features aren't 100% correct, bugs 'may' be included (for now), and it's not a final product.
Maia isn't your everyday resource planning, create, build kind of affair. Yes, it has those elements, but the game is way more technical and scientific. You have to bear in mind breathable atmosphere for your people. You have to watch for the core temperature and air flow. Create correct conditions for plant and animal life to grow. And watch that your people don't go loco and start losing their minds.
Graphically the engine is quite well done. Visual representation of solar flares, and external radiation are well done. Of course these conditions affect your environment too. 
Building and placing objects is pretty easy to do, after some practice you'll be placing and moving about freely. Personally I would like to be able to zoom out a little further, but that's personal preference.
Looking forward to more interaction with the wildlife - they are out in the wild, but I've yet to experience them attacking my crew, for example.
The addition of missions is a welcome one too. You have objectives to achieve and a time limit to do so. Once complete, you progress further on. I've not tried all of them but they certainly make you focus on the tasks in hand.
Just remember - early on - Crew need clean air, food, water. Nail that down quick and fast.
Looking forward to seeing what's coming next to this game - certainly a worthy purchase, in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038281770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 561, 'last_played': 1488047965}
review:
I have been enjoying this game  for a little bit over a month. I like the idea and the visual approach. The game play took a bit of getting used to and given it's still being polished I can't really base the review too much on it. Yes there are things I'm hoping that will be fixed, like selection squares that do not dissapear upon deselection, room tiles that don't go away after cancelling the construction, people who take forever to build things while running about aimlessly back and forth. Robots who can't always reach their mining destination despite doing so earlier is another thing I've been bumping into quite often. Or people dying of starvation or malnutrition despite having full stock of rations. I should also add my humans last a veeeery long time without a bathroom.

One of the major things I would find helpful is having more information on  item descriptions. While some are self explanatory, a short line saying what it does and what it requires to work would be great to have. I had to go online to see what does what so far. Another thing I'd personally appreciate is being able to prioritise construction in some way according to your selection or order in which a specific item was placed.

All in all I will be keeping an eye on further updates and I think I will have more and more fun with the game in the future.
