author: {'steamid': '76561198007008264', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1912, 'last_played': 1575084902}
review:
- Updated 2016-12-15 -

I definitely appreciate the continued updates to this game. I got a bit of time to get back into the latest patch (0.59) and really enjoyed many of the expanded options that the game presents. I get a lot more colonist deaths than I used to, which created stress to deal with the many problems - a very good thing in a game like this. I also managed to turn that flagging base around and down a more stable path, which was a huge sense accomplishment as everyone stopped dieing!

I'm looking forward to capturing one of the native fauna that can be domesticated and using it to supplement the base rations.

Every update has added blancing changes that make aspects of the simulation more interesting, and major features are added quite often that change aspects of how I've played the game. I still recommend this game, as it often makes me wish I had more time to play it.

- End Update 2016-12-15 -

I really enjoy this little base building & management game. I absolutely love that the development team works to publish regular updates to the game about once per month; each time adding neat new features (it's an alpha!) and working through the known bugs that have been reported and reproducible.

In particular, I love the heat simulation and new room layout mechanism in the most recent update. The former adds a layer of management detail that is complementary to other base needs, while the latter presents a more intuitive and visual way of "painting" the layout of your base than the existing system (you placed entire room tiles with a click). Then they worked to add in color a color picker for the lights, which affects the colonists' moods and plant growth rates. Oh and a brand new scripted mission to play through. So, plenty of new features each month to go along with learning what exactly it is your colonists need to stay alive and form a self-sufficient colony.

I've definitely enjoyed the open development of this game. Each update has been great and added several new toys to play with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004604229', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1030, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1593190445}
review:
ほぼ開発終了した様な印象の模様
一年半経過してアップデートが来たので、数年単位待てるなら待つのもありかもしれない。

バグ落ち・高負荷、インフォメーション不足・コンテンツ不足
個人開発だと思うけど、そのキャパを大きく超えていると判断する。


以下過去文

現在アルファであり、今後修正される要素や改善する箇所などがあるだろう事も踏まえた上で駄目な部分を書いておく

・UIが物凄く使い辛い
まずメインメニューの"Launch"文字がクリックしづらい。オリジナルカーソルを使用していることと、反応するサイズが小さすぎて押しにくい
ゲーム中マウスホバーで表示される情報は、逆に文字がでかすぎる上に画面からはみ出すせいで非常に見づらい
何より表示される文字が全体的に見づらい

建築するものをQやEキーで選択するという古くさい仕様
クリック(右含む)が汎用過ぎる。建築しようとしたときに出るメッセージを閉じるためにクリックしたら同時にオブジェクトを設置してしまうとか、設置しようとしたが止めようと右クリックしたら、マウスの下にあった建築指示を取り消してしまうとか

・全体的にインフォメーション不足
足りないものがあるならそれを表示するべきだし、建築指示を大量に作ると優先順位を設定できない
一つ一つ建て終わるの待ってから次を作らないと、何時まで経っても建て終わらないオブジェクトができて、主にミッションで容易に破綻する

石を掘り、材料にする、というメイン要素の資源管理に対して、地面に石が落ちてるところに部屋指示したら石は消えるし、材料作る指示しないと殆ど全てのオブジェクトが作れない
ロボが無限に石を排出できるみたいだけど、無闇に掘りたくないのに掘らないと進まないジレンマ
掘った後そこに部屋指定ではなくて、部屋指定をしたらそこを掘ってくれる方が楽なんだけど、部屋指定してない場所の崩落イベントが無意味になるから無理なんだろうか

・カメラの自由度が無い
・オブジェクト配置時のマウスに張り付く仮オブジェクトが緑のドットで輪郭が不鮮明である為に、微調整できず綺麗に位置合わせできない
・ミッションの建築指示のタイムリミットが短すぎて他のことが全然できない


サバイバルゲーにありがちだけど、現段階では自由度が少ない、というよりコンテンツ自体が少ない
酸素を供給する手段が一つだけな所とか、エアロックが無いと外に出れないはずなのに掘ったら外と繋がっちゃうところとか、まだまだ全然ゲームのベースができてない感じ

[strike]期待を込めてRecommendedだけど、現状はまだ「ゲームがまともに進められない」状況なのでNot recommendの方が強い[/strike]
バグも結構ある感じだし、開発能力もあまり高くない印象だが、がんばって開発は続けてもらいたい
(2016/11/29) しばらく経過して、現状のゲームにならない状況は1年2年以上待たないと解消しないと判断し、現状はNotRecommendにしておく事にしました。
参考になったと支持してくれた方、すいません。数年後もう一度状況を確認し判断したいと思います。

author: {'steamid': '76561198044021122', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1475995872}
review:
Ok, so I'm going to do a review of this game in its current state of 0.54.

Overall, this game isn't bad.

The graphics are ok, especially since it isn't a AAA engine. (The rain kinda is wanked, but that is with most games that are top down) The concept is, in my opinion, one of the best parts of the game and I'd love to see it reach its goal. Making it into the game a few hours, I finally built a lab and was able to start doing research, though it doesn't lead to anything yet. But based on the reserach that I completed and finished, it seems that the goal it to eventually get a tech tree of some sort into the game which would increase the time to "finish" the game and also increase replayability.

So, since this is a great concept and it seems to be on its way, what is the problem? I personaly feel like I don't know if it will ever get to its goal and dream. I've seen so many early access games come and go and never get fully finished. Like I said, the concept is great, but with a UI that needs work, menus that are slightly confusing and an AI that really doesn't seem to know what it is doing, I just don't know. Hopefully I'll get proved wrong.

So, breaking down the issues with the game I'll start with the UI. The UI doesn't provide enough information at a glance. It is slightly cumbersome and it provides so few functions in general. As for the menus I'll just give a few examples; the load and save buttons aren't in the "esc" menu but are buttons in the upper right of your screen... ok, not bad sounding... but they aren't labeled so I lost a two hour base because I hit the "load" and not "save" icon. Another example of the UI needing work is the building menu. To switch between items as of now, one has to press "Q" and "E" a design choice I personally don't get. And that latter brings me into my last point or the AI being wonky. I can get around most of the other issues, but the AI is my biggest gripe right now. I can't tell my colonists what to do by say clicking on them and then clicking on a task I want the to complete. In some cases, this can lead to many deaths. I can set up many tasks, with the first thing I tried to build being a heater, and they'll do other things first, and die from hypothermia. lol. I mean, if I'm freezing to death, I'll build a heater first. But, IDK, maybe they know more than me.

So, in the end I'm going to recommend this game with a caution. Beware of what you are getting. It is, as I said, a great concept and I think that all the negative reviews don't do it quite justice and I want to see this succeed as I miss games like this. However, I think that my fear of it not being finished or what it could be may still be well founded.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025892014', 'num_games_owned': 629, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1457532555}
review:
This review is of the game in ALPHA stages: Potential exists but don't purchase it yet.
Every once in a while you find a developer that understand what early Early access means and understands that it does not mean crowd source fundraising.

Not everything will work in Alpha and that is fine -- however there should be some minimum expectations. As of right now there are some ridiculous bugs/issues that I noticed within the first 20 mins of play including the following:

- Turning on/off text effects do not work properly (text effects are very annoying and distracting)
- The exit button does not work.
- Camera functions are not smooth on high end machine (i7 / GTX 908ti / 16GB)

There are options that should be available for use in an alpha that are not:
- Video options are extremely limited and are extremely slow to respond to adjustments
- No Gamma correction and this game tends to be a bit dark

By the time the developer is receiving money from players, the core game enviornment should be stable and workable enough to determine what else needs to be done in order to enable the community to provide usefull feedback. This is not the case and adding features should not be the priority when the enviornment is not stable and the GUI is clumsy at best.

My guess is they are running out of money and are getting desperate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029934417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1794, 'last_played': 1429863052}
review:
Plus de deux ans de développements et le jeu est à peine jouable !
Je veux bien soutenir le développement d'un jeu mais il faut que l'équipe s'investisse en conséquence. Pour le moment ce jeu n'est qu'une pure perte d'argent.

Difficile de donner un avis sur le concept du jeu puisque celui-ci n'est pas achevé... La partie gestion se limite à demander au robot (lorsqu'il ne bug pas) de creuser et de récupérer du minerai, puis de demander aux habitants (lorsqu'ils ne se bloquent pas) de construire des locaux dont on a vite fait le tour (lit, chiottes, machines, panneaux solaires, ...). la partie la plus intéressante consiste à gérer l'énergie de la base en construisant des batteries, panneaux solaires et des éoliennes en n'oubliant pas de les réparer tout le temps (pas à cause du climat difficile mais probablement d'un bug). Bref vos personnages se contentent de réparer des éoliennes toutes les minutes parfois à trois dessus sans penser à se faire de la bouffe et finissent par crever comme des cons... La recherche se résume à construire un ordinateur qui fera des recherches aléatoires et complètement sans pouvoir agir sur dessus. Ah! une dernière chose, vous construisez votre base mais pourquoi ??? il n'y a aucun but, sinon le plaisir de voir le jeu crasher au bout de 30 min de jeu.

A 22 euros !!! je trouve ce prix franchement malhonnete !

author: {'steamid': '76561198045109003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1542939140}
review:
I'd like to preface this review by saying that the game is in Alpha and I'll update the review as things change if I have time.

Ok, so I haven't written a review before but decided to write one for this game. First I'll just list Pros and Cons in order then describe a little about it from my experience thus far,

Pros:
-Neat idea worth expanding on
-Good graphics for an alpha
-Fun*
-Harder sci-fi than some I've played
-Devs work on the game and respond to feedback (Got an answer on the review initially)

Cons:
-Bugs
-More bugs
-Occasionally problematic UI
-Optimization issues
-AI build priorities
-Inability to manually control colonists

So, I'll start with the Pros. First off is the idea, I like it. It is always nice to see older style technology (Like the capsules the colonists land in) in a Sci-fi game instead of the constant use of sleek and streamlined ships and tech. Next up is the graphics, they are actually surprisingly good for an alpha game although I'll admit I've never been much of a snob about graphics. Now on to the "Fun" I mentioned, it is not fun in the sense of a fast-paced action kind of fun. It is more of a challenging fun associated with overcoming the challenges of survival. And finally, the last pro, "Hard" sci-fi. I find hard sci-fi to be more interesting a challenge in a game and that made it just a bit more interesting to me. For example: to get water you have to build a solar still and for food you need to build and maintain a hydroponics area instead of just building a food replicator or the like. 

Now on to the Cons. First off let's talk about the bugs, most of the other reviewers say that the dev/devs have focused on features over bugfixing (time will tell if that's true, I've only had the game a few days at time of writing.) I think the dev/devs should absolutely focus on bugfixes first, at least the game breaking ones that is. A good example of this has happened to me several times in a single game where I would call in some additional colonists and they would just stand outside the capsule waiting to die in their suits, that needs to be fixed. Apart from that, there are a few bugs I've encountered like one of my I.M.P. bots just standing in front of a fossil stand that was full holding a fossil and wouldn't dig or another one where my maintenance bots wouldn't go around the local Flora to repair my wind turbines so I had to manually drive them out and around the plants. Now that bugs have been adequately discussed let's move on to the UI. It is hardly there, kind of annoying to get used to, and is a little hard to use for rotating items without placing them. In addition to those, there is no way to save your game during it so you have to hope that it saves it. And, finally, on to the the optimization I mentioned. It freezes while loading it but eventually does get running. It is a minor issue but I did find it frustrating that the game freezes each time I start it even though it'll run well after it loads (with bugs and UI issues of course). 

TL;DR: It is definitely worth waiting on. I'll recommend it but with one planet sized caveat: it is buggy and very much an Alpha. In other words, watch the game and buy it when bugs get fixed.



**UPDATE**
I said I'd come and update the review over time, so I will. The bug with colonists getting stuck coming out of their pod is fixed. There are still some problems with AI priorities so far and the game crashes occasionally. For the AI priorities, I can set them to build the basics of a colony (Like heaters, atmosphere generators, and wind turbines) and they will not get around to much of it and die of hypothermia. 

One new problem I have with it has emerged though, and it is admittedly a little bit nitpick-y. The problem is that the escape menu has no save option or "quit to main menu" button. I'm assuming it is a save and quit situation, but it is still a little odd that I can't save with how much it crashes for me at present. I'd be fine with a "save and continue" or "save and quit to menu" option or something similar. 

I'd still recommend following the game, it is interesting and you don't see too many more "hard sci-fi" styled games like it. I'd recommend buying it if you don't mind it being a little buggy or supporting the devs though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001520311', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1427312855}
review:
This is a survival game based on hard sci-fi, so things can be a little "messy". The humans don't have handy mood bars above their heads and machines don't have health bars. You'll have to pay attention to whether your crew are writing dark poetry about setting the repair bots on their fellows to work out if they're going psychotic.

This game goes to great lengths to bring the perils of just existing on a hostile planet to life and the attention to detail can be felt running through all of the interacting systems.

It's been really interesting to watch this game grow through Early Access - update after update have added new systems and fixed bugs, and with a simulation game like this each new system increases the complexity exponentially. With the addition of the campaign it feels like those systems are now pushing towards something as well, for those who are less inclined to play a "directionless" sandbox.

If you want a fast action space fix this is not a game for you (and never will be) but if you want a well thought out simulation of what life could be like on a distant harsh planet then give this your consideration.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999725847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1900, 'last_played': 1465749634}
review:
***DO NOT BUY THIS GAME***

.56 update: Now the game has been updated so it'll work on modern video cards, so the game now runs.. HOWEVER, the game it's self is still unplayable. Colonists will just randomy starve to death even though there is food, livestock will spawn uncontrolalbly if you create a livestock area and cause all of your oxygen to be sucked up (the chickens don't die, but the colonists do). The funny thing is, there's an article from years ago that says the developer knew the chicken spawing rate was insane, but left it as-is because he thought it was amusing. Haha funny, we'er all laughing at a game-breaking bug you never bothered to fix (esp. since now it seems chickens are needed so colonists don't starve). 

Colonists won't build a door to save their life, quite literally.  Some things which should be automatic aren't (like converting raw materials into usable materials--the smelter isn't automatic, and can't be made to be automatic). Robots still get stuck, although the addition of repar robots is progress in the right direction (if they didn't get stuck).  UI is buggy. I had the tool tips say I was placing a "Dog: wooof!" for everything: items, rooms, etc (restart fixed that). Had another case were I couldn't see any of the update texts to know why a colnist died etc.

The game is playable for the first 10 minutes, then it crashes and burns in a cesspool of bad game logic.

I've given this game, and the developer, a chance for years now. I'm done. He has never fixed the core game logic, and, at this point, I doubt he ever will.  In fact, as of .57, he's added more logic that causes colonists to die even faster.

----
.54 update: The game now has issues with modern video cards using OpenGL 4.5 --it won't launch, and, instead, will try and "fall back" to OpenGL3, and then finally fail.  

Stay away from this game. Looks like the dev may have tried to make his own game engine--Unity would have worked fine here. No wonder why game developent is taking so blasted long.

---

Instead of fixing bugs and major playability issues (which are boring to do),  the developer has focused on adding features (which are fun to do, but pointless if the game core is broken). The only thing this "game" will provide you with is frustration. It isn't even a beta quality project yet/

Watch your colonits wander around inside your base and suffocate because they never bothered to take their space suits off. Have your colonists starve to death because they're too busy walking in circiles or standing still to eat. Watch your base equipment catch fire and burn because colonits are too busy fixing a door they just fixed a minute ago than to maintain equipment--and watch equpment filair up far more often than is fun. And come on? A work lamp becoming atorch and burning an entire room of hydroponics? That's just stupid-- no light would explode and start a fire because nobody had touched it for hours.

The UI also leaves much to be desired. The UI is both keyboard and mouse based, and the keyboard element isn't well explained,. There also is no scrolling through messages, so if the text doesn't fit all on the screen (such the case with stored research), then you won't be able to read it at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039801906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 1265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1254, 'last_played': 1537221194}
review:
J'ai récemment changé ma recommandation sur le jeu. Mais attention, tant qu'il n'est pas livré, je vous déconseille de dépenser près de 20 euros dans cette beta qui dure depuis 4/5 ans environ. Attendez que le jeu soit sorti avant de vous le prendre et vous verrez les avis, les tests, etc. Le développeur est très lent, peu communicant sur son site en tout cas (le dev log n'est pas à jour il me semble), mais il n'a pas abandonné son jeu. J'ai eu de gros problèmes de retour Windows et de plantages en tout genre pendant longtemps. Depuis aujourd'hui (13/09/2018), il semble qu'après 2 petites updates, le jeu soit plus stable.

Il serait bon d'avoir un wiki sur Maia pour savoir exactement ce qu'on peut faire. En tout cas, après quelques heures de jeu, j'apprécie beaucoup l'ambiance "dark sf". Alors certes l'IA semble... pas très smart, je veux dire : les animaux censés être dangereux ne nous attaquent pas... mais on peut faire des tas de petites recherches qui améliorent les items du jeu. A l'origine, le jeu semblait avoir pour objectif de quitter la planète hostile, il n'en est plus rien je crois. A la place on a un mode exploration, et des modes "missions". A suivre !

Soyez raisonnable : n'achetez pas le jeu maintenant. Mais je lui laisse sa chance, donc suivez aussi les progrès de ce jeu, qui n'est certes pas une révolution ou même à la hauteur des attentes, mais qui vaut le détour et plutôt unique en son genre.

Bon courage !

review:
Maia is still in early Alpha, which means it has quite a few bugs.  It will crash in the middle of play.  The AI will do stupid things.  There are graphical glitches.  Many things don't work or don't provide feedback on how to manage them properly.

If you can get past all that, it's actually a really fun game to play.  I've been playing about 16 hrs and done pretty much everything there is to do.  Since I bought it on sale, I feel like it was a fairly good deal - especially since it will continue to expand and improve.

It's possible to set up a functional base and complete everything that has been built so far in sandbox mode.There are also 3 missions, and 10 more to be released soon.  I can only complete 2 missions due to bugs, but that's what you get with early releases like this.

The devs seem responsive and are updating the game regulary (roughly quarterly), as well as participating in the Steam forum.  If you don't mind quite a few rough edges and an AI that will occasionally starve to death with plenty of food in the next room, I definately recommend this game :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197995414704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1445891952}
review:
[h1]Maia - Early Access[/h1]
[i]A Dungeon Keeper-esque space-colony builder with minimalist UI[/i]

tldr - I like it. Maia shows great promise, and has a very low chance of succumbing to Early Access Syndrome.

[u]Gameplay[/u]

Your base is built into a mountain (the atmosphere of the titular Maia is toxic). If your colonists need to go outside (to build solar stills for water, wind turbines/solar arrays for power, collecting researchable things like non-sentient alien creatures and plants, or meteorites, etc) they will use the airlock. The suits they use outside are cumbersome and slow.

Inside the mountain-base you designate (much like Dungeon Keeper) areas to be mined out. Once empty areas can have rooms (such as a workshop, a research room, a living area, a hydroponics room, etc) built into them. You must then place a door, and other context specific items (for example workbenches and 3D-printers in the workshop, or beds/couches and toilets in the living area). 

Once a game starts you must quickly build a workshop, and add a workbench. Once that is done you must build a power system (wind turbine/solar array, or a geo-thermal power plant as well as a "fly-wheel" energy storage (battery). Once a power system has been built you must place atmosphere generators. That all takes care of your urgent needs. You must however secure a food source (hydroponics, or animal farms) and continually satisfy the needs of your colonists.

You do not directly control your colonists.

[b]A note on the minimal UI[/b]
The devs of this game have stated from the outset that they don't want to 'spoon-feed' players to much information, and have designed the game in such a way that players must work for information. There is no "emotion bubble" that floats above your colonists, only biometric data like respiration rate, perspiration rate, heart-beats per minute, etc. This is just one example of a system that promotes player interaction and investigation as opposed to unrewarding spoon-feeding. All the information you'll need is there, you just have to find it.

[u]Pros[/u]
[list]
[*]A cool, and compelling theme.
[*]Easy to understand game mechanics.
[*]A tutorial (I'm serious, how many games have a proper tutorial while in Early Access!).
[/list]

[u]Cons[/u]
[list]
[*]No traditional savegames, instead you play one game at a time that can be continued if you exit the game and come back.
[*]No bordered window mode.
[*]Lacks detailed options (but there are resolution, anti-aliasing and quality options).
[*] No goals/missions other than survival (Although the latest update has added three scripted missions).
[*]Still in Early Access.
[*]The normal price of $24.99 is arguably too high for the current build (but will be a good price once Maia is feature complete).
[/list]

[u]The Early Access Problem[/u]
Maia is still in Early Access (As I write this, Alpha version 0.51) which poses several problems with a recommendation. When it comes to Early Access many promising games are either; abandoned by their developers halfway through development, developed in such a way that early-adopters are angered, or have their developers react angrily from criticism. I believe that Maia, although not immune from such problems, is certainly free of them for the foreseeable future.

[b]Dev Abandonment[/b]
Maia has received regular updates, both small 'hotfixes' and major updates. The two latest major updates, Alpha 0.50 and Alpha 0.51 were deployed on the 3rd September 2015, and 22 October 2015 respectively. Each update adds a lot of new content, and fixes bugs.
The developer, Simon Roth, is also very active on Twitter and happily answers questions.
[b]Bad Development[/b]
Some Early Access games have started out promising but developed along different lines than what was promised. I don't think Maia is at risk of that as it's clear from development and the content of updates that Simon and his team have a clear plan and is sticking to it. Hopefully this will protect against feature-creep, and I have seen no evidence that it isn't.
[b]Naughty Developers[/b]
Some strong games have been let down by their developers being taking criticism very badly and being rude - which does sometimes make people shy away from their games and makes adapters regret supporting such devs and their games. Simon and his team do not appear to be the type to do any of this though, as Simon is quite open on Twitter and I have never seen or heard any complaints regarding his behaviour.

I wrote this review after playing 6.2 hours of Maia.

review:
Updated Review 0.62

Problems:
* Contruction is weird when building two rooms adjacent to each other... the second room will have space used up by a hallway you didn't place.... why?  The blueprint didn't show that.
* Font for colonist selection screen is almost unreadable at my resolution.  It really needs to scale with resolution size.
* No way to prioritize what gets contructed first... and the AI isn't smart about it either. No food... well we'll work on something other than the greenhouse.... 
* AI problems.
* Letters/messages take a long time to scroll on the screen.  Annoying.
* Game could really use a UI element that shows your bases inventory, oxygen, etc... So that you don't have to click over to the storage or the ? button over, and over and over again.

* Lack of useful information.  
 -  Ok.  Red means you can't build something, green means it's ok.  But wtf does yellow and orange mean?  There should be a tooltip explaining what's wrong with the location.  
 - Why is something not being built.  Am I out of resources?  Is everyone too tired?  Can noone get to it?  When you hover over a construction project, it should show a tooltip saying if there is enough resources to build it or if its waiting for an available worker.
 - Are people idle?  Or is there something else preventing them from work?  Can't tell.
 - What workshop buildings do I need?  Are some of these just upgrades?  Or do I require some for building specific objects... No clue at all in the game.
 - Still no way to tell how much air their is in a room.


Pros:
 * It was neat that colonists would make suggestions that have possible positive and negative consequences.
* Looks nice.

(The game has improved allot, it is in a much, much better condition than it was before.)

 0.57 Review

Main Problems:
* Lots and lots of unecessary micro. 
 Ex:  You can build space heaters... but you have to manually turn them on and off as rooms go from too cold to too hot, apparently they can build robots, but not a rheostat. :-P  
 Ex:  Accoding to his youtube, if you don't manually operate the furnace, to smelt the ore... It has a chance of breaking down!  Cookie clicker isn't the best source of inspiration. :-P

* Lack of useful information.  

 - People dying.  They need to call for help or something.  So that the user can get an indication that something is wrong.  Example:  I had a colonist die from dehydration.  I had barrels of water and a water still.  Never got a warning saying colonist thirsty and I have no clue why they died.  (Stuck someplace maybe?  Bug?  I have no clue.  Which is the problem.)
 - Why is something not being built.  Am I out of resources?  Is everyone too tired?  Can noone get to it?  
 - Are people idle?  Or is there something else preventing them from work?  Can't tell.
 - What workshop buildings do I need?  Are some of these just upgrades?  Or do I require some for building specific objects... No clue at all in the game.
 
Pros:
Looks nice.

Overview:
I tired it out again and quit as I found the lack of useful information and all the micro really annoying.  It also felt agonizingly slow... but I suspect that was because of soemthing the peons where lacking, just no clue in game as to what that is.  (Sleep, workbenches, resources, something else?)

Still don't recommend buying the game.

Old review I had was for 0.51

review:
Think it's time to update a review of this game.  It's rare to have a responsive dev so I better take advantage.  The I.M.P. is much improved, no trouble with it ignoring orders.  However there is issue related to the I.M.P. but not really the I.M.P.s fault.  after it gets done digging it just stays there and when you build a room there's a good chance it'll get stuck inside a wall.  You can avoid that by giving it a dig order some where else so it'll move away but you have to remeber to do it and sooner or later I always forget.  I think the best way to fix this would be to program the I.M.P. to automatically go to the nearest storage unit and wait there when it completes any job it has so it will be safely out of the way and I won't need to remember.  Another fix would be the ability to destroy rooms.  As far as I know you can't destroy rooms but I havn't chaecked the tutorial in forever so I might be wrong on that.  There are two other concernes.  I notice after a long while the colonists seem to lose focus on building blueprints.  This only seems to happen after the base gets pretty big so it might be because they are busy repairing things, not sure if repairing is prioritized over building.  In future plays I'll try and remeber to use more than one repair drone and see if that helps.  

The other thing is the windmills.  They keep falling down.  I always put turrets by my windmills so I'm pretty sure it's not wild life getting them.  Often times it happens so fast I don't think it normal wear and tear, I'm lucky if I get two days out of them.  Solar arrays are working great though just don't forget to use generators so you get power through the night and the generators are working perfectly in my experiance.  Happy to see the progress this game has made,  Thats all for now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977161982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1441505517}
review:
[b]I work on Maia[/b] - So you should treat anything I say as biased, untrustworthy, probably composed of festering garbage.

[b]Short summary: [/b]Maia is a unique, captivating game. It explores the possibility of a human colony on an alien world. Even in its present unfinished state, Maia is worthy of purchase and full of potential for enjoyment and delight.

[h1]Overview[/h1]

I first encountered Maia at a [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J7HLqexFBeY]game show in 2014.[/url] Being fascinated by space exploration, I was immediately sucked in. Maia 'gets' space exploration in the same way DayZ 'gets' zombies: The story is not the zombies, it is the [i]people.[/i]

In Maia, people are at the heart of the experience. They do what the want. They interact with each other. They may follow your orders, or they may laze about and die of starvation. They might threaten each other, become sad, grow happy, or develop relationships. They are truly a group of colonists, going about life on an alien world.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Interaction with Maia is indirect. The player never builds structures, or conducts research. Instead, requests are placed in the world and colonists then react to those requests. I use the word 'request' rather than order, because colonists will not always carry out instructions.

At first, their ambivalence to a placed Atmosphere Generator may be interpreted as a bug in the game. With more play time it becomes apparent that the colonists have a sense of what is important, and what is required. Already have too many Solar Arrays? Colonists might simply choose not to build them.

There are no centralised mechanisms for managing colony power, food, and water requirements. Instead, individual stores must be inspected, and observations taken around the world. This quirk can sometimes be frustrating, but that frustration can give way to fulfillment - Balancing a power grid is very hard, and more rewarding for being so.

Often I see Maia referred to as a 'God Game.' Having never played 'God Games,' and not being familiar with the genre, I can't speak to the accuracy of that description. I would not, however, describe Maia as a god game in the first instance: The player is not god, they are a companion. Not omniscient, omnipresent, or all-powerful at all. Instead, the player is limited, flawed, and often ineffectual - A reflection, perhaps, of the colonists pottering about on the planet surface, and all the more enjoyable for it.

[h1]Aeshetics[/h1]

Generally, I am about as artistic as a pencil sharpener, so I'm not the one to judge Maia's aesthetics. But I think it looks fantastic.

The use of a custom renderer means the game does not express the intangible 'feel' of a commercial solution such as Unity or Unreal. Instead, it gives of a vibe of bespoke craftsmanship. Models are of a consistently high quality. Animations are well weighted and engaging - Though they are often blatantly disconnected from the gameplay their are supposed to be related to.

[h1]Technical[/h1]

Early Access games come in various flavours of 'bugginess,' and Maia has tended to hover towards the 'very buggy' end of the spectrum through much of its development. Because Maia does not offer many explicit clues to the player about what is happening in the world, bugs can be insidious. A colonist sitting on the floor of a room may be bored and recalcitrant: Or their AI might simply be stuck in a buggy loop of doom.

Recently, the [url=http://steamcommunity.com/gid/103582791434871068/announcements/detail/97180323971741771]Stardystopia Update[/url] has brought fresh stability and consistency to the experience. If Stardystopia is a foundation upon which Maia grows in future updates, then it has the potential to leave its challenged technical past behind.

[h1]Development[/h1]

Judging the character of Maia's development is perhaps the act in which my conflict of interest is most likely to manifest itself. It is also the area of which I am most critical.

An Early Access game must be open. To be on Steam Early Access to not just invite, it is to require the interaction of customers with the development team. It has been difficult for Maia's customers to find information about development. In the last few months, the team has made strides towards pulling down the fourth wall and letting information flow out to customers. This process must accelerate.

The pacing and content of development updates are strong. Most especially since around March this year Maia has received consistent, high quality updates that have steadily improved the game.

Most importantly, Maia's development team has authentic soul and character. [url=https://twitter.com/SimoRoth/]Simon[/url], [url=https://twitter.com/carolinedonnaf]Caroline[/url], [url=https://twitter.com/leannethng]Leanne[/url], [url=https://twitter.com/Ruairi_Iliffe]Ruairi[/url], [url=https://twitter.com/hdickson_]Hannah[/url] and others are committed, tireless, optimistic, and hard working. They want Maia to be a better product, and are constantly putting in the effort to make it so.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Maia is a unique, captivating game. It explores the possibility of a human colony on an alien world. Even in its present unfinished state, Maia is worthy of purchase and full of potential for enjoyment and delight.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006776194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1441647333}
review:
If you ever wanted to play a colonist game where all the colonists are taken from Idiocracy then this is the game for you. 

In the earlier alpha versions:
-The colonists built in some random order prioritizing food and water over building anything, so all my colonists died from lack of clean air. During one of the play throughs they finally built the air generator and power generators just to find out that the colonists prioritized a couch over a bed. Yup, a couch. They would run to the workbench to work on the bed then run all the way back to the couch to sit and repeat this process with the occasional run to get food or water. The workbench and beds were really close. To be honest they finished the hopper before a bed, oh and a door to an empty room, and another couch. They never finished the bed.

-Another play through I set up a nice looking research lab and placed an artifact in there. To my horror the artifact was cursed. The colonists would run to study it and oh boy did they study the hell out of it. They studied so hard they died from starvation or exhaustion. After the colonist's untimely demise the next would run over to study it on top of body of his fallen comrade. This happened until my colony was wiped out. Yes I had over 8 colonists and all died in a glorious pile in front of the artifact. 

With Alpha 0.50 I find the colonists actually building things. Except doors to rooms with their fellow colonists trapped inside. For those that haven't played when you create a room it has no doors built in and the person who built it gets trapped inside. I thought my other colonists would go to the rescue but instead they roamed the land outside the colony searching.... searching for what I do not know. Then they would suddenly stop and stare at a tree, rock, windmill, solar panel, or just stand infront of their recently dropped colony ship thing. Yup new colonists would land and just stay in front of their ship. I had about 5 guys next to each other in front of their ship. The colonists must have messed up bad on earth because all I can think of is the earth being run by really smart people: "You have an IQ of 20! Well we so happen to have am OUTERSPACE mission for you! Can you say OUTERSPACE?" "Otterspace!" "Yeah close enough, off you go."

I would recommend this game to any who feel like get frustrated at colonists who are anything but the chosen few to expand our foothold in the galaxy. I will say the concept and what the creators are trying to do is really good but the game has a long way to go before it can get out of alpha into beta and even more before it can be released as a game.

review: I thought I would update the review because the dev requested new ones since the game has changed. Simon Roth takes his time with his work. His studio is clearly passionate about this project. There are a lot of problems with it, and it has taken a very long time to fix them. But that is what happens when you don't have a huge budget or adds all over the internet. I get the feeling that most people heard about this game by accident. But if they were like me, they have creative minds, and saw another creative mind building a game with a fantastic concept and wanted to help. That's waht creative people do; they help each other, they support each other. Buying this game in early access should be about that. It should be about the support, the criticism, the evolution of a product from an idea to its fruition. If you are not in it for that, then wait. The game will come. And it will be awesome when it does. Until then, keep up with the progress. Show your interest. Spread the word. The more people that know about this, the better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969758335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1438742824}
review:
I really, really wish I could write a positive review for this game. It is fun! I do enjoy playing it! So, why can I not recommend it? Why am I writing a negative review? Because I do enjoy playing it. That is, when I can. When I don't mind waiting 5 minutes for the game to load to the main menu. When it doesn't crash on me (something that occurs far to often). 

I've been following this game for several year now. I bought into the alpha back in mid 2013, or at least well before it hit steam. It was in Alpha then, and is in Alpha now. Even Minecraft didn't take this long in alpha, and its alphas were far more stable. I was playing through this game just before writing this, wanting to record some footage to post online. I played for about 17 minutes, after which it crashed. Lost that save. And if I wanted to start it up again...whelp, gotta wait for the game to load the menu, in order to load the game. Oh, and DON'T EVEN THINK about changing any graphics settings, unless you want to wait a minute and a half until the game decides it's ready. Also, while this maybe due to me having a shitty 4:3 monitor, but I could not play this game in any widescreen resolutions, even in windowed mode. 

This game had, and still has, so much potential. If it wasn't so crash prone, and didn't take a lifetime to load, I wopuld recommend it. It is fun!....WHEN it works. The problem is, well, it tends not to. Not for very long, at least. It's as crashy now as it was back in 2013. 2 years, and still a crashy, buggy alpha. It feels like more effort has been put on gameplay and features, and less on fixing bugs. What good is gameplay, even amazing gameplay, if you're unable to enjoy it due to bugs and crashes? I want to play it more, I really do! It's just...why bother? I'll get really into it, and oh well then hello there crash! Oh, and goodbye save.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032552620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1545516927}
review:
EDIT PLAYING 0.62:

This game still sucks :( The interface is terrible. Text is not well visible over the background, the UI switches to things happening outside while you are placing objects inside of base. Or it shows some random email while you are building - why is this engine in charge of what I see all the time???

There is almost zero sesnse of the base's resources. Sometimes things don't get built but I can't figure out why. Do I not have enough material? Is the building itself bugged? I can't tell because there is no UI to get this info!!!

The game still crashes while playing.

The missions are too hard. It's not easy to fulfill objectives unless you have every single move planned upfront. I.e. after failing numerous times.

IMHO, the developers keep failing in game design. Yes, building your own engine is great, well done, you can pat yourselves on the back. Now get someone who can actually make things playable for people!


REVIEW OF 0.49:

I just had a look at the 0.49 and regrettably I must say I wouldn't recommend this game. I bought it around 0.47 because it looked so good on paper but here is why you actually shouldn't get it in my opinion, at least in its current state:

- the updates have been increasingly rare
- the updates that it does get add new functionality that seems random while it doesn't improve the (lack of ) core game play
- there is no sense in the game of what you are supposed to be doing - e.g. how much material / food / colonists in total you have. They just added reports on power which is great, but every game like this has an overview window that shows you your resources so that you know what you need to be getting next. That, to me, seems more important than adding weapons, for instance.
- there is no sense of why accidents happen - e.g. all my atmosphere generators exploded all at once - I have no idea why! And the colonists don't seem to care, they just walk around. You would expect major panic if something like this happened in the real life (the game is supposed to be a simulation, right?)

Before you all start accusing me of not knowing what alpha is - I know very well. I'm a dev myself.

In my opinion, the devs here should stop adding more functionality that create more breadth and isntead focus on improving the gamer's experience to create depth. Make a game out of this. Because at the moment, it seems like bunch of functionality stitched together. Give us a reason to play! Experimenting with new features is great, but wears off after you've built everything. The game is not interesting after that.  Give us a sense of what we are doing and why we are doing it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994233547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1551669315}
review:
I really want to like Maia - and largely I do. I was part of this game's IndieGogo campaign four years ago. I'm a huge Dwarf Fortress fan, and Maia was promised to be sort of like a Dwarf Fortress in space. This seems largely accurate, since Maia has been in an alpha release format for years, is designed around a story-lite rogue-like colony building simulation, and it has some pretty heavy detail on certain things (colonist moods, for instance). 

However, Dwarf Fortress is playable (your mileage may vary). Maia is really not playable and hasn't been for some time. I imagine that making a game is difficult, especially with a small independent team. However, the game got a couple hundred thousand dollars from Kickstarter and tens of thousands from the IndieGogo side. I do very much hope that I'll be able to change my review of this. In its current state, I cannot recommend it to anyone -- especially for this price. I don't regret buying into the crowdfunding campaign, but I am pretty disappointed at the abandonware/vaporware aspect of it. It has a lot of potential. Perhaps some day it will be realized.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055081506', 'num_games_owned': 455, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1076, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 986, 'last_played': 1631892060}
review:
Ich verfolge das Spiel nun schon seit seinem "Erscheinen", Maia hat durchaus Potential.

Normalerweise werden Astronauten wegen ihrer Intelligenz ins All geschickt, HIER ist das anscheinend nicht so. Das Personal stirbt ohne jede weiter Rückmeldung einen der zahlreichen Bildschirmtode nach dem anderen.

Leider baut das Entwicklerteam lieber neue Maschinen ein statt endlich ein sinnvolles Userinterface und Meldesystem zu entwickeln. So quält sich der Spieler, vom quiekenden Alarmsystem unterstützt, von Besatzungstod zu Besatzungstod. Den um herauszufinden warum die Besatzung stirbt, oder warum die Alarmsysteme schreien muss man im Forum fragen.

Das Spiel lässt den Spieler nämlich absolut im Dunkeln, was denn nun so rundherum vorgeht. Selbst so einfache Dine wie die Tastaturbelegung gibt das Spiel nicht preis. Diese muss man ebenfalls im Forum erfragen.

So stirbt man, zwischen zahlreichen Systemabstürzen, fröhlich weiter vor sich hin. 

Ach ja, kommt bloß nicht auf den Gedanken das Spiel stumm zu spielen. Denn sollte es mal einen der spärlichen Hinweise geben, erklingt der ausnahmslos nur per Sprachausgabe.

Wenn ihr es dann geschafft hab, mit Hilfe der anderen User, eine größere Basis aufzubauen, werden die Systemabstürze und zerstörte Spielstände euer ständiger Begleiter sein.

Die liebgewordene "Early Access" Ausrede kann man daher getrost stecken lassen, denn nach fast 1,5 Jahren kann man als Spieler, speziel für mehr als 20,- Euro schon etwas mehr erwarten.

Daher seit vorsichtig, empfehlen kann man Maia derzeit absolut nicht.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039772947', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1674345326}
review:
*Read the edit after the first review too*

Some issues I found in the game while playing:

- Some NPCs will often start walking in circles trying to find a sweet spot to reach something and will stay like this for a while (minutes, sometimes 10 minutes or more), and if this NPC is a human being, it will starve to death.
- The colonists starve to death even if there is plenty of food
- The animation for the "aliens" to die takes really long. Like "Wow you shot me? Just hang on while I prepare to die... just a minute... almost there. Okay, dead"
- There is nothing you can do about the bodies outside the base and sometimes the alarm will just keep warning about the base perimeter, even if everything out there is dead.
- When you ask the colonists to build a materials hopper they just won't... until they feel like it. But then your entire base is completely full of rocks and they WON'T TAKE THE ROCKS FROM THE FLOOR AND PUT THEM IN THE HOPPER!
- The colonists walk too slow. So slow that they often starve or fatigue to death on the way to their assignment.
- There are not many things to do in the game, so the player may get bored REALLY FAST. No action, no jumpscares, no nothing... and it gets boring.
- After you built the entire base, it will be too big, and the colonists will die because of fatigue due to their deficient AI.
- When a colonist die from the fire on the atmosphere creator (?) it will become a burning corpse and won't move.
- Sometimes colonists die and just stay there, standing... creepy.
- Colonists will ignore bodies and people dying. This should be prioritized. 

My reccomendations:
(To the developer)
- Fix the bugs before developing new stuff. People are getting tired of the bugs and are leaving the game.
- Some more action would be a nice thing (if you really want to develop new stuff)
- Make the colonists faster! They run and stop too much! It's so annoying.
- In base, the colonists in the suit should walk faster.
- Try to program a new AI. They should prioritize some stuff, like eating and resting! They die of thirst and hunger even when you have lots of water and food avaiable. I don't think a human being would starve to death due to his many assignments. He would eat and then work.
- They get hungry too fast.

(To the players)
- The game has a really nice concept but is still in development. It's still unfinished! If you don't have patience to wait for the developer to fix stuff, just don't try any alphas. You will get tired and will just get pissed for no reason. 
- If you do have a lot of patience, my advice: play it. The game is really cool and it makes you imagine all the possibilities for it in the future. It's raw, but when cooked it's gonna be crazy :P

Edit: It has been 5 years since my review of this game. The developer even thanked me for my detailed review. And I appreciate that. But then it's been 5 years and...

The game is still unplayable. One thing is to have patience and wait for the dev to fix the bugs, another is to come 5 years later and the game still be in the same position.

I mean, the concept is great but the game is still in its early steps. Not playable at all.

Some examples of bugs:

- The colonists still starve to death even when there's food everywhere.
- Colonists usually forget to do stuff like tending to crops and making food.
- Bodies are still left outside to rot.
- Colonists still walk way too slow in a "run and walk" manner. It's mildy infuriating to see. They often walk too slowly and die before arriving to their destination.
- Sometimes colonists have to wear protective suits inside the base, and that's fine, but that makes them EVEN SLOWER than they already are. And most times they just starve to death.
- Aliens can clip through walls and doors and get inside your base and eat your chicken.
- Most buildings are forgotten by the colonists and the blueprints stay there forever.
- Fighting is extremely not satisfying at all. Colonist shoot, alien walks like nothing is happenings, and takes 200 years to "die". The animation is wonky.
- Colonists get out of the base for no reason without wearing protective gear and die on the wasteland. Definetely a bug because there is no reason for them to do that and you can see the colonists is trying to get back in but the path finding is awful and he can't seem to find a way back in.
- There are many other bugs I could describe but it has been so long I'm not sure the dev will be able to fix this.
- Now, after some time, there won't be enough space for new colonists to arrive. And I don't mean in the base, I mean they can't land because of the capsules outside from previous colonists arriving. You can destroy the capsules, but as I told you, most times colonists never go where they have to and they never destroy the capsules you ask them to. Your colonists start dying and you can't seem to get new colonists because of the old capsules outside.

Once again, the concept is cool but sometimes I feel the engine chosen to make the game might be too old or something like this. It seems the dev can't make it work and I understand how frustrating this might be. I'd love to give this game a thumbs up again but after 5 years waiting for the same bugs to be fixed I just can't do it.

If you like this kind of game and want to give it a try, go ahead, but don't expect it to be a walk in the park. It's hard and most times it'll kill you for no fault of your own. You give the colonists everything they need to survive but in the end they always die.

NEW EDIT:

I don't learn. I can't learn. After literally more than a year after the last edit, I came to the conclusion that the dev doesn't understand what are the issues with the game. Problem is, the whole community is telling him the issues and he still keeps doing them. I don't know if this game will ever be what it could be. Anyway, don't buy it if you treasure your sanity.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106160971', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1509679198}
review:
This is my first reveiw ever, and I only write this because I want to warn people.  First off, I have a Mac.  I know, hail PC master race, I'm not worthy and all that, yada yada...  If you have a PC, my complaints probably aren't for you.  For Mac users, here's your warning.

The fact is, this game said it was Mac compatible, so I spent my 15 or 20 dollars thinking it would be, you know, Mac compatible.  Well, a year later, I still have never gotten to play the game (unless you count one time it actually started and ran at about .5 fps. for a few minutes before crashing.)  I have patiently waited for this dev team to fix whatever bugs have been preventing this game from running or even starting on my Mac that meets every system requirement I've seen.  And here I am still waiting, with no results to show for it.  Yes, this is an early access game, so bugs are expected.  But this has been an early access game for 3 years.  I think that is a long time for any game to be early access, and its plenty of time to fix bugs that make it impossible for customers to even start the game.  

So please, save your money and move on.

-100/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197986850839', 'num_games_owned': 961, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1064, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 860, 'last_played': 1454945338}
review:
Rating based on what is present. When/if things are resolved, will be ammended.

Good potential in what is there but at this point after following the game for a few years now preceding the Early Access release it is still in dire need of:

* Colonist behaviour tuning so they don't just feel like partially-autonomous robots just running about performing reactive duties - Missing are Social interactions, off-duty behaviour, interests, role ownership in that it doesn't take 5 colonist engineers to attempt to change a lightbulb. If one person decides they will own the job of changing light bulbs it should be their responcibility, and just generally seeing colonists do more than just bounce between reactions.

* Some means for the player to actually be involved in the colony even if it's through passive influence events. Currently you say where rooms go and what objects go where, then you're done and have nothing to do forever except sit watching a rather interesting/destructive screensaver. Complex simulation inclusion is great for a game, but a game it does not make in itself if you have no avenue for continious engagement.

* Cleaning up some of the AI in place, especially in the areas of pathfinding common occurance still for example is Imps walking through solid walls and then finding themselves stuck on the other side when they notice that wall is solid making the player demolish chunks of their base or cavern walls in reaction to buggy behaviour.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970258858', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1545684830}
review:
Do not waste your time and money on this game. In its current state its barely playable and will just frustrate you to tears. Each update brings more features and content but even more bugs. If its current rate of development continues it will take years to even leave alpha. While it shows some promise and I really want it to work, I seriously doubt it will ever realise its full potential before the plug is pulled on this project.

Update: 

I tried to play the recent build of 0.56 and I hate to say that this game has gotten even worse somehow. Your colonists are even more stupid than ever before, despite several A.I improvements mentioned in patch notes. Instead of roaming around weeping themselves into starvation they will now wander aimlessly freezing to death, as weeping and sitting on the floor is more productive to their survival than building a wall heater apparently. 

There are many many more ridiculous bugs that are each just as game breaking that seem to never be fixed, but rather compounded with each content patch. If the current build was made to be somewhat playable before new mechanics and other content is added or if what is stated in the patch notes is actually present in the game I may have hope for this game. But as it stands, there is none.

TL;DR
The game is still broken, has been in alpha for years and will never be worth your money

author: {'steamid': '76561198033688139', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2512, 'last_played': 1526484395}
review:
НЕ БЕРИТЕ ЭТУ ИГРУ! Даже со скидкой в 90%! 

Уже сколько лет игра в разработке, а прогресса почти что и нет!
Я все ждал, ждал... еще с версии 0.25+ постоянно слежу за ней. Но обновления выходят раз в 2-3 месяца! Причем обнова из разряда: "Починили траекторию ИМПа!", через пару месяцев опять: "Починили траекторию ИМПа и добавили какую-то мелочь". И так далее каждые 2-3 месяца! Нет, задумка хорошая, но вот разработчик явно положил мокрый и горячий на разработку. А те так называемые "сайлент" апдейты никто и не замечает, ведь, как говорит сам разраб, фиксится что-то важное. 

Про никакую оптимизацию - даже говорить нету смысла. 
Более того, если еще на версиях 0.37-0.45 колонисты могли забегать в скафандрах домой, то сейчас они это делают постоянно... 

В общем, раз в 2-3 месяца что-то фиксят, но при этом ломают в 2-3 раза больше. Даже полосу слева на ЛЮБЫХ картах от АМД не удосужились убрать! В свое время брал за 450р о чем жалею. На тот момента была надежда, и вот увы, прогадал в итоге. 

Ее даже за 50р не рекомендую брать. Это будут просто выкинутые деньги в никуда. К тому же противно наблюдать, как разрабы доят народ как коров. Сначала заманивает, а потом, когда все видишь и осознаешь - обещают кучу всего. Так что можете смело взять игру, попобовать поиграть минут 30, и сделать возврат средств. На крайний случай - час. Надолго вы вряд ли тут задержитесь.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030886853', 'num_games_owned': 266, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1639160313}
review:
I like the general idea of the game and if it actually functioned the way it is intended to, I would enjoy it. However, after several tries on several development stages, so far it has disappointed me. Not being able to *directly* influence what game units do is only fun if game units do sensible things by themselves. 

Settlers not sleeping, because they have no beds is hilarious. Settlers not building beds (or anything for that matter) because they prefer to write hilarious letters is unsettling. Settlers not sleeping even though they have beds is frankly just annoying.

I will happily play again and continue to give this game more chances since it is still in development.

review:
Das Spiel hat ein großartiges Potential und eine feine Idee dahinter, denn Weltraumbasis Aufbauspiele hat es lange nicht mehr gegeben.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013351773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1674747966}
review:
Habe die "Entwicklung" von Maia seit dem Erststart bei Steam verfolgt. Fazit: Noch immer nicht spielbar.

Derzeitiger Stand (betrifft 0.48 auf iMac 27" Mitte 2011 unter OSX 10.10.4):

- Nur jeder zweite Programmstart funktioniert, im Wechsel mit "unerwartetem Beenden" noch vor dem Ladebildschirm.
- Hat ein Programmstart geklappt, bietet sich der Bildschirm in nativer Auflösung im Fenster an: 2560x1440. In dieser Auflösung ruckelt es fürchterlich.
- Also Neustart (mindestens zwei Mal), um die Auflösung zu ändern. Ein Krampf. Die Auflösung lässt sich nicht auswählen, sondern ich muss alle Auflösungen durchklicken. Nur dass dieser "Mauszeiger" dann nicht mehr mit dem Bildschirm synchron läuft. Unmöglich, dann noch die Zeile mit der Bildschirmauflösung zu treffen. Abhilfe: Abbruch des Programms, Neustart (mindestens zwei Mal).
- Hat man die Auflösung endlich geändert, NIEMALS DEN FULLSCREEN-MODUS EINSCHALTEN !!! Dann bleibt nämlich der Bildschirm schwarz. Abhilfe: Abbruch des Programms, Neustart (mindestens zwei Mal). Dann die config.xml löschen und von vorne beginnen.

In den Update-News feiern die Maia-Macher neue Features. Davon konnte ich noch nichts probieren, mangels lauffähiger Engine.

Unbedingt nachbessern!

review:

If you answered yes to any of these you will need to skip this game. Take your money elsewhere, maybe even donate it to your local space program, as that will get you closer to space than this 'game' ever will.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035676654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1614100627}
review:
So it seems like a cool game, it the screenshots seemed to be how I would picture an ideal game of this type. I've been following Maia for a while but I've never bought an early release game and was hesitant to do so. I few weeks, maybe a month ago I bought Prison Architect, which is also an early release game and it was great, it seems complete even though they are still working on it. Then just a few days I decided to buy Maia, I believed for the price it would be fun to play and see how it would grow through updates. 

However I can't play. I installed in on my computer and when I start it up I get a little document which flashes and then shut downs, not even making it to the actual game. I reinstalled it, didnt work.  Changed around with the screen scenes and it didnt do anything. So I tried to install it on my cousins computer. I got so excited when the game launched, I got to what I guess was the loading screen before it faded white and said, "Maia.exe has stopped working."

I dont believe both computers have issues, I would like to think it was simply an early release bug, but they are two different problems. So for now, I would not recommend this game until this is fixed. I do hope this can be fixed with a future update as I really would like to try out this game.

Update: 5/5

I was playing this game again and realized that it is playable, and somewhat enjoyable once you get pass the intial stages. Then I realized that I gave it a bad review like three years ago. Still it has has a lot of work to be done, but the developer is very active with updates and responding back to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031757552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1428237533}
review:
[b]Early access review[/b] of build 0.47.  Ignore the steam playtime; I bought this outside of steam at 0.3x.

It's not often I write a negative review, especially of early access games - either it's too soon to tell, or the game is so bad that Jim Sterling will deal with it.  Maia, though, I want to warn people off, for now.

[b]Maia should not be in early access at this time[/b], and it certainly should not have a ticket price of $25.  This is an alpha stage game, with serious, fundamental flaws that need to be worked on before this can be an enjoyable beta experience.

[b]Maia[/b] is a colony builder, like [i]Spacebase DF9[/i] or [i]Rimworld[/i].  It takes the [i]Towns[/i] approach of letting you set tasks and build spaces but not directly control the colonists.  With good AI and balanced priorities this works well; without it, you get issues as with Towns.  Maia is somewhere in between: the AI isn't very good, but there is so little going on in the gameworld that it's just about good enough, unless you do something weird.

Graphically I like Maia.  It's got a 1980s styrofoam-and-foil aesthetic, with big-head robots and Space: 1999 jumpsuits.  The graphics are very unpolished, but this game I think qualifies as alpha at this stage, so that will come.

The UI is just so bad.  It is clunky, awkward to use, with unintuitive keybindings, an absence of necessary information in the overlay, no easy way to check what your colonists are doing, and an annoying over-sensitivity to screen scrolling when you're trying to get the obnoxious and imprecise mouse cursor over the icons.  Drawing rooms is a chore, which is an issue when that is pretty much the only thing you can currently do in the game.

It's also very poorly optimised.  Running on min settings, with a mid-range computer in excess of the recommended specs, I get memory crashes, terrible frame rate issues, and periodic freezing as the game tries to calculate something.  I've spent a lot of time on forums trying to find ways to address these issues at my end, with no luck; I'm not the only person with this experience.  A certain level of poor optimisation is to be expected with early access, but not to the degree where it derails your playing.

Development is okay.  I feel like they should be further along than they are at this point.  For over a half a million dollars in funding and a year and a half since the first playable build, it should be further along than this.  I think Maia, Towns, DF9 et al illustrate one central truth about town-management games: they take time to develop.  If you over-promise, you get DF9; if you rush and then run out of hype, you get Folk Tale; if you don't nail the AI, you get Towns.  Dwarf Fortress didn't happen overnight; without having to worry about graphics or platform integration that game took years to get to anything like a quality gaming experience.

And that's principally why I am warning against Maia.  For a well-funded game to be charging $25 for an early access build that isn't optimised, isn't visually polished, doesn't have basic features, lacks solid AI, and is without the diversity of content you need for a game in this genre, that's not a good investment.  I accept that an early access game will be content-light, will have areas needing to be polished, but when a colony-manager after this much work still doesn't have basic UI, AI and optimisation sorted out, they are going to have no chance of adding more content without bringing the game crashing down.

I want this game to succeed, but they don't need more money, and you don't need the current experience of Maia.  Give them until the end of the year, see where they're at then; they will either have fixed these issues by overhauling basically the core of the game, or it will have gone the way of Folk Tale.  Either way you'll have your answer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993694080', 'num_games_owned': 2303, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1542471558}
review:
Firstly I think I should explain what the game is, its an early access version of a hard sci fi colony sim, very similar in play style to Dungeon Keep. It features I.M.P that are robot versions of imps from Dungeon Keep, they will mine what you select for mining. Your colonists build your rooms and items in them, as well as grow crops, research and all that jazz. Maia is also hard sci fi, the colonists sweat and burn calories when working, the more calories they burn the more food they need to eat. All this is simulated in the game, so you need to get your food correct and it takes time to grow so planning and learning is needed.

Lots of updates to the game since it launched on early access, there is at least 1 sizeable update a month. Its is very stable at the moment, runs very well and no major crashes. Its very much an alive game.

The AI has been improved drastically in the last few updates, they no longer seem to want to die, still a way to go with them, but they are very much do what you think they would at the moment.

The UI is the biggest stumbling block in the game. I kinda like it, but I can understand people that don't. Its very hands off, you know what is going on by seeing it. If a colonist is shivering and you see their breath, then the air is cold. You know the air quality of a room by screens that can be built, there is no overlay or any information readily available to the player. 

Also in the construction menu, there are no images, you have to scroll through a list of options with the keyboard, its easy to miss things. I would like a slide out panel that had images and you can select it but you get used to the way of it soon enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970673877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1106, 'last_played': 1531725752}
review:
I Purchased this game on the release week i think and that was a while ago I was early access then and it is early access today, I have read some of the neg reviews and the tone is slow to get updates, broken game play, stupid AI. then I think early access there is no false clam here saying this game is 100% ready to blast your socks off this game is early access and it will be for a while yet and as for the slow updating i can say I picked up this game again when alpha 47 started and there has been a hot fix jsut about every day the Dev and his relatively new team are working on the game every day make fixes addressing bugs and concerns on the steam forums Simon the Dev is there every day that i looked this week nailing down reported bug to keep the testing of the game moving forward that's were this game is right now Testing because it's in alpha development.

So yes slow update was a issue but with recent events I don't see that being a problem any more and if you worried about the dev burning out or burning the cash of there customers like some other early access dev have done Simon has already addressed these concerns http://maiagame.com/viewentry.php?id=25 This game is receiving good attention from the dev team and the progress is moving faster then i have ever seen it on this game improvements are happening faster with that said there is still a ton of testing for game breaking glitches left to do so don't expect a glitch free game yet.

Pos:

steady progress of the game with hot fix’s and cont updates

game is poorly optimized ATM (But what do you expect form early access a gold toilet?)

When it's all said and done this game is going to be great till then Colonist starving to death becasue they forget to eat 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198025218414', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1675390815}
review:
The game is actually a ton of fun, if you happen to be fortunate enough to have the exact configuration the game supports.

With an early-access game, I expected AI glitchiness, gameplay mechanics that were unfinished, and occasional crashes.  What i got instead was a game that got me addicted completely during the first session, and then refused to ever launch at all again.  It's incredibly frustrating to see other users reporting the same issues, and the devs continuing to add features and push the game content forward without fixing a game-breaking bug relating to AMD graphics cards.

I'm still hopeful that I'll either get a response to my multiple requests for assistance in the forums, or that there will be a fix that makes the game usable again.  Until then, I can't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091937424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1276, 'last_played': 1546735921}
review:
This title has been in my library since I supported it in Early Access a few years ago - I go back to try it every couple of updates (hoping that the major issues have been repaired), but still no luck:

Pros:
 - Nice concept/style, I can see why it's attracted attention over the years.

Cons:
 - A tasking/AI-centric game with terrible AI. We're talking colonists running out of the airlock with no suit on, people standing motionless in burning rooms until they're incinerated and no prioritisation to job queuing so critical life support machinery will not be repaired because everyone's too busy following each other around in circles or all waiting for the same (broken) machine. The order you create jobs in is ignored, and even completely clearing the queue won't get your colonists to repair that air filter before they all suffocate.
 - Alerts/announcements that become repetitive and annoying, particularly environmental warnings that you can't do anything about because your colonists are all sat in the lounge ignoring you.

This is a game I really want to like, but no number of cosmetic updates can paper over the fact that it's just not playable with this level of AI dysfunction. The developer needs to get someone to troubleshoot the queuing/pathing - until the basics are sorted I'd save your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004778797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1486882417}

review:
Stand: Version 0.69 Release! (Review nachbearbeitet und Empfehlung angepasst)
Maia spielt sich gut und es hat meine Erwartungen erreicht. Ich bin auf die angekündigten weiteren Features gespannt und kann im derzeitigen Release-Zustand guten Gewissens zum Kauf raten.

=====

Stand: Version 0.65 (Review nachbearbeitet und Empfehlung angepasst)
Die Entwicklung geht sehr regelmässig im 2-Monats Rythmus voran. Die Updates bringen auch jedesmal einiges an Inhalt. Der Fortschritt ist solide, aber immernoch sehr schleppend (1-Mann nebenberufliches DevTeam?).
Falls die finanziellen Ressourcen reichen um das Spiel fertigzustellen, dürfte es ganz nett werden. Ich hoffe dass es sich noch oft genug verkauft um dorthin zu gelangen.
Da sich das Spiel mittlerweile recht gut spielen lässt und einiges an Inhalt bietet, kann ich nun zum Kauf raten.

=====

Stand: Version 0.46
Maia hätte eigentlich Potenzial und seine Reize, nur zieht sich die Entwicklung dermassen schleppend hin, dass das Spiel zum finalen Release wahrscheinlich veraltet sein wird. Derzeitig  arbeitet die Crew (und Imps) ihre Tasks nicht speditiv ab und läuft oft desorientiert herum, was nicht nur ihre Überlebenschancen schmälert, sonder auch Spielfrust beschert. Zudem ist es immernoch schwierig herauszufinden wieso ein Crew-Member gestorben ist, respekive was man hätte dagegen tun können. Rundherum ist alles noch sehr experimentell und das Spiel stürtzt auch gerne mal ab. Ich kann zum derzeitigen Stand nur empfehlen mit dem Kauf noch eine Weile zu warten.

review:
Upon the personal request of the developer, I have re-played the game after my first review. Here's what I'v got to say

The game reminds me a good deal of dwarf fortress in many way. Firstly: You die a lot. Personally speaking, Im frustrated as I can't get a handle on the building which always kills me. Sometimes the humans are machines, making 4 turbines before lunch, other times refusing to build a heater because their cold. Many problems,bug, and preformance issues have been fixed, and I see good potental in this game, but untill  the problems with build order has some sense to it, I can not reccomend it, esspecially at a $25 price

Other Problems:
No way to check colonist skills
Alert system treats skill ups and colonists about to die as the same priority
Build system is rather buggy, and doesn't always make sense. Perhapse an in game tree of what builds what in the workshop?
Having to build wall screens to check atmos and heating doesnt make a lot of sense and is poor gameplay, as sometimes your colonists dont build them in any sort of resonable time.

I really wish the best for this game, and the dev, but right now I can not reccomend it
