author: {'steamid': '76561198033237630', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1531706938}
review:
This game has a lot of great potential. It's an Alpha right now and it shows. AI improvements should be priority #1 over texture/graphics improvements. Structure placement (i.e. placing hydroponics or beds) should be #2. I had a colony die because a hole opened up in the ground under one of my bulkhead doors and destroyed it, effectively cutting off my hydroponics room from the rest of the colony with 3 colonists trapped inside. I routed some new doors through another part of the complex but the colonists just wouldn't build them. So basically everyone on the outside of the hydroponics room starved to death, everyone on the inside died of fatigue because they couldn't make it to the beds. I hope there is a better save option in the next update, because crashes are going to hapen often. Also, my robot keeps getting stuck places and just stands there even though I give him a clear path and give new orders. Sometimes it gets stuck if it wanders into a spot where a colonist is building something. In my last game, mine got stuck inside the materials hopper.

I'm going to give this a recommendation because I can see where the developers want to take it, in hopes that they actually follow through and dont end the project in favor of another.

review:
The game seems like it will be good, and it has a lot more content than when i first picked it up when it appeared on Steam EA. But, it is somewhat unplayable right now. 
It randomly crashes, and the AI is either bugging out and colonists/robots end up stuck in place, or they are actually getting stuck. Colonists seem to get materials, go to work desk, and then repeat, endlessly. 
The UI isn't finished yet, even the main menu is bad - instant changing resolution when you click for the next one, and you can only click one way :/ .
So, I would recommend following the game, and seeing what it is like in 6 months or a year.

В общем идея игры неплохая, вот только сама игра забагана вусмерть.

UPD 23,06,16

author: {'steamid': '76561198039825635', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1422201610}
review:
В который раз зарекался покупать ранний доступ, но гребаные грабли...
Идея игры интересная. Это единственный плюс.
Минусы. 
Убогий интерфейс. 
Неписи очень тупые. В опреденный момент, вместо того чтобы строить нужные объекты начинают тупо жрать, спать и чинить то что было построено раньше. И никак им приоритет не поменять. 
Крайне неудачная система строительства помещений. Между двумя видами структур возникает так называемая room, которая часть блокирует работу дверей, сама она в шлюзах не нуждается пользы от неё никакой.
практически нет никаких логических подсказок. 
Дерево технологий отсутствует.
Перечень ресурсов отсутствует как таковой.
Короче игра очень сырая. Верните бабки!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197973589012', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 848, 'last_played': 1504257314}
review:
I love the idea of this game... it also looks really great. The weather effects are awesome. That being said, I have purchase several games in alpha and beta stages. I have been in invite-only beta tests also. I know what to expect and what not to expect from games in early stages, and this one is terrible. The developer clearly has little idea of what he's doing from a procedural point of view. In the time i've owned this game here's what's happened: several patches have been released, but the big problems haven't been resolved... neat new little content has been added, but with the game unplayable it makes little difference. This game is sure to disappoint over and over again. I waited so long to write this review because I wanted to see if some progress would be made, but it hasn't. The worst part of it is that the developer has had to go off steam (on kickstarter) to continue to raise money. Please save yourself the headache of downloading this game. If you do try to play, here are a few tips.
1) Save often. F5 saves and F9 loads... the icons at the top right also save and load, i'll let you try to figure out which is which
2) The AI is always getting stuck in stupid loops or just shutting down. This happens every few minutes like clockwork... you must save, exit the game, and restart it to continue playing.
3) Things don't update like they should... if you mine ore but can't figure out why it isn't being moved to storage... it's probably AI to blame again... another reload should help.
4) Sometimes things stop working inexplicably, If the airlock breaks and cannot be repaired, you must start a new game. some things can be repaired though, so who knows.
5) Always place two doors on rooms... if the door breaks and needs repair, but your people are inside of the room, and the guys outside the room are too tired to do it and the door that's broken leads to the sleeping area... they might decide not to repair it and instead die from lack of sleep... leaving the others trapped inside to starve
6) Just get in the habit of restarting the game every few minutes
7) Don't bother with research, it causes bugs which basically cause the game to crash beyond a certain point... meaning you'll never get past that point without starting yet another new game.
8) Use windows 7 or vista, and make sure you have the latest drivers for your graphics card (and by that I mean have a graphics card that uses newer drivers) The dev doesn't like helping with bugfixing if your computer doesn't use the latest drivers, despite the fact that some older cards (like the ones in my windows 7 machine) have old drivers (even if they are the "most up to date" they are still like 2 years old) and that still others (like on my windows 8 acer machine) require the use of special drivers provided by the OEM which may not be the "latest and greatest".
9) Don't expect too much, this way you won't be disappointed.

Edit: still... don't buy this game. It's on sale, but seriously... you wouldn't play it more than 30 minutes, even if it were free.

UPDATE: 21 May 2015... I'm not sure how it's even possible, but the game is even worse now than it was before.

UPDATE: 1 Sep 2017... Still going to be a negative on the recommendation. I advise staying away from this one a little while longer. The dev has continued on pretty much the same trajectory. New features, new bells and whistles, and failure to address very long-standing issues with the game. It still has graphical glitches everywhere. Sometimes a door will be stuck closed because of power outages, but it will never update. It looks open, but noone can get inside. Upon reloading you'll go "oh, that's why they weren't building anything... they couldn't get to the workbench". Sometimes colonists become unresponsive but seem to still be standing around. AI has improved, but not by much. Resolution problems and graphics problems. None of my OTHER games require disabling overlays or nvidia share. None of my other games are affected so horrendously by UI scaling (if you go fullscreen and can't click the buttons, that's probably why... this game hates UI scaling). None of my other games break horribly when my gpu drivers are a couple weeks out of date. The dev is better at writing exuse posts blaming the flaws in his code on everyone else's setup than he is at writing code to fix problems and address issues. The game is not as awful as it was, but at this rate it'll never be a thumbs-up game. In the past couple hours I've only had one crash-to-desktop.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977063672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 737, 'last_played': 1438724032}
review:
I backed Maia on Kickstarter and I feel that now is a good time for people to buy it on Greenlight. Personally, I think that Maia went to Greenlight too early, while there were still too many bugs and issues. But with 0.46 the game is stable and playable for many people and the future promise is just starting to show through. For new players there's probably a solid afternoon of playtime here, plus some replay value. There's no combat yet, but it's planned for the next build (0.47) and I imagine that this will boost re-playability a great deal.

I was initially drawn to Maia by the atmospheric trailers and the potential shown in the very first alpha builds. The aesthetic and design of Maia is fantastic. The art and music combine to create a slightly unsettling, suspenseful atmosphere that's lifted by the numerous little touches of wry humour and observation; many of which are genuinely clever. Hitchhiker's meets Alien.

If Simon and team manage to wrap their unique design around a enjoyable and challenging colony builder then this will definitely be a stand-out title for the future.

As a guide to what's coming next, here's a link to the 'rough' feature roadmap [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/252250/discussions/0/613939294454258196/] - Rough roadmap[/url]

If you still aren't sure then hold back for a month or two until the game is more fleshed out, but definitely keep an eye on Maia.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969096617', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1547643564}
review:
Release Update:

Simple: The UI menu is straight out of the 90s, equipped with a load in time of a minute for a selection of 4 choices and a spinning globe. After half a decade of the player base begging and complaining about one of the worst UIs of the 2010 era, the devs have not touched it since day 1. Now, 5-6 years later of development it no longer even functions on some computers, so sorry, as one of those people, I can't even review the game.

5 Years later, I can't even get this POS to start anymore, because the UI is so horrible it puts the start button off-screen and takes multiple ctrl-alt-del restarts to get fixed, which frankly is just not worth it. We went in reverse since last year, but apparently that logically means: "It's time for release!"

I purchased this game in 2014, in 2016 it was clear the Devs had absolutely no interest in fixing any issues the players were complaining about. So no fixes and long periods between meaningless updates eqauled a bad review which, back then got a lot of hate comments on my profile. I hope you all are eating crow now, yes the Dev truly didnt care as I said in my 2016, 2017, 2018, and now 2019 review. The game is -still- atrocious.

review:
Eigentlich ein recht geniales Spiel, tolles Konzept.
Ich würde mehr Stunden mit diesem Spiel verbringen.

Aber leider ist es seit dem letzten Patch fast schon unspielbar.
Man habe angeblich die AI gefixt, was aber dazu geführt hat, das sie noch dümmer geworden sind.
Und viele andere Dinge, die ein fortschreiten des Verlaufs erheblich erschweren.

Ich würde wirklich gerne das Spiel positiv bewerten, aber da es sehr lange her ist, das dieses Spiel ein Update gekriegt hat, und man somit nicht mehr anständigen Spielen kann, gibt es eine Negative Bewertung....

Mehr hier zu erfahren: http://steamcommunity.com/app/252250/discussions/0/613941122827455067/

/Edit: Und nach 3 Jahren hat sich das Spiel immer noch nicht verbessert. Die AI ist immer noch dämlich, laufen im Kreis, faulenzen, etc. Ich kann dieses Spiel keinem Empfehlen es zu kaufen, solange sich nichts verändert was die AI betrifft.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994879788', 'num_games_owned': 414, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1668088161}
review:
In its current build, the game is completely unplayable. Its list of faults is longer than a bad year, so I won't even try to name them all.

That said, it shows a lot of promise. I am looking forward to the finished product, when it is released. Judging by the rate of improvement thus far, that should be in the summer of 2029, or thereabouts.

I'd like to recommend it, but I can't. Currently it is simply not an enjoyable experience. In fact, one could argue it is not even a game yet, merely a concept demo. I can't say I regret paying for it, though, as I consider it money well spent in support of the game's development. 

I really do want this to be a good game. Or, failing that, at least a finished game.

Update:
Work continues. Although my colonists and the IMP remain utterly useless. The game is still completely unplayable, as the colonists will be happy to ignore everything you tell them to do, and thus promptly starve, thirst, or choke to death, as everything spontaneously bursts into flames around them for no damn reason.

"It's only early access" is not an excuse when not even the core mechanics are functioning, or even present. This game should not have been released as early as it was. It's still not ready for release.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086882386', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1413317427}
review:
Bought this game a while ago, like the market sale spiel, space versionof dungeon keeper, but with colonists, and a robot instead of imps. Oh and space chickens. Well I have played this twice and the game needs much more development. The tutorial is lax and needs more input, maybe hints of what to build first liek...oh I dont know and atmosphere generator (Will come back to this point). It took a few goes before I figured out that the robot is accessible, you dont click on it. you click on rock formations and he digs bits of the rock face out and you can then build your colony. No tutorial on how to use him though. Colonists are unuseable, they do what they want to do. 

I have played this a number of times and each time my colonists died of asphyxiation. Every time, even when I build atmosphere generators. This game is currently a no go without a decent tutorial. Its not a game per sae currently, its really a large project in futility and how to kill space colonists off the quickest.

Thumbs down, I bought this knowing it was an early access game and they are stillworking on it, but this ... is embarrassing, It does not hold a candle to Dungeon Keeper. And yes my hours played looks low. Trust me if you have a Vista or earlier made computer this game will crash badly. My hours are lower than what it says above, its included crashes and time i tried tofigure out how to fix it. 

In my humble opinion, wait 6 months then have a look at reviews on here. See if some of the issues have been fixed but there are better things to waste money on than this. Free to plays are plentiful, this kind of half made game is far to commomn on Steam. They need to look at these and decide whats worth keeping on steam and what needs to be taken off and developed a bit more.

Ok rant over 2/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198058356169', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1498797443}
review:
I have to say, this is a game I want to like. Its a great concept, but the execution is very poor.

I've been patronizing this game's early access since it was available for early access, and while some bugs have been fixed, numerous game-breaking bugs still remain. Its pretty-much unplayable still, despite several months development since its initial release.

Glitches in character AI get them stuck in routines that eventually lead to their deaths. For example, eating and sleeping, repeat et infinitum, while not working on the hyroponics bay. The AI seems to get deadlocked quite a lot. Since the characters start running to the food and then eating, I assume that the value for hunger isn't being reset properly.

There are also animation problems that seem to somehow reflect character position. Character position in the world should not be a function of the 3D engine. The location of objects should be purely data, which is then rendered. The reason why I suspect this isn't the case in Maia is because characters "jump" back, particularly after a collision with a wall. Yes - they walk into walls and then teleport back a few steps. So the pathfinding is bad too. I think this is because the objects in the world are not on a real "grid" system. While rooms might be, everything else seems to be kinda "free-floating" and placable anywhere in the room / outside. While this would be cool, it doesn't work right, so its not cool.

Also the object rotation system is very annoying. It would be much better if there were a "spin by increment" key prior to object placement. And objects can intersect eachother, which makes no sense.

Additionally 6 mo after launch there's still no save / load system. The game still starts with invalid start conditions (breaches in the base start point to the outside world makes colonists unable to move around in the cavern without space suits, and the airlock is on the other side of the base). There is no way to make a new game without exiting to desktop and starting the game over. The settings are very minimal, and there are enormous problems with resolution. You click and it changes, in a cycle, rather than selecting from a menu. This is terrible because it saves the last setting, and there's no "does this resolution work for you?" dialog. This means you can get yourself into unusable settings and be unable to get out.

Also the game performance is really quite bad.

Meanwhile the creators are adding content while there are still problems with the fundamental mechanics of the game. I wonder if they understand how unusable the game is right now....

review:
So I do think there are some good things about this game, but I highly doubt they'll ever be finished.  Just stay away until you see it out of early access, should that ever even happen.  (9/30/2017)


Old review below.  Was positive. (4/10/2014)


READ BEFORE YOU THINK THIS IS A PURELY POSITIVE REVIEW!!

I normally don't like to review games this early on because I really don't think it's fair to either the consumer or the devs to do so at this stage.  However I think a good number of the of the reviews have been a bit unfair.  A lot of the reviews aren't taking into account how early this game really is in development.  Yes that is the fault of the devs for jumping the gun, and putting it on the market, however the game does show a lot of progress, and it's a really good concept.  It is extremly buggy at the moment but that's to be expected of any early access game.  That's why I'm not considering the bugs in this review but I'm focusing on the content.  The devs have done a good job of keeping this game as a more realistic survival/ managment game, and that's nice to see, since it's not really something that has been done that much.  

HOWEVER! I don't write reveiws for the sake of the devs, but for the sake of the customer.  This game is a big risk!  It's very hard to tell how this game is going to turn out at this stage since it's in such a raw state.  I myself think that it's going to turn out well, and that's why I'm giving a positve review.  However unless you're a risk taker I would advise that you hold off for a little while before you buy this game, and keep an eye on it from afar.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977477995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1650914545}
review:
Get this game if you think a colony sim sounds like a good idea and want to support it, and only if you're the patient type. Development is slow, don't expect it to be playable any time soon. At this point it's full of game stopping bugs, and core game mechanics – work queues, colonist AI etc. – are barely working. 

Maia can be a great game, but it certainly isn't yet. To be honest I'm surprised that the developers released this as a paid alpha.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976164835', 'num_games_owned': 710, 'num_reviews': 292, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 747, 'last_played': 1542508842}
review:
Additional update edits are inside ++
++++++++++
Update 18/11/2018

If you're only going to read one part of this then here it is in a nutshell: In my first section of the review I say that I couldnt get colonists to build a hopper. No matter what I did. It is 4 years later and I STILL cannot get them to build a hopper.

Although there have been a number of improvements there are still so many situations where the AI Just simply doesnt work. From not deconstructing things to having colonists die and being unable to have more "dropped down" to you even when the timer hits zero. Having so many chickens in the livestock but none of your colonists will kill them even when theyre marked to be killed. Having colonists rush and build new items yet the leave items that are waiting to be built since the start of the game which leads to the error saying no path found to workshop even though it says when you place it the placement is perfectly fine and you build another workshop with more tables and they still cant build it. 

All in all this is early access but at the same time this game has had these issue since it was first put onto steam back in 2013... its now 2018... and after 5 years I can honestly say that there have been improvements but these improvements over the space of 5 years simply do not constitute a $24.99 USD pricetag when there are games that are the same price and A THOUSAND TIMES BETTER and fully released even after being developed on steam early access AFTER this game started development. A great example of this is subnautica.

I credit the dev team of this game to sticking with it in the long run as this is what a development team should do for an early access title. Taking a look at the feedback and continuing to improve on the game. However, I am honestly am at a point where after purchasing the game a few years ago I simply have no interest in it whatsoever anymore and honestly feel as though from this point onwards I consider this to be a failed project and do not think I will continue to update this review as I will no longer be playing it.

NOTE: I do not see this is a waste of money for me, I purchased the title because I was interested in it and wanted to see it develop further and sometimes these "investments" dont pay off and this is an example of that.

++++++++++
Update 17/01/2018

Let me start off by saying I honestly cant tell you if you will like this game or not... why? because I dislike it so much that I simply cannot find anything I enjoy. so here is just some input I have after playing the game for the first time since 2016. You wil notice there are 2 other review sections and each is from experience playing the game. the first is from September of 2014 (initial purchase) and the second is from August 2016 (return two years later to check progress).


As it stands the developers have removed quite a few bugs from the game and i praise them for that but to put things simply... they just havn't done anywhere near enough. This game has been in Early access for how long now? and to be perfectly honest there are a lot of games that START in early access in a better state then this game is at this point in time.  I honestly would be happy to say to the development team to focus their efforts on a new game. One that has a roadmap more refined and clear targets to be  set as this game is stuck in its own little development hell.

Now for some gameplay. In terms of the fundamentals its all pretty much there, buggy, but its there so you can play the game, however, the execution, feel and controls just dont make a lot of sense, the UI feels clunky and out of place and there just isnt any polish at all (which is soughta understandable for an early access title). There is not enough information given to the player a lot of the time or its just presented in such a way that it seems really childish (for a game about colonizing space... this just kills the whole "vibe" and with popups just being annoying as hell on their own.... not to mention some are just stupid. Like honestly... you're colonizing another planet... WHERE THE HELL ARE YOU MAKING MUSIC THAT YOU WANT ME TO HEAR..... you dont even have a damn atmospheric generator at the start.....

++++++++++
After purchasing a new monitor and attempting to play this game not only did i realise it doesnt support widescreen but that the features being added to this game seem totally pointless. I feel like I am playing a game from the early 2000 with features still in development. Seriously... its been so long now, HOW CAN CORE GAMEPLAY MECHANICS STILL BE A PART OF TESTING. Bugs are everywhere (including just trying to change graphical settings) and the gameplay is outdated to say the least. If steam had the refund option when i purchased this. I would have refunded it on the spot
+++++++++++


++++++++++
So a new patch has come out which for me, has been the biggest improvement since the beginning. I have actually managed to build a base! WOOHOO!! :D There is a bug that still occurs where the human AI get stuck and end up dying from starvation but I hope that this will be fixed soon!
++++++++++


This game COULD be great. But what lets it down most of all is the AI (A CORE MECHANIC OF THE GAME). For a game that has been in Alpha for almost a year now the AI is STILL SHOCKING to the point where the game is virtually still unplayable. 

People and the IMP get "stuck" and dont move leaving you to restard or watch them die.
The people don't build certain things even when they should be able to (For example I have NEVER been able to build a hopper, it just sits there unbuilt for countless amounts of time)
I've had people die from exhaustion because they refuse to build a bed.....

I have only played 4.4hrs of the game and watched tutorials on how to get people to do things but nothing ever works. this game needs a serious overhal becuase as it stands, I WARN YOU NOT TO BUY IT

author: {'steamid': '76561198051574839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2409, 'last_played': 1707875917}
review: 1st day, all animals go for unauthorised space walk, they dont give a damn about Maia, end day log. 2nd day, Wind turbine keeps breaking, mad race by colonists to be the one to fix it, all walk out airlock to repair it and three turn back, end day log. 3rd day, IMP bot walks through rock wall, doesn't return and took our water with it, so damn thirsty, end day log. 4th day, still no sign of the imp bot or our water, but thankfully we have a couch, end day log. NO MORE LOG ENTRIES! This game has plenty of bugs but hey its in alpha and I'd say it is pretty great! If you are into beating your head against the wall until you learn how to prioritise what you need to do this is most certaintly the game for you! Once you've got a strategy going the game becomes even more fun but the colonists need you to hold their hands at times, such as when they are wounded, I had to herd my colonists to the medbay by locking doors, didn't lose anyone but it was kinda annoying. Also if the AI glitches the IMPs movement or colonist movement when it comes to objectives just lock and unlock a door real quick and that seems to fix it, weird huh? But it works so I can't complain! This game reminds me of Space Colony by Firefly and some other developers, if you can manage to get your hands on a copy of that I'd recommend you do so post-haste! ANYWAY, buy this for hours of fun and haikus, and witty doors!

author: {'steamid': '76561198059773230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1545409981}
review:
Cannot recommend this game at all. The progress has been so slow and any updates have not improved anything. 
To make it worse is the price...should only be charging €5 for a game at this very very early stage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118427437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1410086613}
review:
The premise is good - build a colony on an uncolonised planet and ensure survival.

The problem is, there are a number of problems.

[list]
[*] Updates come once in a blue moon (pun intended).
[*] The GUI is clunky, basic and badly explained.
[*] Most items in the game appear to be "unbuildable" - i.e. you can place the blueprint but your colonists will never build them, even if there is nothing else to do. The only way to build them is using the "cheat" mode.
[*] Colonists randomly get stuck in walls / thin air.
[*] Full release is lightyears away (another pun intended).
[/list]

Give it a year or two and it may be a different game, at the moment on the rare occasion I play after an update, I'm still disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049759468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1556144248}
review:
На данный момент (август 2014) это не игра, а подлая пародия на жалкое недоразумение!
1) интерфейс - жутко неиформативный: нет ни показателей воздуха, ни воды, ни электричества, ни чего бы то не было ещё! То, что у меня кончился воздух, я узнал только когда начали дохнуть колонисты как мухи.
2) тот скудный интерфейс что есть - жутко неудобный: все действия нужно делать кнопками на клаве, даже невозможно просто выбрать нужную посторойку в меню. Как в любой нормальной игре - нажимаешь меню строительства и в графическом списке\таблице выбираешь нужный вариант, читая описания и требования. Но очевидно это не путь этой игры, здесь нужно циклично листать возможные варианты кнопками на клаве, которые ещё запомнить нужно...
3) обучение стоит переименовать в издевательство: после него только больше вопросов чем ответов: что, а главное КАК делать, ни примеров, ничего...
4) у объектов нет описания - на кой хрен они вообще нужны...

Долго думал покупать игру или ещё подождать... Теперь жалею что купил, судя по текущему прогрессу ждать нужно ещё пол вечности...

author: {'steamid': '76561198025156861', 'num_games_owned': 711, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1422402091}
review:
This game has equal parts potential and problems. It is buggy, incredibly buggy, with most sessions only lasting 20 minutes before a crash. That's when it launches properly, a third of the time it crashes to desktop. 

When the game does work however, it shows a lot of promise. I will be keeping track of the development and new updates, at the moment the game is confusing and lacking in customisation options (textures, graphics, sound etc.) 

I wouldn't say Maia is a must buy in it's current state, but if anything in the game seems interesting to you it could be worth  a purchase. 
Overall, wait for the game to "grow" a bit more, it might end up being great.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960289039', 'num_games_owned': 942, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 1551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 958, 'last_played': 1611361090}
review:
Edit 2: Update as of 23rd Jan 2021  (5-odd years later). Despite a new update, this game is still woefully unintuitive, with a clunky and underwhelming UI that had me doing things like accidentally deleting my airlock when i was trying to clear / unbind the current tool from my cursor (you know, where games would usually let you right click to stop doing a thing). 

It also still heavily, HEAVILY punishes people that don't know what they're doing. It will not give you reminders or UI feedback on what you're doing (for example, if you want to expand a room? nope, no idea what to do there), and gives you no hints if you're trying to do something wrong. 

The tutorial is still effectively the same since it was first implemented, and even though it has been 6 months since I last played the game, it still moves at a glacial pace, and still does not help you adequately navigate the hopeless UI. 

This game, as far as I'm concerned, is still an alpha AT BEST, which is a shame, because as you can read below, I had such high hopes for it. 

Sorry, Simon, but you should cut your losses or get some help with this game, because it REALLY needs other peoples perspectives. Particularly on the early game to new or long returning players. 

That said, if you enjoy bashing your head against walls while you try and figure out whats going on, having to restart a lot through trial and error, then you might just like this game. 

Edit: Update as of 29th April 2020 (4 and a half years later). The developer has become disenfranchised by the amount of work required to fix this game, and basically released this game from EA, bugs and all. The game works, and if you're lucky you wont suffer any of the game breaking bugs regularly, but don't expect to be lucky. Simon (the developer) moved on to a new game because Maia was not earning enough money for him.  

Maia is yet another cautionary tale of early access buy-ins, and it joins the like of Towns, Starbase DF-9 and games of their ilk that were abandoned, only to be picked up with half-hearted effort whenever the developer can be bothered.

Shame, it had so much potential, as you can see below in my earlier reviews. 

Edit: Update as of 4th Nov 2015, original review below for posterity and because it still has some valid points. The aforementioned save system works fine now, the game is a lot more stable, and has many more features and content. The AI pathing and priorities are still buggy, but the developer is working on them. 

The caveat at the bottom still applies, but there is more substance to the game now. Considering it was up until recently a one man dev team, its at least a good effort. Worth peeking at if you can get it on a 50% or more sale, not recommended at full price unless you're a big fan of the game concept and know what you're getting into.

---------------------------------------------------

A neat game with a good concept, but is nowhere near playable in any respect YET. Currently (as of 19th June 2014) the game lacks such features as working save system, game stability, solid AI pathing, room code management and much more. 

With more funding/staff or time this game can be amazing, but right now? Don't even.

As of current version I recommend this game, with a HUGE caveat; Know what you're getting into: An unfinished, very early alpha of what could possibly be a great game. If you trust the developers wont get sick of the game and run off with the money (anyone remember Towns?) then give it a go and see. If you want a fully functioning game, keep it on the wishlist and wait until it gets out of early access.

review:
A interesting game, considering past interest I've had in some of the game who's system of play have inspired the system for this one. I can see "Dungeon-Keeper" and "Evil-Genius'" trade mark right there and perhaps the "The Sims" as well.

I've only managed to get as far as  sussesfully adding a Workshop room with two of three Work-Desks and Two Working Lights before the Robot who digs the rooms out just froze and then started to move around in small circles depsite being given orders to dig out another room. It's the only thing in this game that can do this. Apart from retreive the rocks, rubble and other detrius from where he deposited after digging. Not much else could be done beyond this.

According to what I had been intructed to do in order to continue playing the game. I had to build a work shop with a desk and a light. 3 by 3 squares is the mnimum size requirement. For starters.

Thw rokshop is need to be built first before anything else can be done.

In previous gaming session, I had tried to make bigger rooms and had marked out acouple of them to be cleared as well as trying to furnish the other rooms as well  as outside. This was mistake. Evryhting should be done slowly and sectiojn by section or else pople start dying (Aphyxiation or Mal-nourishment.)and they need to be replaced and the robot just stops moving. Refusing to do anything. On two occsions, he got caught between the wall where it had been digging and the wall of the room that had been built by the human working on top of him. So, I need to be careful to let the robot do what it can first before the humans  perform their duties.

I think this needs to be addressed.

I might add a video later.

Looking forward to the finished product.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027590844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1403909720}
review:
What can I tell you about Maia? I can tell you that it has sat on my wishlist for quite some time before I bought it during the sale. I have watched with some interest as the game has developed. Having now, albeit briefly, played it for myself I can say that - in it's current state I cannot in any good conscience recommend this to my friends in its current state.

That's not to say that Maia hasn't got potential, it certainly has. But the fulfilment of that potential is a long, long way off.

The most glaring shortfall here is the staggeringly poor optimisation. All early access excuses aside, this is a game that is charging almost £20 to get players to poke around at what is currently available - the scope of which is very limited, and in my opinion, not especially fun either - for that money I would have expected that the game engine would be in some sort of state that was reasonably optimised for the very broad range of system builds that comes from PC customers. Whilst the game is not unplayable, it's always irksome when a system that vastly exceeds the recommended spec splutters along at 12 frames per second, like some elderly man with a cold. 

The second issue I had was with the minimalist UI. This is subjective and some people will like it, but for whatever it's worth, I didn't. Having to blindly cycle through construction options using 1-9 and B and V felt unintuitive and was something I can't ever see myself getting used to. That being said, I liked the way I could place items pretty much wherever the hell I wanted in a room, that felt smooth and comfortable to get along with.

Another thing that struck me was the very sparce tutorial. Alright, alright, so it's not rocket science this and for the majority of people, there isn't much that is going to need explaining, you can figure stuff out just by playing around with the game, plus it's an alpha, I have yet to see a game in it's alpha state that has a fully fleshed out tutorial. Nonetheless, I feel that the areas covered by the tutorial were hastily put together, and not especially informative.

Whilst i'm on the subject of tutorials, the dialogue. Being British myself, I 'get' that whoever wrote the tutorial was attempting  to create the lofty humour of a smug, arrogant ai. However. At the early stages of the game, it's a bit jarring, and doesn't lend itself well to imparting knowledge. Those of you who played Frozen Synapse may remember the tutorial and it's deeply condescending dialogue. That worked for two reasons: 1. It was offset by a more pleasant dialogue as a counter and 2. It was voice acted so it felt like a infinitesimally intelligent ai and not, in the case of Maia, simply the developers quietly sneering at it's customers. In this instance it comes across as not only churlish, and dare I say, a little rude, but also because of it's delivery, entirely misses the target of being funny.

Another bone of contention was that there was no feedback to see what was being worked on. Not being one to build one thing at a time, I slapped down a load of stuff and waited. It was hard to tell whether people were working on something, or just running around like lunatics. Another thing is that I had very little feedback on what it was that my colonists needs were at any given time, it would be nice to be able to see a general overview of that at a glance.

Maia might be a good game one day if it's devs stick to the plan and don't get too lost in the woods on the way, but it's a long was off that chequered flag, and at this juncture there really is no guarantees that it will be good in the end. My enthusiasm has certainly been significantly dowsed by playing the game in it's current state, and I have to say, I regret paying the money, but you never know, maybe i'll have gotten a good deal in the long run, only time will tell at this point. Only really worth investing if you really have an overwhelming desire to support the developer or have an incredibly optimistic disposition. Elsewise, wait and see.

TL;DR --- One for management/stategy fans to stick on their wishlist and check in on every so often.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971548533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1406162163}
review:
Après avoir testé ce jeu pendant deux heure, voici ma première impression...

Ce jeu à quelque chose de plaisant, bien sûr, il n'est encore qu'au début de l'alpha et le jeu contient très peu de chose, mais il est assez plaisant de regardé les gens travailler,

mais on se rend vite compte que le jeu n'est pas amical envers l'utilisateur en ce qui à trait au commande,

il est impossible de configurer les touche que l'on veut utilisé, chaque personne à ces touche qu'il préfère utilisé dans tout les jeux, ce qui rend le jeu asser déplaisant et frustrant quelque fois, comme nos petite manie d'utilisé nos touche habituel pour le déplacement de la caméra par example, je me trompe de touche à toute les fois, vraiement pas amicaux comme système d'interface...

les "FPS" ont des problème, le jeu est souvent sacadé,

le petit robot, le "Wimp" je crois, il lui arrive souvent de tourner autour des resources, d'essayer de les prendre et ne réussi pas, il va donc au prochain tas de ressource et ne réussi pas à le prendre, il va donc à l'autre tas de ressource et... ainsi de suite, il peut faire le tour de 50 ou 60 tas avant de ce décider d'en prendre un,

il lui arrive aussi quelque fois de rester à un endroit et de ne rien faire, il faut donc relancer le jeu pour qu'il ce mette en mouvement, ainsi que certain personnage...

pour ce qui est de nos colons, il ont une appetit de loup, il passe tout leur temp à manger et à boire, en moin de deux heure il avait déja tout mangé...

pour ce qui est de la construction, le jeu étant encore en alpha, il n'y à vraiement pas beaucoup de chose à construire, et pour ce qui est du l'agencement des pièce construite, de mon côté je suis bloqué, il nous est impossible de déplassé le sas de départ, il est impossible de le démonter ou d'en créer d'autre, ce qui rend le 3/4 de la carte innacessible, puisqu'on ne peut pas créer d'autre sas, donc impossible de faire d'autre sas sous d'autre montagne, ou de faire un sas de l'autre côté de notre montagne pour y aller...

il y à un gros problème avec les pièces principale qui existe au début du jeu, même si on peut défaire la première pièce ou l'on peut ranger le matériel, il est impossible de déplaçer le matériel, comme la nourriture restante ou les barils d'eau, ce qui rend l'endroit impossible à utilisé à d'autre fin même si on détruit la pièce...

le jeu à de beau graphiques, mais presque aucun sons pour l'instant, hologramme des objets avant le placement très mal fait, impossible de dire ce qui est le devant du derriere de l'objet, utilisation d'un système par point qui remonte à la programmation sous le système d'exploitation "dos",

les écriture qui apparaissent à l'écran sont presque illisible, tout est en vert pâle, une des pire couleur à utilisé dans un environement éclairé, il faut donc bouger la caméra pour essayer de trouver un coin sombre pour essayer de lire...

bref c'est un jeu qui est quand même plaisant, mais que je trouve présentement surévaluer au niveau du prix, pour ce qu'il offre pour l'instant, c'est un alpha que j'évaluerais plus autour de 10$ et non 25$, mais bon, ce n'est pas le premier alpha à ce surévaluer, beaucoup on cette mani, l'attrait de l'argent sans doute ha ha ha..., mais bon ça reste mon opinion...,

si vous désirer l'acheter, je ne le recomande pas au prix de 25$, dans son état actuel...,

pour ma part disons que comme c'est un jeu de création, trop peu d'option son offerte pour la création, et que la création de pièces peut être problématique, dans mon cas ma créativité est bloqué, causé par le manque d'option et de réarangement des pièces et des objet que l'on ne peut déplacé...,

pour l'instant c'est plus un petit jeux de passe temps, mais il ne faut pas trop utilisé notre créativité car l'on sera vite bloqué par tout ça...

mais le concept est interessant et le jeu semble avancé vraiement très lentement, mais peut-être que dans quelque année nous pourons laisser notre imagination fonctionné...

je ne recommande pas ce jeu comme je l'ai dis à cause de son prix trop élevé pour la qualité offerte, mais je le recommande si les gens peuvent l'avoir à prix moindre pour encouragé le créateur, car il semble faire son possible, et si vous aimer ce style de jeu, car bien que ce qu'il offre soit peu, il reste quand même interessant, mais ne le prener pas trop à coeur pour l'instant, car les "bugs" vous rammenerons à la raison asser vite ha ha ha

author: {'steamid': '76561198012562469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1412389276}
review:
Brilliant concept and engaging mechanics.

Absolutely horrific UI.

"Make sure that the system communicates what’s happening.  Always inform your users of location, actions, changes in state, or errors. The use of various UI elements to communicate status and, if necessary, next steps can reduce frustration for your user. " There isn't even any indication you saved. For that matter there is no keybinding available.

"Use typography to create hierarchy and clarity. Carefully consider how you use typeface. Different sizes, fonts, and arrangement of the text to help increase scanability, legibility and readability."
Needing to hover over somethign for 30 seconds to read the tooltip is not okay.


Let's use the basics:
"
1. Does this interface tell me what I need to know right now?
2. Is it easy to find the information I'm looking for, or do I have to look around for it? (Are the menus nested so deep that they hide information from the player?)
3. Can I use this interface without having to read instructions elsewhere?
4. Are the things I can do on this screen obvious?
5. Do I ever need to wait for the interface to load or play an animation?
6. Are there any tedious or repetitive tasks that I can shorten (with a shortcut key, for example) or remove entirely?
" Maia fails to pass any of these test except for number 6, and even that is only half passed as you need to search the internet just to find the keybindings.

Great game, with an unplayable UI/UX.
But, hey, it is early access.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007094206', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1411809832}
review:
Je recommande ce jeu pour son concept original . Il reste cependant très bugué ( sous Windows 7 ), ce qui nécessite de relancer le jeu : personnages se déplaçant au ralenti, robot qui cesse toute activité, affichage qui se fige, personnages qui meurent de fatigue en dormant... Existe-t-il un système de sauvegarde ? Je ne sais pas, je n'ai pas encore survécu assez longtemps pour en avoir l'utilité .

     Sinon, pour bien démarrer :
- Commencer par sélectionner quelques zones rocheuses à l'aide de l'icône-main ( celle de gauche ) . Votre robot ira les creuser automatiquement, ce qui vous procurera les matériaux les matériaux nécessaires aux autres constructions et agrandira votre zône constructible .
- Installer une zône de travail pour agrandir votre base ( icône centrale ) . Y installer une table d'étude et la machine-outil ( icône marteau à droite ) .
- Positionnez des générateurs d'air, l'asphyxie étant le premier risque mortel et pour qu'ils fonctionnent il faut au moins une éolienne ou un panneau solaire à l'extérieur . Attention à ne pas laisser entrer l'atmosphère planétaire !
- Ensuite, l'ordre de construction me semble moins important .

Conclusion : un jeu à surveiller mais loin d'être terminé .

author: {'steamid': '76561198031302987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1409652026}
review:
Maia shows promise, although in the way of being so little more than a bare-bones engine, that anything is possible in the end. It could be that (judging by the progress speed that makes continental drift seem fast) in half a decade it will evolve into the most amazing colony sim ever. Or not. Who knows?

But at the moment, it's NOT a good use of your money. As was said, it pushes the limit of what is acceptable to release as "early access". It's just a bare-bones graphics engine, with some minimal and BROKEN animations, a non-functional AI, and no save and reload either, so your progress WILL be lost each time you exit.

And by "non-functional AI" I don't mean "might not prioritize right", but as in "doesn't even work, or not for long." Colonist AI routinely craps itself and either stops building anything any more (lucky version) or you just get a colonist going catatonic in the airlock and never moving any more (more usual version.) And when you do get it to work for half an hour, it will prioritize the hilariously wrong thing, like everyone keeping repairing the doors instead of building the air purifier.

Now that might be palatable (not really) in a game where you can direct them around, like in The Sims, and the AI only keeps them alive in between. But here you can't direct them, and the WHOLE premise is that they do their own thing, a broken AI just means a broken game.

Etc.

Really, it has no excuse to be released at this early and dysfunctional stage. It may eventually be worth playing. Save your money for then.

Update for 0.44: 

Upon starting the game, I proceeded to place the workshop and dig a small tunnel to one side, and a 4x4 tile hole there. Partially because you NEED minerals, and partially because I needed somewhere to place the hydroponics bay. I must stress that I wasn't digging some grand ballroom hall, and I was mindful that it has plenty of all rock walls on all sides, because I did read the update notes about earthquakes. When that was about half-way dug, the ceiling promptly collapsed, squashing the only digger robot and two of four colonists, who were there to take minerals.

So basically, instead of fixing the existing problems, it just added a random "*BANG* you're dead!" event, the hallmark of incompetent game design. Yippee.

Well, regardless of how you personally feel about that kind of events, to my mind it just further illustrated the point of why shouldn't you buy a game that's not even in alpha yet: you don't know what you're going to get for your money. The kind of gameplay elements that the final mix will have can just as well be what you like, or what you hate, and there's no way to know which it will be, as there doesn't even seem to be any plan.

review:
Jeu en Alpha de chez alpha test.
Pas mal de bug, crash récurant etc...

Pourtant je pense qu'il en vaut la peine, car le principe de base est vraiment sympatique. A voir s'il est prévu que la personne qui le développe en solo vas s'associer a une boite pour finaliser son projet ou pas. J'espère en tout cas, car le jeu promet.

En clair, il sera interressant a sa sortie, une fois rendus a peu près jouable, avec des sauvegardes récupérable qui ne crash pas systématiquement, et un problème de lag et ralentissement récurant réglé du fait (sans doute) de conflits d'IA ou de textures...

Attendez qu'il sois un peu mieux déveloper pour acheter donc.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038738212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1482957095}
review:
Not one to normally write a review of a game, but here is mine...

This game just updated, saw the 2nd trailer of the new stuff the game introduced so i bought it to try it out myself. After about 20-30 min of playing, this is what i've experienced
- Game play started to get choppy
- Colonists randomly going unresponsive (guessing death)
- No indication of what they are needing to stop the deaths
- No way to control the AI's to make sure they are getting their necessities such as sleep
- A livestock farm I made had (my guess) about 200 chickens in it which lagged harshly
- Multiple crashes (no autosaves)

Now, im not dissing the idea, its a wonderful concept that isn't in most games. It just has a way to go... Give it maybe another 2-5 updates and it should be playable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998156029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 436, 'last_played': 1618483320}
review:
Sadly the negative reviewers either failed to understand principles behind early access and the development cycle.

Does the game have bugs and sometimes become unstable?, yes. This is because the game is still in development, the developmer is pretty quick to fix issues.

As for grouping units and so on, it's not that sort of game. Your role is to set orders for build, maintain your base and those inside.

The game is still early in development, I would suggest those looking for a complete game, lacking in patience, wanting a polished product to wait for release.

I really enjoy the game, especially after the last patch.  
Still have much to learn with resource management and and the more technologically advanced bits and bobs.

Really interested to see where this game is heading. 

As stated above, if you're unsure wait for a few more content patches, read forums and ask questions to see how the game is coming along.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036870255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3924, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1466546279}
review: What is there to say about this very Early Access game. Released too soon? Yes. There is no legend or key to show what the wants and needs of the group members are. All of a sudden a team member is running then dies for no reason. Far far far too much micro managing with absolutely no feedback on whether or not what you are doing is constructive or will cause death. Should be renamed 'build stuff and lose... in space!' Build too many essential things which are needed (turbines) and watch your crew spend all their time maintaining and repairing machines and completely neglecting everything else such as eating or sleeping. Nice concept but a very very long ways left to go on balancing the game play, NPC control, and micromanaging EVERYTHING.

review:
Update:::::

I am NOT gonna Recomment this game.. The game developer startet out with wanting 18 euroes for the game witch was more than enough for the game as it were. Now the game is up to a staggering 22 euroes!! and thats for a game that dosnt even work probaly.. The developer is just too greedy.. At the games present state i´d say its no more than 12 euroes worth at the very best.. 8 euroes if you wanna be fair about it... DO not support the developer in this greedy project that has nothing to show for it.. sure its ok Graphics got somne good features in it... but the game crashes all the time.. colonists die all of the sudden for no apparent reason and the list goes on.. DO NOT BUY!!!

Off too.. even with only about 90 minuts of playtime i can already now say that this game needs alot fo work before it is playable.. 

Before i go further i´d like to say that i really think this game have potential and that is the reason i recomment it.. However

Even with only 90 minut of playtime i experienced several major issues that makes this game unplayable in its current state..

1: Game crashes to windows on a frequent basis for unknown reasons.. I have 12GB DDR3 Rams a Radeon 6950 HD 3D graphics card with 2GB intergrated GDDR5 rams and an i7 8 Core processor.. i KNOW my computer is not the issue. witch leaves the coding of the game as the problem.. This is something the developers needs to adress Assap if they want any success in keeping this concept alive.. 

2: The game seems to slow down when you open a mail from one of the colonists.. this would be completely okay if it was not for the fact that sometimes the game stays in slowmotion and there is nothing you can do about it other thanm restart the game witch brings us to problem number 3.. 

3: The game seriously needs a save game option.. The crashes = start a new. The game bugs out on you = start a new
The game freezes = start a new.. so on and so on..  you get to play like 10-20 minuts at a time and the game halts for one reason or another.. and then you have to start from scratch again cause there was no Save option.. 

4: Another thing that can make the game very heavy to play or even unplayable is the introduction to windpower mills.. As soon as i placed a couple of those and the game started to slow down.. The more machines i put down the slower the game became.. untill i at last gave up and quit.. 

There is probably more than what i have written here.. and as i said to begin with i would recomment it.. It is up to you guys out there considering to play this game wether you wanna support a alpha version that have ALOT of work still there needs to be done.. My personal oppinion is that 18 Euro is way too much for a game that hardly work yet Developers needs to make some drastic changes to the game coding if they want this game to be successful.. Each day that g oes by without changes i highlighted will be another nail in its coffin..

author: {'steamid': '76561198029126609', 'num_games_owned': 427, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1547772756}
review:
I have been following Maia for a while now, infact it was first anounced while I was still in middle school, and being a big fan of retro futurism and colony managment the game peaked my interest.

Now the game has come out while I am in college. Was it worth the wait?

Yes and no. Maia is a game definitley with a lot of style but perhaps not enough substance. The game looks great, has a awesome retro futuristic style, and is engaging enough with its development of the colony. Considering how it was all made by one person over several years, its impressive Simon got this far. It feels nice to slowly build up your under ground base and the cheeky humor keeps things lively. The sound effects also remind me quite a lot of system shock 2, which is a big plus in my book. The missions give a lot of structure to the game, more so than the generic sandbox mode does and the dialogue is engaging enough, albiet a bit bland. 

However the game has its issues. It doesnt have the in game longevity one could hope for or enough substance in what can be built and done after 5-8 hours. Not enough interesting dynamics or systems exist like seen in Rim World to keep the moment to moment interesting enough. The game is still missing features promised early in development and probably could of done with some of those extra stretch goals that didnt come to fruition. 

Even the fauna could have used more. Theres only three alien types and they dont look really "alien" at all. Im rather dissapointed by how boring and sparse the aliens are.The threat posed by the world was over stated and a bit dissapointing. Furthermore the games missions are often vague and the game with holds critical information from you in non sensical ways. They could have done with a far more traditional UI and control scheme. I encountered my fair share of bugs too that made doing certain missions impossible with cheating. 

TLDR; Maia is a pretty game with a lot of cool style and engagment but in the long run this doesnt make up for its lack of substance and other issues. If you ask me this is probably more of a beta than anything. That said its cheaper than Rim World and despite its issues is hardly a bad time. Just dont go in with too high expectations. Still I want to congragulate and thank Simon for sharing his awesome dream with us. 

6.5/10 slightly above average

author: {'steamid': '76561197962046323', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1428436587}
review:
I would not recommend Maia, YET!

Its a very good insight into what will possibly happen but as it stands right now it is nothing more than a tech demo. There is no save game feature and you cannot progress any further than what you start off with. Basically its a colony game without colonists or any form of expansion.

What is currently in the game is a handful of objects for a handful of rooms. A couple of those objects have an unknown function and nothing is really explained about the objects or indeed the colonists that you have. There is no way to get any more colonists as of yet and pretty much as soon as you build all the rooms and fill them with items you have acheived all that you can.

The graphics are pretty good and although it has some clunky animations and is still rather buggy it will no doubt be polished quite nicely. It DOES have the potential to go far but even compared to other early access titles it just doesn't have enough content to even class as a game yet. Its simply a tech demo.

Keep it on a watch/wish list and get it when its at a game like state.

EDIT: As per the developers response you CAN save the game using keys F5 and subsequently using F9 will load your last save. Again this is obviously an unfinished feature but its a lot better than starting from fresh all the time!

P.S. This review isn't intended to be negative towards the project, I love whats been done so far and im routing for Simon to get an good job done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053263016', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1458428996}
review:
It said early access and it is, the game concept has a lot of potential and i look forward to new updates.
As for now. the 0.40 is not much more than a tech demo that shows a few parts of the game mechanics and basically works as a sandbox to test the implemented features for example machines need way to much maintenance and natural disasters like earthquakes or solar flares? happen in a row. But that's not a problem, balancing of features is an beta thing, currently its alpha that means basic features are just implemented right now.

As for the current 0.40 state the game will not satisfy someone who is looking for an actual game with content, it is much more of a test build but it sure looks promising for everyone who wants to get a picture of the game mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981499887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1490078326}
review:
I have tried to like this game.  I really have.  But it is one of my biggest early access regrets.

The AI is simply awful.  The settlers are complete idiots, and will not do simple things like build food planters to help themselves survive.  Instead they will wander in circles and grab their stomachs, wondering why they are so hungry.  They won't build beds, but then they'll wander around random rooms until they die of exhaustion.  It's stupid.  The chickens are more intelligent than the settlers ffs.  The devs either need to vastly improve the AI, or add in a way to control or at least prod settlers to do what they need to be doing.  I understand the whole "early access" concept, but this is like one of the basic premises of the game.  If the settlers can't even stay alive on their own for an hour, why the **** am I playing?

I wrote a review of this a long time back, when it was more or less a demo at full price.  I didn't recommend it back then, but someone on the dev team commented asking me to try the game again and do another review.  Well, here you go random guy.  The game is still bad, I still don't recommend it, and thank goodness for games like The Forest, Subnautica, and Project Zomboid, or I'd have completely lost faith in the EA concept.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001484701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1415915467}
review:
This is another example of a " half-baked to make a buck " game. This is why indie game's don't sell. I want my money back.

This game stinks. I'm sorry I voted for it in greenlight. I'm very sorry I wasted $24 on it. I'm even more sorry the publisher recieved any of my money. Crime shouldn't pay.
It doesn't work with Window's 8.
I had to put the Maia.exe into XP sp3 compatibility mode to get it to launch. Still it only would launch 1/3 of the time. It goes looking for driver's that should be provided, if needed. Once inside the game, the controls are terrible. Most of the time they don't respond. I couldn't get it to demolish doorways to expand rooms properly. The game kept wanting to place things instead.
There is no sidebar to select the items you want to place, like in any other building game. There is no demolish button. You have to go into the main game file and open a readme text file to find out what the controls are. There should be a sidebar icon for each of the controls, like any other building game. In game messages are very difficult to even read because they are distorted by a pointless green line distortion effect... Forget anything like a voice tutorial... The 2 main challenge's in a game shouldn't be getting it to launch or getting the control's to work.  I don't care if game publisher claim's this game is in perpetual Alpha. I expect $24 worth of game for $24. The can be no excuse for the shabby state of this game. This looks like a project someone got lazy and gave up on.

review:
I feel like I would love this game if I had any idea what I was really doing. The short (but very humorous) tutorial tells you how to move the camera and how to place rooms and not much else when there are certainly more things to be explained. For example the game said it was toxic and dangerous outside and so I just assumed I couldnt go outside until I unlocked something but after an embarrisingly quick death I couldnt figure out what I did wrong but the next time I played I was told to just put something outside (by an external source) and what do you know, they have SUITS! would have been nice to know. I built at least one of each type of building but couldnt figure out what any of them did. They said I needed a workbench but after I managed to build one I had no idea what it did and I only figured out what that robot did by watching that video.

Long story short : Cool idea but PLEASE make the tutorial more indepth!

review: Maia is a space colony building game, it has great potential and can be the next colony building game. However it is currently in the stages of development, it laggs like crazy when the performance is on high, and it has very little content in it! You can play this game for maybe 10-30 minutes maximum, and then youll be bored. It currently has no save option, and it only has a "creative" mode, where everything is buildable, and nothing costs anything. The game has many bugs, and few features. Do not buy this game unless you are trying to help the devs and give constructive critisim, to help them make the game the way the community likes it! I will not make another review untill more features have been added.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012308986', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1508684062}
review:
So the I decided to pick this game back up and try this game out again. I wasn't really planning to ever really try this game out again or have really thought about it at all. However the dev reply to my review(which you can read at the bottom) and I felt obligated to at least give it try again. I mean it has been almost four years so it has to improved somewhat in this amount of time.


So launching the game brings me back to when I first played this in 2013. The menu screen is the same. Which is very limited, you got "Launch", "Settings", and "Abort". I am a big fan of having the ablilty to select/adjust a wide veriety of Game Options and Settings. With this game as a "BETA' now. I expected that you can do a lot more with more information available to you. My expectation was fully crushed. The UI is simple, too simple that it makes it very annoying to change any of the settings. It's set up as something you would see in a console game ten years ago. You have to toggle through everything first to know what is available to you and then toggle again to your choice. Of course toggling the different textures crashes the game. The only "Auditory"(audio, why not just name it Audio and keep it simple?) option is to turn music on/off.

The game itself looks the same as before and there is a little more information than before during gameplay. However the UI just makes it really annoying. Everything just pops up on your screen overlaying the game with that old school green text. Since it just overlay your live game it makes it very difficult to read. You end up not wanting to read it and just click "Y" over and over again to close them out. Also the building controls are not thought out well. To build different areas you have to toggle 1-9 to select the type of area you want to build then select the ground. Why not have a build menu? or at least just make it where you build a basic zone/structure and then select what that desinated zone will be. Which then the colonist just modify it to said type. Everything is just too simple that it makes it unproductive and hinders your gameplay. BUT! its okay you have a pet dog, you are only barely surviving so having a dog before a way to feed yourselves is important.

Right now, with what the game is currently I could not reconmend this game to my friends. Maybe in another four years, it will improve enought that I will enjoy MAIA and be able to tell others the same. Okay so this is my original review back in 26Dec2013


Maia is sci-fi strategy simulation game by Simon Roth. The game is currently in Alpha however it seems to be very pre-alpha at the moment. The game has a lot of potential but is lacking a few features right now. One of the biggest issues I have seen is the ability to save, right now there is no saving feature. With that, it doesn’t matter how far you have progress, in the end you have to start over again. There are a few glitches where your Colonist and Robot worker will ether stop working or would not complete tasks assign to them. The tutorial of the game is very limited but having them pop up is the annoying part.

The good thing is that if they brought out updates and improvement it might become a great game. However, so far it has been 22 days since the steam launch and it has had zero updates so far. If that changes or the game get better I may have to come back and change my review. This review is based on what is available during this stage of the alpha.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019028864', 'num_games_owned': 1023, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1443162366}
review:
In it's current format, Maia is not a playable game. I would say that it is currently in VERY early Alpha stages. Graphics are up and running (for the most part), but that's about it. The actual gameplay is not really implemented, and the parts that are there are not easy to figure out. There's no way to change the settings, no way to look at the key mapping (a critical thing in any new game), and it's really just trial and error.

I'd advise putting Maia on your Wishlist and waiting for about 6 months or so. It looks like it has a lot of potential, but it has a way to go before it's even in an Early Access playable form.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972430628', 'num_games_owned': 462, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 9304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4598, 'last_played': 1630914275}
review:
Amended Review. (Original Review 12/2013)

Still an early Access game at this point, and now apparently abandoned.

MAIA is rough. Still "Alpha" rough. 

There's great potential here, but I'm rather hesitant to recommend a game this unpolished and unfinished to anyone. For now, I'd advise waiting, and returning when the team delivers that final software.

However...

If you're willing to tolerate the slow pace of development necessitated by the small team, then I do really think that there's a gem on the way here. It's still early days, but the game has come a long way since I first played it in 2013, and the development team has continued to roll out updates, including feature additions and bugfixes indicative of ongoing long-term development and support.

As long as you understand that you're getting in on an alpha, this might be worth a look. Just recognize that it's not a finished product yet, and given the pace of development will not be ready for that final rollout for some time, if ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036792088', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1414265365}
review:
The idea of this game is good, innovative and has a great deal of potential....

But it is only that... Potential.  At the moment this isn't a game, rather a 5% finished application that rewards your exploration of new things with crashes.  Basic features, such as a save game, or even a proper explanation of what you should be doing are absent.  

It is wrong for STEAM to already allow this game under an early-access program.  It will take months, if not a year before anything stable comes out of this, and that is assuming the developer(s?) will continue work on this.

I don't recommend to buy this game, not until it is at least a few months from now.

review:
As with most alpha games this is far from finished, but promising to say the least. Its graphics look good and it features a nice and clean interface. Also the approach of you looking down on your colonists as though your an central AI or commander behind a set of security cameras give a real nice overall feel to the game.

Again, this is very early in its development, but with the planned game mechanics this should prove to be...interesting to say the least.

REVISIT 28-08-2020:

So, I don't know what happened during development, but basic things such as changing display resolutions completely ruin the game and I haven't even played it because it is impossible when the main menu buttons are waaaay off screen in lower resolutions. This is a thing I always check for because it seems trivial, but it determines how much respect the developer has for lower end machine owners and sets the bar for anything that follows from that. It is really simple; If you choose not to ask for available display modes and instead decide to limit the game to a specific set, at least make sure it actually works on those settings. I can deal with full lists with every available display mode and then have GUI elements disappear off screen, since that's easily solved in a patch or update, even after leaving EA. But to have this happen in a strict set of settings and still not get it right...that's just flat out wrong and the idea of text-editing a config.xml to resolve these GUI issues is 'BloodyShoddyLookingIfYouAskMe' (reference to the lowest texture mode available; It's actually called THAT).

What also rubs me the wrong way is changing settings are applied immediately, even though there is an 'apply' button at the bottom. I have to wait for the game to unload textures and load new textures when changing detail levels. That is fine, but do that when clicking the 'apply' button, that's what that means. Also, tell the user WHY the cursor isn't moving, none of the buttons work anymore and show a loading bar to tell the user how long it takes (approximately) before control is returned.

These are just 2 examples of very basic things right from the onset that just make sense and don't frustrate the user needlesly before even starting the game.

When starting the game for the first time, one is offered a tutorial. Following the instructions to the letter, not only did I manage to start a fire (unintentionally), but also stopped any future progress by building a workshop with a door and a workbench...since the game doesn't actually mark these objectives as reached... Missing the completion of an objective is pretty trivial if it is done every second or so, but it should never cause a game to become unplayable afterwards. Most games solve this issue by doing exactly that; Check it regularly, meaning within reasonable time but not so often that it will crash the game, and mark it completed once all the conditions have been met. Then never ever check back again unless it is a repeating objective. Again, this is one of those simple things that should not be a big deal; You (the computer) knows where to draw a workshop, door and workbench, so you know that they exist, so tick the bloody boxes already. If not this frame, then at least anywhere within the next 60 frames (means it should still be ticked after a second at most).

I'll be checking this game further over the next day or so, but I won't add (I hope) to this anymore lest I risk this becoming a 'what to watch for when making a game' tutorial... As it stands right now, these things are 'BloodyShoddyLookingIfYouAskMe' (sry for repeating that, but it just fits somehow)...

review:
This game looks like it has a lot of potential and I look forward to seeing how it progresses.

It should be made VERY clear though: at the moment this is more of a concept demonstration than a game... I'd say game play totals no more than 5 minutes.  'Early Access' is really a concept that's taken off big time this year and it can mean huge variation; there are games out there (example: Project Zomboid) which you can sink many dozens of hours into and others which are really just proof of concept.  Until the terminologies catrch up to describe the differences anyone looking for a playable game should always be aware of this before buying.
