author: {'steamid': '76561198014098113', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1430051987}
review:
Based on the addition of new content from 0.42 to 0.48 instead of addressing core interface issues I am no longer optimistic about this game's development. The game still feels pointless, there doesn't seem to be any way to prioritize certain actions over others for your colonists. You end up querying items like the Atmos processor and material hopper constantly to see how much stuff you have on hand. There is little feedback about how you are meeting or failing to meet colonists needs.

I do like the goal of this game, the graphics, and the sense of humor but it feels like "shiny" updates are being prioritized over core functionally.

I'd really like this game to prove me wrong and turn into a sensational game, but based on it's past year of development, I really doubt it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005811038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1612840605}
review:
Do not buy this. I regret Maia more than any other useless, unplayable purchase in the dark history of Early Access. Maia is absolutely beneath what's acceptable to release as an EA game. It does not even meet the minimum bar of quality for paid alphas.

As of this updated review, you're still paying for an extremely limited demo sandbox where you can place objects and watch animations happen. The setting can't decide whether it wants to be a realistic simulator (vital statistics on each colonist, food/water/atmosphere required for survival) or a complete joke (giant fuzzy extraterrestrial life). 

User interface design is not good, and it's difficult to tell what each control does. The current main controls for Maia are a series of badly documented hotkeys. One of the only good new features: you can skip the tutorial now.

But if you take one thing away from this review: the bugs are [i]show-stoppingly[/i] bad. I've experienced sudden framerate slowdowns on both Mac and PC, as well as crashes-to-desktop for no discernable reason. The colonist and robot AI will get stuck in walls or stand next to piles of rubble on no notice. There appears to be very little QA before each release, and minimal progress in fixing the crash bugs since I wrote my last review in 2013 December.

Summer 2015 Update: It still sucks. I'm not even going to sugar-coat this. It crashes and freezes even more than it did last year, and there's still no resource management or objectives to speak of. They literally just added more framerate-drop-inducing wildlife.

Maia isn't worth paying for and probably never will be. I used to think something good might come of it eventually, but after more than a year and a half I've lost all hope.

Summer 2016 Update: Still pretty unstable. They finally made time to fix a few bugs.

2019 Update: Crashed to desktop as soon as I started a new game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978095237', 'num_games_owned': 562, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1477170598}
review:
***Updated Review***

I last left a review / played this game about 3 years ago. I had many issues with the game then. This time around, the same applied. Still having issues with features of the game working.

Here is a list of things I had trouble with during my 4 hour playthrough (which is also up on my Twitch/YT Gaming/Hitbox/Beam profiles):
- Colonists move incredibly slow and thus, progressing through a game is excrutiatingly slow.
- Placing items/rooms is difficult. I had mined out the rocks between my initial default space and the empty space nearby and I hit a bug in which, I couldn't place any type of room in the given empty space.
- During the first mission I had to repeatedly find a new place to setup the microwave transmitter. The transparent showing of the object would be green, assuming to me it was a good position to place the transmitter, but then when placed that ghost object would be red. 
- Double clicking to prioritize jobs works some of the time I feel. I had the transmitter, some atmos gens and meat trolleys prioritized, but they were not taken care of in time and I failed the mission or my colonists died.
- I would like to see smarter AI...If I have my storage room setup with atmos gen and a small heater...I'd kinda expect them to hang out in there most of the time instead of venturing into other parts of the base to then die from cold exposure or asphyxiation.
- I had 2 or 3 crash to desktops as well during my 4 hour playthrough.

After trying out this game again, I still cannot recommend anyone to pick this up. I'm sure that Simon is the only one developing this game and it has got to be tough, but I am no happier playing now than I was 3 years ago. There have been improvements for sure since my last playthrough, but from alpha 0.1 (or w/e it was when I first played 3 years ago) to Alpha 0,58 there are still issues that I saw 3 years ago not addressed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975164320', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1543108856}
review:
I can see where the game is going from this. I like what I see.

One thing to keep in mind is that this game is in alpha. Now I know a lot of people go, "Oh I'm a software developer, I know what alpha is! This isn't it!" Those people are dumb and probably liars because, hey, this is the internet. So from a completely normal, non-developer girl: This game is in alpha. It's obviously in alpha. It is not feature complete. There is very little in the way of UI and things people expect to be there (like cancelling orders for objects) are not there.

But the concept is there. You can see things working. You can ooh and aah at the pretty graphics because they do look really freaking nice. One thing you can't do is play much. You can't save. Why? It's in alpha. Alphas are not feature complete. They lack many things we've grown used to and honestly take for granted in games. The developer isn't lying to you. They aren't tricking you. They're being very honest that the game is very deep in development. It says that right there on the tin.

So if you don't want to see and experience a slice of game development, if you can wait and be patient, or if you hate bugs and incomplete UI... Then don't invest in this right now. If you can't wait, if you like to see a game grow and change, or if you want to help with development then do invest in it.

So I'll say it again: I like what I see here. I can't wait for more. I mean, cats in bee suits? Come on. That's gold right there.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970978758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 1438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1398, 'last_played': 1543113902}
review:
Since my previous update, I have checked back on the game periodically. The stability of the game has greatly improved, but still not perfect, although this is to be expected with a game still in Alpha (0.57 currently). Just a few short notes below.

The game has not advanced much since 2013, and is still very barebones, the AI of the “colonists” and robots still requires a lot of work, with perhaps a system of prioritisation within the AI or user set. Examples are things like, building an item and getting “trapped” by the item, or temperature problems, but they will not build a heater when requested, the robot trying to complete non-existent build orders and refusing to do anything else, although these things are not my main worry about this game.

My main concern is that in the past two and a half years there has been very little progress and brings me to wonder if it will ever achieve release worthy standard.


--5th of December 2013----------
Keep clear for now, this is not worth being on Early Access. The constant crashing and memory errors that are being experienced by owners should be a clear warning to others.
--------------------------------------------

--18th October 2016----------------------
Avoid this buggy, poor product, awkward interfacee, horrible control scheme, with a just painful method of placing items in the world.

Over 3 years and still an unplayable heap.
--------------------------------------------

--3rd September 2018----------------------
I throught I would check back in on this game after leaving it for a while.

This game was set for a release in 2013, yet it is still in early access today, with very little changed in the last 5 years.

Unless Simon is holding back a lot of stuff for a big release shortly I would advise everyone to keep well clear of this. It sounded like a great project, but an incomplete, horrible UI and awkward interface leaves the game just plain bad. 
--------------------------------------------

author: {'steamid': '76561197982837520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1452552814}
review:
Maia is basically one of many atempts to juice up an old concept. Throughout teh years many games about colony survival hit the games market and only a couple gained a place in our memories. e.g. Outpost, Space Colony, Startopia. But, most of those games are lost in the vast endless space of cybernet.

So, how able is Maia in obtaining a place amongst our memory?

At this point, it's a buy and forget game. Not because of the way it looks, it's probably one the best looking colony survival games out there, but because of the way it tries to create an atmosphere. 
I don't know exactly why, but something is missing.. The feeling of survival. Why should I build s**t if I don't care. Why should I research things if I don't see the point in doing so.
This is probably because of the lack of any solid plot and future goal that keeps me interested.
Yea, sure, my goal is to survive. Yea, whatever, I'm playing a game, I want some glittering prices along the way and some motivation to do some crazy things. I'm playing a game to escape the dull side of reality, so please, don't show me my daily struggle. 
In other words, we need a good Visual Novel style content / plot / story. We need interesting characters and social dillema's.

If Maia is able to provide us with those things in the near future, well, in that case we might have ourselves a winner.
But, as long as it stays the way it is (Bugs not taken into account) it's a dull experience.

My final verdict, which might sound strange, is "Yes"not bad, actually pretty good, because it shows good potential.

On the other hand, I won't hesitate to put out a huge "NO" if the developers don't change the "Living" part of the game. The social interaction, story and story driven motivation.

Original Text:
Yeah no more early access games for me. 
I really love to support Indie game developers (and i did by buying this i guess) But to be fair and honest: This is not even Alpha. This is barely a short demo tops. No menus, no full screen, the game starts right away (by the way those darn messages are WAY too friggin fast!) So in the best interest for this game, which really seems to have potential. Let's wait for late beta i'd say. Do not let your opinion form just right now. By getting this now, you'll probably walk away from it, saying "what rubbish did i got again?" (like me). There is just so much missing that would make it an Alpha right now. I really like to see this evolving. But for now my thump remains down. If the game progresses in an acceptable manner i might rewrite this here and lift the thump.

review: Looks very promising early access game, plays very much like Prison Architect and Dungeon Keeper 2 combined. However, it is still very early early access. Even the most basic stuff worked only half the time, my colonists just disappeared for no reason, and after about 15 minutes, 3 of them got stuck in... well, nothing. If you are one of us suckers who can't resists another game that could be like Dwarf Fortress lite, go ahead and buy this game, but not yet. It's still in early alpha, and while it looks pretty, there's really no game yet.
